content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is by far the best zombie survival game you will ever play and this isnt even beta. I read reviews about the game being to predictable and that every 7th day is the most dangerous time to survive but I will tell you that is not true. I purchased 2 copies for my son and I to play and for over 150 hours we survived with no cheats. We have built several different types of structures to hold back the zombies including ones that may just be glitchs or exploits and we have found out some interesting things that may or may not change with later builds. Random gen is the only way we like to play. The unknown is what makes the game fun.Wood shack.. Like everyone else the first home we built was a little 10x10 wood shack. No windows, wedge shingled roof with center support with ladder for roof access. This shack only lasted a few days before we needed to seek something stronger.Underground.. We then found a good size neighborhood but was quickly overwhelmed with zombies and knew we wouldnt be able to bed down in the town and it was getting dark so we decided to make a big loop around the town to get the zombies off our trail and we began to dig a hole in the ground.  First night underground was stressful. The zombies become alot more active when the moon comes up and even underground we could be sensed. We didnt move one inch until the sun came up. The next day we decided to dig further underground and make a small cave for storage containers. over the next several days we extended our lair with tunnels under the town. We actually tunneled all the way to a house in the center of town and came up threw the floor only to be welcomed by zombies boarded up in the house. Our underground lair worked well until about day 100 then all hell broke loose. A little after midnight the game ai decided to send a large pack of about 8 dogs our way. We didnt think much of it since weve seen dogs come and go plenty but this time the dogs knew our location and circled around on ground level and starting digging in the dirt. It didnt take to long for them to dig a hole straight down into our cave and with our best efforts we tried to kill them. Didnt work. We had to abandon all our crates only to watch the pack collapse our lair destroying all our loot.Floating lake house.. Some days later we decided to give the floating house a try. It worked extremely well since the zombies acted odd when in the water and cant swim to the surface to attack our home. We lived in this home long enough to get 2k zombie kills and become bored with our home. The lake house is a great concept but the ai isnt able to do anything to you.. yet. Hopefully this will change since the game is all about keeping you on your toes.Cheats activated.. Bedrock spawned in. We now decided to work in creative mode and see what kind of structures can be built with the game physics as of now. We built a mega fortress out of bedrock with 4 floors, a water elevator, and a pitfall 65 blocks down to kill off the zombie horde. Now this sounds like the way you would want to play this game but we found this is not the best way. Because we used 1,000s of tnt and used power tools etc we heated up the map so bad that we had non stop hordes coming from all directions. This was still no problem for our fortress. The build was fun but after learning all the structure physics and just watching zombies come after us for days and never needing to do any repairs or kill anything we found ourselves bored again.So what now? Well the saying keep it simple is the way to go here. We restarted our server and decided to try the wood shack again but with some extra defenses. A 3 block deep trench with log spikes helped but the wood spikes made no difference. Placing the log spikes against the shack also helped alot. One of the biggest things we noticed was that using the crossbow let you be sneaky and kill and hunt without being detected even when close to dogs. For the remainder of our playtime we kept our part of the woods quiet and the only issues we have is the roaming horde every now and then but we just leave them be and stay out of site til morning. You will occasionally get a group of spider zombies scouting the area but we just snipe them off with our crossbows. This may sound boring but with this setup your not cheating the ai simply because you can make a mistake and draw to much attention only to find yourself running for your life in the middle of the night.Bottom line is this. The game is only in alpha so if you like the concept you should give this game a try. Hours of fun and off the edge of your seat madness. You will never feel safe and thats what makes the game fun. Keep it up pimps.

Early Access Review
								So.  Where to begin?  First off, I've really, really enjoyed this game so far.  Granted, it's only been four hours of gameplay, but that's from a general lack of free time more than anything else.  I will almost certainly have a different point of view than anyone who started playing earlier in the Alpha, so bear that in mind.  My opinion will not have been infected (no pun intended) by having to have played through any "broken" builds.  I'll also try to be concise.- To begin, "A mix of DayZ and Minecraft" really is a great way to describe the gameplay, though the zombies are more of a menace than they have been in DayZ for a while.- Next, yes, there is only one world.  It is fairly large, though, so I expect to get another 10-15 hours out of play into it before I might start getting sick of it.  And that's assuming that there's nothing interesting underground.  That being said, there is a random world generation option coming.  If I get bored with this world before it is released, then I'll just shelve the game, and come back to it once it is an option.- More than anything else, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND that you play with friends.  While playing solo was fun, playing with a friend or two definitely makes the game more enjoyable.- This game is fairly difficult.  I've only been playing on the medium difficulty, and I still have to be very careful to be in a safe place by nightfall.- As for how well it runs.... well, I have a decent rig, with a 2GB video card, and the game on a solid state drive.  With this setup, I can run everything on maximum with no frame loss or lag whatsoever.- The only "bug" I've encountered so far is with the zombie dogs.  Their pathing is rough, they're hard to hit when near because they usually spin in circles between attacks, and they occasionally glitch through walls.- Speaking of bugs, the big flying ones are super annoying, and really the only thing I've found thus far that I dislike.In conclusion, if you enjoy zombie themed survival games, enjoy games like Minecraft, and can get a friend or two to play with, you will almost certainly enjoy this game.  I have so far, even when playing alone, and I feel like it was worth every penny even in it's current state.  I look forward to getting to continue playing this game as it is developed.

Early Access Review
								Let me begin with a few basic overview marks.The graphics aren't the best, sure. They're not fallout or dying light quality, but they don't need to be and they're still quite good for what the game is, a unity game. Still a great set of assets and a hell of a lot better than minecraft or unturned but with the same or I'd say even more freedom and crafting options.The sound makes up for the graphics when it comes to atmosphere, seriously, they got some of the sounds down really well, the hair raising clicks of a spider zombie, the growling and barks of the zombie dogs (I Hate these things), the nerve jittering sound of a wondering zombie cop, the music's ehish, not sustained and more just used in short bursts to indicate day/night/horde cycle.Now on gameplay!This is where this baby get's most of it's points. If you're into crafting games and survival, this is the game for you, with everything from hunger and thirst, to body temperature, infections and illness. You have to battle these things as well as the zombie hordes. Detailed and awesome, don't think you can just stand around in the rain and you'll be ok, your temperature will start dropping sharply if oyu're not wearing the right clothing. Clothing, just another aspect of the level of depth, so many layers and tiers, the fact that even guns and power tools are made up of individual working components and such, SO much depth and detail to this game it doesn't even need a story, survive and build is all it needs.A first hour or two Experience in 7 days to die:Have spawned on a road in the desert with some basics, a can of stagg err, I mean cragg? (something) chilli, a jar of water (It says it's a bottle but it's a jar god dammit), a flaming stick (torch), a bandage a backpack and underpants. For some reason I remembered my backpack and flaming torch, but only had time to put on underpants before the apocalypse hit.  Game tells me to make a primitive stone axe. Noted. Need wood. Start punching a tree into submission, eventually it yields beneath my mighty fists and coughs up some wood. I see my next victim, a stone. I charge at it, arms flailing and swinging wildly at bits of grass as I go. WHAP! whap whap whap whap whap, 40 punches later the rock still stands beneath my awesome power and has yielded little. I find a few stones on the ground, enough to combine with the wood and grass punchings to make an axe. I craft the axe, AH HA! I hold it aloft, I have evolved, I am man, I have made a tool. First course of action, charge the mighty rock beast with my newly created tool and beat it into submissions. I hit the rock repeatedly, feeling it crumble to my will offering up it's many goodies until CRACK, it becomes dust beneath my mighty tool! I am man, I am unbeatable! (Low grumbled growling) ZOMBIE! Ha, a moment ago I would have been zombie chow, but I have my trusty stone axe, ready to beat down this zombie. CHAAAARRRGGEE!! whack whack whack, Take that zombie I scream as I wildly hack at it, engaging it from behind. The zombie stops and turns, responding to these attacks unfavourably. OH GOD IT'S EATING ME, IT'S EATING ME OH GOD WHY, WHY DID YOU FAIL ME SO TERRIBLY AXE. I perish in an horrific fashion. My soul rises above me, to watch the zombie chow down only to be zapped and snapped back into the body of another survivor! I can only assume my spirit has possessed him because he TOO is wondering the wilderness with little more than a pair of underpants and a backpack. I start to walk back to my old body to see what has become of it. I trudge forward, barely noticing the dimming light of day until the sun has almost set. Night time approaches! I should find somewhere safe to hole up for the night before I can varily trudge to retrieve my stone axe for sentimentality reasons. A town, that should be a good spot to find some gear and hole up til morning, let's try there. OH GOD, NO, NO, ZOMBIE DOGS, WHY OH WHY THEY'RE SO FAST AND ANGRY OH GOD THEY'RE EATING ME annnnnnd death, floating away watching myself become Zomdog food. Well then, back in my underpants in the middle of nowhere wearing nothing but the baseball cap I found near my spawn point. Ok so, time to make a stone axe....11/10 Still addicted almost 200 hours in.

Early Access Review
								Alright, this might be a little biased, but this review is coming from someone who loves the grind in pve survival games.(Ark pve, subnautica, FTB and tppi minecraft, and w/e else i played throughout the years)Got the game a good while ago, developers HAVE been putting constant updates out, which is more that I can say about other alpha/ea survival games.Each update there are new things to build and find. UI has been reworked too and skills have been added as well as zombie variety.I play on my own server with my friends(4 of us) and we are doing it pure PVE, im hosting it off my PC as I play.Here is how it goes:You start out pretty much naked, punch some grass, gather some stones/wood and start crafting tools to gather more things to craft more advanced tools. If you like survival games(doesn't have to be zombie genre) and more PVE than I would say get it while it's on offer.The pros:-Best looking voxel game out there-Grinding skills and exploring is addictive-Early horde nights are intense(before you get a reinforced concrete super base with spike pitfall traps...)-Zombie dogs, ferals and cops are a threat-It's fun to build stuff and survive with friends over voip-Skill levels and luck matter early on, can make a huge difference on quality of life-EVERYTHING is breakable-There are some community mods for the game that improve QoL-You can adjust your own server settings as you see fitNow onto cons...-Zombies do a bit too much damage to blocks....i get it that they should be able to break through wood and scrap metal, but it's not right for them to break through reinforced concrete with their bare hands with relative ease.-Skills need some work, some are better than others and some really shouldn't be in there, but im sure they will fix them-Map generation needs some work, "random gen" is HUGE, but you can either get a nice city block or a wasteland with multiple biomes next to each other. "Navezgane" is a lot smaller and pre-made but it feels more atmospheric due to the way it was built(street layout, houses, hospitals, survivor camps, factories, prisons.....all feel more real than copypasta randomgen things).-Optimization(or the lack of to some extent). There are some video settings that you should just turn off to get smoother frames. Reflective surface/shadows to OFF, don't max the view distance(huge fps loss), shadows to low/medium as its good enough IMO. Im running 980ti here and im getting ~80-90fps in the city while hosting the server(130+ in empty areas).-Some item balance is poor....even if you specialise in say....blunt weapons(sledge hammer) you will still have to use an axe to break wood and pickaxe to break metal things, it's just more effective. Rifles are a bit too good, compared to every other firearm. -Minibikes are ...rubbish and glitchy.-Some item sounds are horrendously loud when usedIf you do end up buying this and playing privately with your trusted friends then I suggest you set zombies to walk only, up their spawn to "very high" and keep everything else the same. Zombie killing will be enjoyable and not feel frustrating. Grind away!

								OK this is my first review ever so bear with me please :)7D2D is a highly immersive (& addictive), horror themed, sandbox survival game that is set in fully destructible voxel landscape.You are one of a small number of survivors remaining after a virus left most people mindless, savage and hungry hungry (for flesh ) roaming the landscape of Navezgane looking for their next meal.OK, that’s the general gist of the game now for my thoughts!If you like building things, finding loot, fighting monsters, exploring and enjoying yourself then this game will not disappoint!I have had this game since about Alpha 8 and I can’t rave about it enough. It seems they spent more time on their new motion capture zombies that they are so proud of rather then spending time optimizing performance.  This is of course running the game on the lowest settings possible, making the game look like it jumped right out of 2001.  This causes their new HD zombies to stand out even more, since they clash with the low res environment. The lag is unbearable, try as many servers as you might, its all the same deal and everyone has this issue.Its funny because I was playing the game right before a13 dropped.  It was running fine.  Then I try to jump on that same server after the update and it had the framerate of a polaroid camera.  It was unplayable.  Of course I didnt get to enjoy that long as I was now being kicked for ping.  This is of course less then half an hour after I was playing on that same server just fine, no lag, no framerate drops.The best part is the fanbase and official forums.  Having an issue with the game?  Don't bother reporting it.  If it isn't a posted consisting of nothing but praise for the gods that The Fun Pimps, you will be ravenously attacked by the fanboys.   All the resultings posts will insist that their version of the game runs flawlessly and that it must be your fault.  That is if you aren't banned immediately for daring to not get on your knees and pray to the devs.As you can see I actually like this game alot, I have over 300 hours logged.  Its one of, or rather was one of my favorite games.  Now I can't even play it.Save your money.  If after 7 months of waiting for an update they honestly couldn't test this update and see how poorly it ran then they really don't deserve your money.  Even if they delayed the update for another year I would tolerate that so long as I could actually play it.  Instead they kept giving release dates, which they shouldn't have, kept failing to meet said release dates, then rushed out a broken mess.10/10 guys

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								7 days to die survival guide.	Civilization has failed, you are one of very few survivors lost & alone in a desolate world.  Equipped with only your head & hands you must survive in a pocket of habitable land surrounded by blasted rubble & irradiated wastelands.   To make matters worse, the radiation has mutated a common flu bug into a terrifying disease capable of raising the dead.  Can you survive?	First & foremost you must become a scavenger, loot every item you see. Pick up every rock, feather, stick, or scrap of metal you find, every item has a use.  You will need tools, if you happen to spawn close to a road carefully check for vehicles to loot.	There are usually also zombies around cars, don’t let your guard down.   If you are lucky you may find a tool or weapon, regardless you should construct a stone axe.  It may be crude, but it is the best multi-purpose tool at the start.  It can be used to dig holes, chop trees, break boulders and in a pinch can also bash in the head of an attacking zombie.  Once you have a home, it can be used to repair blocks. 	How do you survive the menacing zombie horde?  Running away is always the safest option, but sometimes you have to stand and fight. What would Darryl do?  (WWDD?) Darryl would find a crossbow, or better yet MAKE One. This is where all those sticks & stones you've been picking up are going to come in handy. While you can find feathers in rubbish piles, loot  birds nests, AS they often have eggs, which you can eat - preferably cooked.  All the foods you cook can also be eaten raw, if you don’t mind at bit of food poisoning, which is preferable to starving.  If you have full or high health, and a water supply the food poisoning wont kill you, just make life uncomfortable.  Same thing with Diarrhea from drinking murky water.	In later versions of the game these will impact your "wellness" which most likely will affect things like movement and loot speed, as well as how long it takes to break blocks and zombie skulls.	Now that you have a silent & deadly weapon, and a crude but effective tool, its time to start thinking about the future.  You can stealth to avoid zombies, and gather materials more efficiently with your stone axe.  Boulders can be broken & trees chopped to provide more sticks and stones, this is safer than wandering around gathering, and the zombies don’t seem to be alerted to the sounds.	If you have a decent melee weapon & full stamina, you can chase down a pig & beat it to death.  This will also alert every zombie in the vicinity to your presence, be prepared to run!   Rabbits are easier to kill, one hit with your crossbow will mean instant death if you can get one to stop moving long enough.  Bucks are the best, from a long distance you can often shoot one 3 or 4 times and it won’t even run.	Once you skin the animal, find a place to store the meat, even if you have to place a box on the ground & mark the location, its better than carrying it around attracting all the walkers in the area.  With few small stones and some sticks, and you can cook the meat & make a quick meal.	To move beyond subsistence level you need two items that can be a challenge to obtain, but once you have them your, future is assured. First thing is a short Iron Pipe, which allows you to build a forge, and clay to make molds for it.  Pipes can often be found in stoves & air conditioners,  if you aren't near a building, a blasted ruins may contain a toilet which you can break it to get a pipe.   Clay is found near rivers & lakes, or you can use corn meal!  If you are nowhere near any building, just keep searching. Some zombies may drop a pipe when killed if you can, loot any that you kill.  Follow any road you find, eventually you will find a gas station.	Before it gets dark, you MUST find shelter.  Wandering in the dark will get you killed.  If you happen to have a light source, it will attract them, and at night zombies are far more feral.  Find & fortify a house, or in a pinch dig a hole * crawl inside.  Night time is best used crafting, forging metals & boiling water.  Try not to make too much noise even if hidden indoors at night, as zombies sense your presence.   In fact they will often try to smash their way into your shelter even if you are completely undetected.  Make sure you have an exit for such an eventuality.	It has been my experience that every SEVEN DAYS there is a massive night raid, if you do not have sturdy walls they will get in.  Reinforced concrete walls, metal reinforced wood, or lots & lots of stone between you and any entry point are your only protection on those nights.   Be prepared to conduct extensive repairs once the sun rises.  	What comes next?  Scout the countryside & gather better supplies, having guns & ammo will make your life much simpler, and make your forays into the urban wilderness much less terminal.  The ultimate survival tool can be found if you locate any abandoned military outposts & loot the munitions boxes that they usually contain.  Having a 44 Magnum and a Sniper rifle make the experience even enjoyable!   With a submachine gun, you can decimate the largest feral horde.

								7 Days To Die is certainly a great game. A minecraft like shooter with zombies. What more could someone want? While the game is in alpha stage, it still has a lot to offer. Another thing to keep in mind when looking at this game is the lack of objective. If you are someone who needs a goal, this won't satisfy you very much. Its more of a sandbox as of now. Something else that I consider very important when buying this game is to make sure you have some pals to play it with. You will find yourself bored VERY quickly when playing alone. Also, the online community isnt the greatest, so I would not put your trust into that.TL;DR - The game is pretty good for the money, while it has its flaws, its only in alpha. Before you purchase, make sure you have some friends to play with and watch some gameplay videos.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								As of 12/31/2015:tl;dr - Good more realistic "minecraft" style game. Dev's are active, and the game is still under development and it gets broken periodically. Overall - 6.5/10Long version:Pros: - Very well done apocolypse sim - As of last update, one of the better crafting systems I've seen - Pretty easy to pick up and learn - Graphics are overall pretty good, and improving as development goes on - Dev's are somewhat active in the community, updates are somewhat regular - Motion captured zombies are neat - Minecraft-esque building, but with physics (see other thoughts) - Randomly generated maps - Pretty decent dedicated servers now - Really doesn't need that much PC horsepower to be playable - Weapon selection is broad enough for most to find a good weapon they prefer to useCons: - Minecraft-esque building, but with physics (see other thoughts) - Melee combat is a bit broken - Climate system is currently buggy - Dev's have a nasty habit of half-implementing features (Sorry TFP, but you KNOW you do...) - Frequent server wipes with some updates (see other thoughts) - A lot of new features, not a lot of new content (see other thoughts)Other thoughts:This game has potential to really be fantastic. I've logged over 500 hours playing it since I purchased it shortly after it hit greenlight. I loved it then, I still love it, but I don't play it anywhere near as much these days. The majority of the negativity I feel toward the game is not the game itself, but to some of the way the game has been developed.The minecraft-esque building is really great, except the physics of it can be a bit flaky. There isn't a lot of warning when your house on stilts is going to start collapsing, until  your floor falls apart when you walk on it. I would like to see that fixed somehow, although I don't know what a good way to do that would be. It's a good system, and with the most recent updates, pretty solid.The maps are randomly generated, and have been significantly improved since first introduced. That said, they're still broken too. The caves are cool, but they currently don't always generate properly, or you will see a building which collapses the second you try to walk inside. Overall, still highly playable. What does cause issues though is digging / mining. The terrain does not always recalculate properly, which leads to "outcroppings" that you can't walk past, until you place and remove a block there then it recalculates and is fine.The reason I don't play the game much is the developers, The Fun Pimps. Overall, they are great, and doing a good job with the game as a whole. When you take a closer look at the development however, they've done some things that I found and still find annoying. A major example of this is half implementing features. Now a lot of you may read this and say things like "it's a green light game, what did you expect?" or "you're being too critical, back off" and while to an extent, both are true, but also false. This game is and has been fully playable for quite awhile now, so to me, it's in development in the same sense that Minecraft is still in development, meaning it's a working, playable, functional game, that keeps getting new features and content. What is a bit of a problem with that though, is that in one update, they will "set up" for features in the next. A few very specific examples of this come to mind:- Mini bikes (which are sweet!) - but you cut the player movement speed in half in an update that came out about 3 months before the mini bikes did- Constant screwing with the terrain generation / cave generation / etc - but every time you "fix it" you have to wipe the server, and quite honestly, the routine is getting old, especially when things are still broken with it.- Skill trees (which are interesting) - now you gain experience for doing stuff. Cool feature, very similar to Ark: Survival Evolved in the sense of how XP is earned, but it currently doesn't much beyond improve crafting quality and loot chance at high level. Important, but apparently a "class system" is coming. A prime example of what I am talking about. Wait, do it all, then push it out- Climate / freezing / over-heating - Cool idea, again, works somewhat similar to Ark, but broken. REALLY broken. How am I over-heating when I'm under water, in a lake? It's been acknowledged as broken.- The Rocket Launcher (since fixed) was removed because it didn't work right following a major update...- Tungsten doors were deemed too strong and removed. Took a LONG time for their replacements to show up...- Acknowledging <INSERT FEATURE HERE> is horribly broken and will be fixed - I admit, to an extent I am being hard on TFP here, but I'm also being honest. Between the "we know it's broken and we'll fix it, but hey look at this other new thing!" statements, then after major update releases the game is typically broken to varying degrees, which again, I do understand happens, and with a lot of regularity, but I also feel like if the dev's backed off the throttle on the hype-train a little, and took a bit more time in testing and fixing their releases, the player experience would be even better, especially players who have owned the game for a long time.The server wiping updates are a huge reason I don't play much anymore. I've dealt with the stretches where server wiping was a regular monthly or bi-monthly cycle, and right around the time you got back to where you were prior to the last wipe, "Hey all, new patch. Wipe your servers, loose your stuff again. Sorry!" then rinse, wash, and repeat, when in reality, I am pretty sure they could iterate through the chunks and regenerate them with a secondary utility, so that server wiping wasn't mandatory, or minimally, give admins a way to preserve player inventory, skills (as of now), etc. because for me, right now, I'm done dealing with it.A lot of the new features which have been added are cool, once they're polished up. The mini bike, the skill system, the new resource collection, zombie stun, UI revamp, have all been overall positive additions, or minimally, look promising. New content however, has been nil for quite awhile. Yes, they've added better graphics, which do look good, they've improved the weather system, finally added some weapons, etc. But the end game is still basically same as it was a year ago. It just takes longer than it did.I understand gating a lot of the crafting, and making things take longer (gasoline and forges are prime examples), but once you build a solid base with enough of a defense (admittedly, the defense requirements have gotten significantly higher), a garden for food, and a forge to make ammo, that's it. You've done everything you need to, now you can go mess with zombies or other players. Now again, you may say "it's a green light game" or "it's still in development" and again, I get it, and to that I say "Fair enough, except they aren't developing new content." The overall end game hasn't changed much since Alpha 10, except for the amount of time it takes to get to that point, which to a lesser extent, I agree with because there was a point where once you had a beaker, an auger, and corn, you could have a fully established base in about 4 real world hours if you knew what you were doing.All of that said, and yes, I know how harsh I was, I still support the game and I do still overall recommend the game. Personally though, I am done until it's done, or minimally, not broken.

Early Access Review
								This game is so cool! I'm not worthy! I'm not worthy!No seriously, this game is excellent. For being an alpha game still under heavy development, it is fun. Several friends and I have made a few multiplayer servers to play on for days to weeks at a time. The developers are very active in the community with the players. While they do have a planned agenda, they do accept ideas from the players or suggestions and incorporate them into the game. This game will also be open for players to mod. While the graphics aren't the best I've ever seen, they aren't too shabby and they are friendly to low-end PC's. There are still a lot of bugs to be fixed. The content at the moment is a little limited in terms of building materials and the different types of buildings/structures that you encounter. However, they are consistently adding new content. I expect the finished product game to be nothing like the alpha I started playing a few months ago (for better or worse).Gameplay is survival horror rpg. You start with nothing and build your way up to having consistent food, water, weapons, and shelter. Alternatively, you could be a nomad and live off of the buildings and structures you encounter on your journey. Either way, beware of the 7 day night horde. Health, stamina, hunger, thirst, and general wellness are all taken into account while playing. Negative things such as becoming infected by a zombie, broken legs, dysentery, and bleeding out are all things that you will have to deal with during your travels. The zombies in this game are a force to be reckoned with. During the day, they are slow and can be dealt with individually if one is careful. If one becomes alert to your presence, many in the area will soon come to investigate. Fighting one zombie can easily turn into running away from fifteen. When the sun sets, the game becomes a whole new animal. Since the zombies run full speed at night, things can be absolutely terrifying. The sheer suspense of hearing the zombies search for you at night can be unnerving. Or the times where you are looting a house and you accidentally slam the cabinet doors in the kitchen only to realize that they heard you and they are coming.Did you ever wish that a game like Minecraft had formidable enemies that would smell you, hear you, and hunt you?Enemies that will dismantle your base and annihilate you if you didn't take proper precautions to protect yourself? That is this game.

Lets do this in parts, its such a mental mess i will have to make an effort to keep focus. I used to like this game very much, yeah you read right, about over a year ago the game was good and kinda fun . I was ignorant and everything was promissing . Then, some day, they somehow managed to ruin what made the game "fun" and turned it into a massive pointless grind. It was such a pointless grind before, but lets say the grind was optional and was about working your♥♥♥♥♥to build. Now its becoming a refilling gauges simulator. Its basically some mechanic they brough up from their arses to make the game artificially harder and "longer". The concept is simple. You start with half the HP and stamina a normal person would have and you have to gain your way to "being a healthy  person". Abusing game mechanics will increase it quickly, making it pointless once you abuse them enough, Dying will decrease it. Early Access Review
								As previously stated by many others, this game has tremendous potential, but it's also greatly lacking in content with correlations to its price. The concepts are somewhat new, and this is what makes it enjoyable, but because of the lack of content, the joy rapidly diminishes in the first few hours. The game is too pricy at this point in developement. I believe the price should be around 15$. Here are a few specific reasons why:1. There is only one map, and although its quite big, most of it is just terrain rather than interactive.(unless you consider dirt and trees interactive)2. Not enough crafting. There are an awesome amount of weapons, but the traps, tools and building blocks are lacking in variety. The game features farming, but there are only 3 different plants.3. Bugs and glitches. Sometimes creatures are stil spawning in thoroughly lit areas. When mining, the blocks sometimes fly out, or fall into space occupied by another block, meaning it cannot be accessed directly without removing the other block. When looking for multiplayer servers, it does not correctly display the current number of players in the server.4. Spawn trapping. When you dont have any weapons or beds,  and you die during the night, it is almost impossible to do anything without waiting till daytime. The zombies run at you and deal relatively massive amounts of damage, and they also spawn in waves.5. Lack of instructorial information. The interface is initally difficult to decipher, and the lack of any tips reduces our learning to nothing more than just clicking a button and waiting to see if it does anything.

Early Access Review
								This game and the developers seem to be moving in the right direction.The development news and update posts here on Steam have been lacking but on the Official forums the developers have been very active.  It is alpha, and there are bugs, and a lot of features not yet implemented.  Plus as should be expected for an alpha, balance is always being re-evaluated.  Of course I don't expect real balancing until all the features are implemented and much more debugged.That said, the game has been fun so far.  I think a lot of people forget that it is an Alpha because the game does play relatively well and has a reasonable feature set already.  That may be part of the inclination to complain about the balance as they've forgotten as enjoyable as it is to play, it is also still very much in a stage where a lot of testing is required and the balance just should not be expected at this point when most mechanics are not in, anything now should be considered place-holder balance at best.  Also, modding has finally been given the OK with the expected 'not yet officially supported' and 'modders should expect mods to break with new releases and changes which may even make them redundant or impossible to recreate'.  Nothing new for a product in Alpha but given the prior confusion as to if modding was allowed (there was even a chill on modding discussion before) this is a great change.They have even adding a Modding forum on the Official forums:http://7daystodie.com/forums/forum.phpThe future is looking brighter for this zombie apocalypse.The game itself is an absolute blast.  Tweaked to just how you want to play with the options they've given so far.  Nothing like using a crossbow to shoot bolts to draw zombies away from a building you want to loot instead of trying to kill all the zombies in Gravestown.  Make the whole feel of the game more alive and realistic.  So much fun and it keep getting better with every release.The Random World Generation is some of the best I've seen with towns actually linking together across multiple biomes.  The latest version added paths from roads to even the side Points of Interest (example a gravel road leading to the out of the way camp site).Game just keeps getting better and better.  I can't wait for each update.

Early Access Review
								For some reason, many of the negative reviews seem to have been voted most helpful, but if you look at the gameplay hours on the negatives compared to the hours people have on the positive reviews, it's clear that this game has a very loyal, dedicated fanbase, and oodles of replay value.In a crowded field of zombie survival games, or just plain survival games, this one stands out for several reasons. First off is the fact that the enemies pose so much of a threat, that it really encourages cooperation. This game is a must to play with friends. There's something really satisfying about building up your defenses, setting up traps, and then fighting together to survive the night. It's something that Minecraft hints at, and Fortnite promises (if it ever gets released), but this game delivers.The PvP features are a bit lacking and, being an early access alpha title, there are quite a few missing features, bugs, glitches, and security issues. Cheats and hacks are still a problem on public servers. However, as a co-op base building / tower defense / horde survival type game, this one is tough to beat.7 Days to Die is a genuinely fun game, blending the crafting, building, and destructibility aspects of Minecraft with the over-the-top frenzied action of Serious Sam or Dungeon Defenders, where the enemies come at you in almost overwhelming numbers. It's already a blast to play, and continues to get better and better with each new patch. If this is what they've managed to come up with for an alpha release, I can't wait to find out what the finished product will look like.Don't let the haters fool you, look at how much time the positive reviewers have put into this game. Pick it up, make friends, play it with them, and go nuts building and killing zombies! You won't regret it.

Early Access Review
								I've been hooked on this game for weeks now. Here's the elevator speech:Is it a Day Z clone?  Yeah, sure.  It's what Day Z could have been if it wasn't abandonwear.  The developers are very active and release updates constantly.  Is it a Minecraft clone?  Sure, you could say that too.  It takes some of the best features of Minecraft and implements them well.  Yes, as others have said, it is a Day Z meets Minecraft love child, in all the right ways.  The crafting system is deep, tons of loot and a vast variety of it.  Lots and lots of building options as well.Now to address some of the ugly stuff a few negative reviewers have said.  Yes, the game is rough around the edges.  It is and ALPHA.  Sometimes things will happen, for better or worse, due to error.  Sometimes it's tragic, sometimes it works to your advantage, sometimes it's just hilarious, but when you play this game, you need to know you're playing an alpha.  Yes, some of the textures are ugly.  Yes, there are balance issues.  Yes, some features are less than reliable.  That all being said, this is the best alpha I've ever played, and it is always getting better.It is also true that there is a learning curve.  Just like any game with deep crafting, building, etc... because there is a lot you CAN do, there are a lot of things to know.  Most of it is pretty intuitive, but you will find yourself reading forums and the wiki alot.  It's just that kind of game.I've been reading about rude moderators in the forums.  I don't know much about that, I jump in to find an answer to a question I have and jump right back out.  That may or may not be true, but at the end of the day, it doesn't make the game any less fun.BOTTOM LINE:  If you like open world survival/crafting games, this is the best one of the lot, and I've played them all.  Better than RUST, better than DAY Z.  WAY better than all the other abandonwear and halfassed rip offs in this genre that polute the Steam store.  Is this a clone?  Yeah, it is.  But it's one of those rare clones that's better than it's own inspiration.

Posted: August 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Day 21 AftermathCome nightfall, I lasted for less than an hour before the zombies got me.  They clustered on the north wall until they broke through, climbing over each other's corpses.  At least I could see them better this time with the torches I'd placed.  I picked off some with arrows, but I should've used my meager supply of bullets.  In the end they surrounded me from the inner staircase and the 2nd floor balcony.  They chewed through the wall, the doors, and even halfway into the foundation, though the building's still structurally sound.Goals for next week: forge a pickaxe and start an escape tunnel from my base to the natural cavern I found earlier.  Mine for iron in the process.  Add another layer of spikes around the base and repair/strengthen the walls.  Stretch goal: start a garden with the corn & potatoes I've scavenged.***Here's the thing.  The zombies are coming in 7 days, and every week they get stronger.  So while there's a big world to explore and it may seem downright tranquil now, you'd better be one focused taskmasker if you're going to be prepared in time.You'll go back and forth between nomadic and sedentary life.  You'll start out punching grass, and charring that pig you clubbed to death over a campfire (if you don't have to devour it raw that is).  You'll progress, hopefully, until you're sitting pretty in your reinforced bunker, dining on bear stew and blueberry pie.You'll likely always be desperate for something, be it clean water, medicine, building material, metals, or that one part you need to make a gun.  Missing any one of these for long can be fatal, because everything connects with everything else.  The crafting is intuitive, and makes good use of the materials available.  For instance, when you kill an animal, you can get meat, fat, bone, and hide.  Each of these is useful for something very different, and while you may have an excess of some stuff, you'll be wise to never throw things away if you have the space.The game is forgiving enough without being too forgiving.  By default, when you die you can respawn on or near your bed, and all your stuff is in your backpack where you died.  However, once in a while my backpack disappears and I lose some of my best stuff (bug?).  In multiplayer you'll have to defend yourself from other survivors, who are craftier at getting to you and your stuff.  But land claim blocks and locks are meant to alleviate this.  I've only played single player and with friends, so I can't say how good or bad PvP may be.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've played quite a few zombie survival games and even non-zombie survival games, and the one game that rises above them all, alpha stage or not, is 7 Days to Die.  While it does, at times, get a tad on the boring side still traversing the map looking for points of interest and taking several in game hours to find them, and while it does get a tad monotonous finding the same 2-4 houses time and time again, everything else pretty much falls into place.Don't get me wrong, every alpha game has it's glitches and bugs, and that's why it's alpha, but you don't see 7 Days to Die "starting over" like some other games out there *cough rust cough*, or being only playable enough to craft about 5 things and that's it.  There are only two alpha games I have ever bought where I did not regret it, and that is this one, and Factorio. (check it out via google. It's not on Steam.)  Now on to specifics.First, environment. More specifically, audio. For me, I always choose to play with music off, so I can't comment on any music, however I do remember the 7 Days to Die menu theme to be prety catchy. I will say that this is the ONLY game I have ever played where I have literally jumped or felt actual fear when playing. Some people have felt that while playing F.E.A.R., Slenderman, or other games, but I really didn't. This one however, when I am looting a house, and I hear snarling, drooling, barking, vomiting, groaing, screaming, breaking wood, breaking glass, breaking concrete, and metal being hit, all at the same time, and I can turn around and not tell where all the sounds are coming from, it gets pretty scary.  And let me tell you, when you can't get inside somewhere safe at night and those zombies and dogs are running at you and you can barely see, that, my friend, is pretty darn terrifying. I don't get scared by much, The Fun Pimps do a good elicting the fear emotion out of me when playing this game.I do love the "AHA" moments of the random generaed maps now as well when I DO discover new things. Like the first time I discovered twin factories, I stood in amazement and thought of all the wonderful things to do with it. I tried making a base out of it but discovered it was much too large to defend alone, but it sure was fun trying.  Or the first time I discovered a non-center city on the map, or got my final magnum part. Those were pretty cool moments for me.  Sure, one could turn on creative mode and just give yourself those things, but that takes the fun out of it when you are working together with 4-5 other people and you are the first on your server to craft a magnum, or to find a factory, or something like that. Those moments happen for everyone.  The zombie pathing and A.I. is a bit glitchy, but they are fixing that soon in 9.2, so I won't talk much about that, but it is annoying.  There are little weird things like destroying cement ramps outside of a parking garage and getting wood planks as a result, or being able to plant trees on roads. Nothing major, but still there.Graphically, this game is amazing. I only started playing about 2 days before 9.0, so I never saw the game personally when it was more cubed, but what I saw in videos, the smoothing of the world is a big step up. I never knew this was a voxel game until I read it. Playstyle is great, I wouldn't change a thing, Crafting is also great. There are so many things you can make, but I do feel there should be a few more things, such as the medicine cabinet, wall safe, and wall lights. I think those should be craftable. Maybe they will be in a future patch, I don't know.I don't know much more to say, other than all I really see are improvements from the makers, and they continue to do so. I haven't seen anything about adding fishing to the game, so I hope that is a plan at some point. Maybe it was a future stretch goal that didn't get met.UPDATED REVIEW: Alpha 13.8: I STILL highly recommend this game. It keeps getting better and better. Sure there are new bugs and still some old ones, but the developer team is small so they can only do so much. And it's still Alpha, so you are basically testing the game while playing.The new UI and Crafting system is great in my opinion. I see a lot of people with 1000+ hours say they hate A13, that it ruined the game and would no longer recommend it, but I am of the opposite. A13, IMO, made the game better. And A14 is around the corner and is going to have perks, an introductory quest, and much needed fixes and optimizations. You CANNOT go wrong buying this game, and as of this edit, it is HALF OFF!

You basically use the daytime hours to scrounge, explore, pursue your goals, and find safe haven (while the zombies are slower and less numerous) and use the night hours (when you'll need stealth and luck to survive for even a minute outside) fortifying your position, crafting what you've scavenged into things you need, and monitoring your defenses from the tireless predations of the dead. Complex crafting system that allows you to dismantle/reverse-engineer or build nearly anything you can find in the game. ALL TERRAIN completely deformable, by you, friends/foes, and the undead. I've played NUMEROUS campaigns and they have all ended in one of two ways -- crushed under the unrelenting hordes, or completely organically and spontaneously finding and making an awesome enclave that grew out of the circumstances I happened upon. Crafting, Fighting, Forging, Farming, Terraforming -- it's all there and it's all fun. AND THE GAME IS ONLY IN ALPHA! More content added all the time, (as of this date 3/2/14)

								Alpha Build Review as of November 2016: It's still awesome.7D has a ton of content especially for an alpha. Compare it to other alphas like back when Minecraft was in alpha, and the quality is also notable. Few crashes in my 100 hours of play, biggest technical issue I have is a greatly variable framerate, on a GTX 970 still dipping to 20fps at times.Overall, people might say it's a Minecraft/DayZ... and it pretty much is, but in the good way. A challenge to scavenge, a variety of changing, persistent PVE as time goes on, and a fairly hefty crafting system that mimics Minecraft's simplicity-crafting-grid type scenario. The voxel system is a neat physics addition compared to most builders, I'd say this plays as a more realistic, harder Minecraft, but with a wide variety of game settings to tailor to your playstyles, a great addition.If you like the builder-survival-crafting type games, I'd say this is one of the best at the moment, with a real reason to team up, especially on a public server, and not a total PVP deathmatch-with-zombies like DayZ or H1Z1. Can't say it's the most amazing of course, but I definitely enjoy my time with it and will hope they keep fleshing out the bugs and PVE side of things.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was iffy about buying this game because the last early-access software I bought failed to deliver.  This game, however, is definitely proving worth the cost.  It's only in Alpha 9.3 as of this writing, but it's already better quality than many "finished" games I've seen.I think the best way to describe the feel of this game is to walk you through a brief chapter of my most recent game.  I found a building made out of stone, and decided that it would be a good place to try to fortify.  An overhang on the second floor blocked line-of-sight to the front of the door for anyone standing on top of the house.  I knew that was a major weakness; once the zombies get to the door, I would have no way of killing them without losing my last line of defence.  I decide to try to use the cinderblocks that are lying all around to construct another wall around the house, built in such a way that I can shoot down on the zombies trying to break through it.  Less than an eighth of the way through building my wall, I look up and can't even see the end of the line of zombies coming at me.My weapons are limited.  I have a crossbow, but it reloads so slowly that I'll only be able to take down three or so zombies before they get to me.  My sledgehammer can kill a zombie with one well-placed strike, but going into melee range with a horde that side would be suicide.  I've got about 100 rounds for a handgun, it's my only choice.  Taking careful aim to ensure headshots, I take down a half-dozen zombies.  More and more keep coming; I retreat up to the balcony.  I know that once the zombies get under the balcony, I won't be able to stop them from reaching me on the porch, but I reinforced the door, so I should be safe for a minute or two.  I try to pick off as many zombies as I can before they can hide under the balcony.  Once the end of the horde arrived, I knew that about ten have made it to the door.  I go downstairs to see how the door's holding up.  Luckily for me, the zombies aren't organized.  Some are trying to break down the windows, some are going for the door.  None of them have gotten a full breach yet.  I return to the balcony, trying to see if I can take down a few more before the wall is breached.  Some of the zombies notice me up top, and try to destroy a support column for the balcony.    This leaves them in a vulerable position, I take a few more down.  I hear breaking glass.  Trying to line up another shot, I fall off of the balcony.  There's still six zombies left, and they're all headed straight for me.  I open fire on them while backpedaling, hoping that there aren't more undead behind me.With the carnage over, I repair the ground floor.  Night is coming soon, and I won't be able to finish the perimeter walls before sunset.  Time to see if I can cobble together the last part I need to build a shotgun.  If a horde visits me tonight, that Beretta won't save me.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is a great, great game I would HIGHLY reccomend, even at it's original alpha price of 35$ Now that it's 25$ if you like the concept of Dayz minecraft just make the jump and get it, you won't be dissapointed.   I have bought Dayz, Rust and this, and while I like them all Dayz has been uninstalled. I like playing Rust a lot right now, but creatively I think this game takes the cake. I have always been entranced with the survival genre, and multiplayer games, especially games that encourage players to collaborate creatively. Rust is a more of a post apocolyptic survival game. Rust isn't a kos nightmare frenzy like Dayz is because you do get the ability to stash things and create bases, but as of right now pvp is the more mid-game/end-game goal as everything else becomes fairly easy once you get to know the mechanics. Rust (like Alpha Dayz) relys on the pvp to define the gaming exerience, and it basically turns into a fps where you want to loot cool pvp gear from other people. Just like Dayz. (Not bashing on it I am loving it right now.)  7 Days to Die however is a different creation and an entirely unique game. It is truly a zombie survival sandbox, that can be enjoyed greatly without even going online. The Zombie AI is great, even in its Alpha phase. Even slow walking zombies have a way of creeping up on you without you knowing until the last second, or filling into a house blocking the exits as you are checking food cabinets, forcing you to jump through a window.  I think the coolest thing about the game is that it is not just one game. You truly create the experience that you want to play. The Default (as you have probably heard) is that during daytime there are slow walking zombies, and at nighttime they turn into fast zombies. Extremely fast frenzied zombies that only slow down in the prescence of enough light (campfires, torches, ect.) The zombies will claw through any material to get to you. How long it takes for them to claw through a material depends on how durable that material is (stone is stronger than wood, which is clearly stronger than dirt.) A mudhut would be taken down in seconds at night time. Just being outside at nighttime in default is terrifying, encouraging a kind of forage and basebuilding during daytime, and fortifying and repairing your base at night time. You can change pages of settings, and even more in depth settings not in the actual game to craft the game that you want, choosing how many zombies spawn, if they are always walkers, or always runners, how much damage they do, or you do and many, many more options. I never really could get into minecraft because while I loved the concept, I felt no immersion. I felt that the game focused more on the creativity, than the survival immersion, but not only am I not good drawing or art, let alone 3D art, but the 3D art that I could create was in my opinion not terribly interesting, or at least not pleasing to look at. This game is all about immersion, and the graphics are incalcuably better than minecraft (and constantly getting better.) Still the physics are solid and sound, and to me incredible. Every piece of the game world is some sort of resource that you can mine and collect. Every inch of dirt is diggable and obtainable. Every stone that you see can be picked up and crafted into stone "blocks" (They are starting to replace classic minecraft blocks with "smooth terrain" something that ironically in the present state I find less smooth and easy to work with than the original block style, but I am sure that will be refined and corrected.) The reward of simply surviving is one very satisfying, yet incredibly hard goal, but really the sky is the limit. Jump on a friendly server and I am constantly shocked by the imagination these people have. They will have turned a warehouse into a castle surrounded by landmines and trenches with spikes on the bottom of them. Go into the castle and it is just a decoy, and ladders plummet deep, deep down into the earth where there is an entire underground world, with many rooms, undergound rivers, mines, bedrooms, lounges and tunnels. Above ground there are towers that lead to large gardens growing many different vegetables and fruit. There is a sandbox "God" or "Cheat" mode where you can spawn any item or resource that you want at any time allowing you to create anything you can dream up.  My first online experience was on a new server when the game had just came out, and a bunch of us found a huge town where we intended to stay together. We did the first night and ended up blowing a staircase away as zombies flooded into the house, shooting them as they tried to jump up the destroyed staircase. We somehow survived and looted the town the next day, but I got seperated and nighttime fell before I could find them and I was trapped in a small shack with one other person and no good defensive resources. Needless to say we were destroyed. My next online game we were in the ruins of a town full of large half destroyed buildings, many floors high, but basically trapped with hordes of zombies below us. I could go on forever but I will end this with saying if you are on the fence look at the patch notes. Out of all of the Alphas, these developers seem to be the most dedicated and hardworking developers intent on providing us with amazing gameplay rather than just trying to let the community make our own gameplay. Every month a miriad of changed occur making the systems more complex and in depth and adding new systems. The map gets larger and larger, even though eventually they will let us create our own maps and create random map generators. The graphics got a huge overhaul in the last build. In the last build we have got a working stealth and cooking system, as well as the beginning of an armor system. These developers are dedicated to making a truly great game with great AI, and it really is refreshing. It is to me a really good example of how gameplay is more important than graphics, something that tends to be forgotten in this day and age. And the graphics aren't bad.

Early Access Review
								A year ago, I would have recommended this game highly. I spent hours and hours building bases, crafting weapons, surviving hordes, and the ambiance of the game was so well crafted I found myself having nightmares about getting overrun by zombies.But Alpha 13 was a bad start and Alpha 14 has just made the game downright unplayable. I think they've focused so much on securing deals with Telltale, they've lost focus on delivering a quality experience to their original gamers.Here are my complaints:1) the weather system is ridiculously illogical - I've been in heatstroke during a snowstorm. As a player, you will spend nearly all your time just searching for water and drinking red tea. This is not hyperbole - in a 24 hour day, I spend about 16 hours just trying to keep myself hydrated.2) while the graphics have improved dramatically, the bugs they've introduced are horrible. Zombies randomly clip through walls. Hornets spawn an endless stream of zombies so hordes several days.3) it's become a grinding-based game just trying to accumulate enough materials to build and maintain a base. Exploration isn't all that possible now unless you play the game fully-nomadic, in which case, you desperately need a minibike and loads of gas so you can simply outrun the bugged hordes.4) quests and skills weren't thought out well. They're there just to be there, not because they add any value to the game experience.5) on any difficulty above Scavenger, due to the spawning bugs, the game becomes impossible to survive as the weapon balancing has been readjusted so your guns are virtually useless vs. the literal hundreds of zombies that will come your way.I really, really wish they'd focus less on the aesthetics and understand that gameplay is more than appearance.

Posted: May 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								From my first try I was hooked on 7 Days to Die.  I missed the Kickstarter for this game, unfortunately, picking it up on the advice of a trusted Youtube Letsplayer at the stage of Alpha 1, and thought, wow this is for me.    From its very early stage of development this game was fully and excitingly playable, and somehow you could tell it had legs.  This game was exciting, realistic, fully working with my PC spec. and totally absorbing.  Blocky graphics didnt matter;  I loved the  way everything but everything is destructable and craftable.  Many have said this is DayZ meets Minecraft, and that is true in all the good ways.  Building your own base, finding ways to keep hordes out, farming your own crops and killing your food after the post apocalypse world is looted out was a challenge, taxing and deeply satisfying.  Its not enough to dig a hole in the dirt and wait for sunrise; Zombies in this game are worthy opponents.  You will NOT survive if you are out at night, or if your base is weak - these undead are fast, scary, loud and deadly.  Running away is not an option. Then as the long awaited Alpha 2 came out... everything got better and some things got even harder to survive.  Then further updates, more challenges, better graphics, sophisticated crafting tools, this is the gift of a game that keeps on giving.  Just as you thought you had it sussed, new zombie types were introduced, tougher landscapes, zombies that could smell you, hear you, sense you, hunt you.  But its not all in their favour, we now have stealth, smooth terrain, craftable guns, repairable weapons, it just keeps on getting better with each update, and slight (non gamebreaking) bugs are fixed every week and released every friday, so that for a YouTuber like me                                    (  https://www.youtube.com/my_videos?o=U  ) its hard to keep up with the stuff the Fun Pimps roll out.Practically every aspect of the game is adaptable to your level and your enjoyment.  You can play on their default settings or you can make it harder if you like Hard Core, or easier if you want to relax and choose less stress.  Want more loot? fine.  What fewer zombies? fine,  longer days and shorter nights? choose your ratio.  Want Airdrops of supplies? you got it.  Tailor the game just how you like it.  Singleplayer is great, Multiplayer is there if you want company, PvE or PvP, all are available.  The smooth terrain now makes it less like Minecraft or DayZ -  those days of that comparison are over.I believe that any Survivalist (the name we give ourselves in this game) will tell you there have been times when all of us have said "Darn, thats a bug, but hey - its Alpha, right?"   None of the minor problems along the way to Alpha 8.3 (at time of writing this review) have made the game unplayable,  7 Days to Die in Alpha is better than most games on full and final release, better than I could possibly have expected and worth much more than I paid for it. I fully recommend this game at whatever stage you come on board.  More bang for your buck - definitely.

Early Access Review
								I was truthfully a little sceptical about the asking price for this game, but this game is excellent! I play co-op with my brother on a private server, and we play for hours on end!Pros:* It doesn't feel like Early-access. The game feels largely complete, but there could be improvements* Crafting and gathering is a very fun aspect, and also important to survival* Death isn't just a number, there's a lot to lose from dying, which encourages safer play: something that makes the game more realistic, and more enjoyable* Zombies are a real threat at night-time, and seem to just sneak up on you. There is very little vision (you can obtain forches etc), but I like that this encourages me to stay indoors and safe* Levelling up earns skill points to increase various things* Fun co-operative playCons:* The AI seems a little sloppy* The graphics and animations feel like early 2000's. While better animations and models would be nice, the game is fine as-is* Currently you can't craft everything you see in the game, which is a little frustrating* The game lacks any kind of tutorial, so your first few hours will be largely confusing. This can be offset by just reading a Steam guideI know there appear to be as many cons as there are pros, but the cons are all negligible. Even for the asking price of $25, this game is truly worth it if you're into zombie survival games

Early Access Review
								So. 7 Days to Die. This review is based off of the latest build (infinite world gen)This game started off well, a good first alpha build that showed off the features of the game, but lacked content with a limited map and lacking item explations and crafting options.In this latest build, the game now has an infinitely generated world (which I must say is very well done). After an hour exploring i found a mix of biomes from bombed out, desolated cities (including convincing bomb craters, ruined and intact buildings, ect.)  Goergous forests, stark deserts, lakes flush with wildlife, and frozen hilly forests. One could spend hours just looking for all the nifty features the terrain generator can create, and so far, I have found no real broken generator features.The new crafting menu is vastly improved, eliminating a lot of the guesswork required while still requiring a challenge to find and assemble crafting components for rare recipies. Unlike older versions, the recipe shows all materials needed in the grid, but you need to know what the materials are, and find them before you can build the recipe. The UI overhaul adds modular sets for different crafting recipes, eliminating the one huge recipe list, and also adds color-cordinated backlighting to different items, displaying what catagory of item they are. It also fixed the OCD aggravating clipping between the status bars and hotbar (Thank god).The build still has some problems, sound for one is a huge issue. Zombies are unreasonabley loud at crazy distances, making scavenging overly panic inducing, and often causing injury or death because you can't tell how far away an enemy is. Footsteps and impact sounds also feel too roughshod, and could use an overhaul.Overall, I quite love the game, and i'll probably play around with this build a lot more. Until then, good luck surviving everyone :3 (also. Dysentery. 10/10)

Early Access Review
								First off I would like to say this is a great game, and hope someday in the future when it is completed this game gets ported to the consoles. There is no game that I know of that has crafting, survival, zombies, multiplayer of this caliber. This game is gorgeous. From the moment the sun sets in game, to the moment the sun rises the game is awesome.When I first tried the game, I was very skeptic, I was like great another zombie shooter game, boy was I wrong. The amount of depth the game has at this early stage is pretty impressive. The Developers are always actively keeping us up-to-date on their progress and constantly showing pics of improvements coming to the game on their blog.I'm currently playing on a public pvp server alpha 9.3. When you first go into the game, it is extremely overwhelming as the learning curve is steep. There is no tutorials so you basically would have to ask people online, or look at some YouTube, wiki, and do some trial and error to learn some of the games mechanics. First person shooter players will feel right at home here, as the controls are basic.When you start your first game, you start out at virtually very little items. You quickly learn that zombies are all around you and you have a limited food supply. You quickly scrounge around in cars, trash bins for food and must collect items to craft basic items to help you with your survival.The crafting menu is straight forward you start out with know recipes such as a stone axe. Crafting an items is simply as just clicking on what you want to craft from the list, drag the components to the grid and click craft. After a short time the item is crafted. As you progress in the game you will find more new books that unlock new recipes. You can create forges that smelt your mining ores such as iron, and you can create a campfire to cook eggs, and raw deer meat (yes you can kill bambi!). Sleeping bags and beds crafted are used to save home locations so when you die you can respawn at them. You can farm food to grow, such as potatoes or coffee beans.The map is huge, plenty of room to roam around and explore or go underground and create secret underground bases by digging. Zombies are slow at day and fast at night, there cute and cuddly but enough to easily overwhelm any player base not properly prepared. You will die a lot in this game, from starvation, diseases and other craziness in the game.So if you’re an explorer or builder type, this game has plenty at its development stage to keep you busy. I recommend playing with friends to enjoy the many "oh♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; moments you’re going to have trying to survive against hordes of zombies.What also makes this game unique is the importance of certain blocks in the game that form the many structures in the game such as buildings and farm houses. For example cement blocks have both a structural integrity that can withstand a lot of damage and has a threshold on the amount of blocks it can hold when used for building. Exceeding these capacities when building and not placing the proper foundation to support buildings can cause the whole building to collapse, pretty impressive from an engineering perspective. You can fortify buildings and upgrade doors windows etc., to withstand more damage.There are many things planned for the game, such as in game vehicles, npc's, and story etc. This game is a good mixture of everything we love in mine craft, left for dead, and fallout games.It is a great game and I highly recommend!

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								7 days to die. WOW. Where do I begin? The game offers so many options in such an early stage, it almost feels complete! However, it is not. Since this is an Early Access review, it will be wrote as such.TL;DR at the bottomGameplay7 Days To Die, in my opinion, is a good cross between what DayZ could have been, with Minecrafts building mechanics and crafting, overhauled. From time to time, the controls can be a bit clunky, swaying around in a direction you hadn't intended. Mocap hasn't been integrated yet so walking, running, and other physical motions are dry.  It is however, very polished, and does not interfere with playability. The game itself handles fine on any well equipped PC.UI & VisualsOptions don't boast too many options in terms of video settings just yet, but offer enough to allow you to tune it to run either performance or quality. It isn't recommended to run it in ultra high settings (unless you can handle it of course), but at a mid point to save yourself from the lag in clustered POI's like cities, neighborhoods, and possible player built settlements.The best part visual wise out of the whole thing is that the entire world is smooth. Everything looks natural and polished, and breaks and modifys just like any other voxel game. It is a learning curve to get used to it if you're just coming in from Minecraft, cause the angles of the ground, cliffs, rocks, etc can be offset looking sometimes, but it looks great and plays fine. The worlds themselves keep getting better and better looking with each update. As of Alpha 10.4, this game already looks wonderful. With the right tweaks, its is a place full of wildlife, and the undead.The UI is nice. It has changed a few times in the course of Alpha 7 through 10, but overall is sleek and very efficient, showing you just your essential meters, belt, and compass. The Day and time count are small enough to be out of the way, and still legible. Nothing sticks out in a manner that would block peripherals, so you get full view of whats in front and next to you.MechanicsThe mechanics to the game in general are fantastic. The crafting is what keeps me coming back time and time again. There are literally hundreds of recipes to choose from, and if that's not enough, you can make your own recipes out of items you couldn't normally craft! The community is good at coming up with unique ways to make the not so useful items useful again, and adding the recipes are as easy and copy and paste.There are some glitches and errors that can be frustrating when crafting. At times, the forge will "eat" your materials, so that 534lb of Iron? yeah, it's gone. The same thing happens with the campfire. There have also been times the zombies warp through the walls, and hordes end up inside our fortified prefab house. this doesn't seem to happen with player built bases.Structural integrity is the game changer. There will be no more building massive structures in 15 minutes. You actually have to think about placement. One wrong move, and half, or even all of your building will collapse. It creates ways to make traps, and take down players bases. It's really cool to watch the bricks rain down! It would be nice to see them fall over in a more realistic motion, but that will come in due time.Zombies are pretty terrifying when setup to spawn in large groups. I play the role of a bandit, so my first habit is to try and set up in the wasteland. What might be done quickly in the plains or forest is damn near impossible to do in the wasteland biome. I remember the days of sitting inside the corner of a small 6x8 shack, listening to the hordes whisper and screech in the night as they run by chasing the animals. The fear was real at that point. SoundThe sounds at first can be frightening, which is a good thing. You get that pump of adernaline when hearing the scream of a Spider zombie or a Zombie Cop bubbling up puke. But after a while the sounds become recycled. You might even notice some sounds from other games used. However, Snow zombies will never get old. That sound will haunt you in your sleep.Overall, I rate this game, in its current state, a good 7.5/10. The bugs need to be fixed, cause some of them can cause frustrated players to just quit, and it diminishes the replay value. Pathing is still another thing to consider, but it just tests your FPS skills for the time being :) With my overall hours, I highly recommend this game. With future workshop support, Mods, and a great community follow up, this is one game that is sure to remembered by all Z fans for a long time.TL;DRPros+Good pace of zombie action+dozens of different block styles to design your base with+Lots of loot to find+100's of recipes to craft+Creepy atmosphere (Crying wasteland babies)+Future Workshop and Mod support+Devs are friendly, engaging, and listen to the communityCons-Hackers on mainstream open servers-Random little glitches -Zombies run through prefabs from time to time-unoptimized for low end PC's-Pathfinding on Zombies and Zombie Dogs is poor-Physics are poorOverall: 7.5/10

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
Early Access Review
								Just because you are unique, does not mean you are useful.7 Days to Die has a problem. It has many problems. Is the Zombie AI awful.....yeah...Are the weapons incredibly stock and unappealing.....Yeah...Is there no risk involved when you can just run back to your house and get your shotgun back after dying.....Yeah...But most of all, 7 Days to Die has one serious problem. It mixes and matches far too many concepts into spots where they do not belong. Base building is slow and unrewarding, when even stone walls can be broken down by the horde, and when breaking the game mechanics is the only way to provide safe shelter. Mining is slow and unrewarding, digging for hours to only come up with coal and nitrite, only to say ♥♥♥♥ it, and use dynamite to blow open caves simply because you can. Combat is slow and unrewarding, when even a huge horde can bring you nothing but some bullets and pieces of paper. Crafting is slow an unrewarding, and in essence, bland, using the usual PICKAXE, AXE, EXPLOSIVE, FENCING objects to build, bringing nothing new or surprising to the table. This game may be an alpha, it may have some quirks, and it may not be perfect yet.But if steam had a return button, I'd be smashing the refund key until Gabe kicked down my door, gripped my wrist ferociously, and lovingly whispered into my ear, "Cut that♥♥♥♥♥♥out"It's an alpha, and it isn't a fun one, not worth 30 dollars, and certainly not worth a moment of your time.
