content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been playing this game since the terrain was still blocks and "scrap metal" was a thing. That's why it pains me to say I don't think I can really recommend the game anymore. There have been a series of design choices that I just do not see as benefitial, and taken altogether, have been detrimental to the experience.Before I got to the biggest issue, first I should go into combat. I am not sure when it started, but combat has become annoying. Not for the fact it exists, but for the fact it often feels like zombies have a longer reach than you do, or that melee attacks you make against them that should hit do not. It feels like you must get much closer to them than they do to you. That on its own would be a fairly minor issue, however it does not exist in a vaccuum.All too often, you will be suddenly attacked from behind by a zombie that had silently crept up behind you from the surrounding area while fighting others. You are essentially expected to swing around mid-combat and scan behind you and your flanks to see if any other are encroaching. That is, quite frankly, ridiculous, nor from what I recall did it used to be that way. From what I recall, zombies used to make much more noise before, thus making it easier to notice them behind you.Again, on its own, too bad of an issue. So what is it that makes these problems such a big problem? Well, it's two-fold. Stunlock and "Wellness." When you are hit by a zombie, too frequently you are stunned. While you can still attack, it reduces more movement almost to nothing. While it may not sound bad to say "it only lasts two seconds," but that is two seconds where you are easily ravaged, quite possibly stunned again right after. That together with zombies that seem to have overly-long reach and can sneak up behind you without a sound, makes for a very frustrating encounter. And god forbid you die.If you did die, you encounter another major design choice that I cannot justify. The "Wellness" system. Your max health and stamina are tied to your Wellness, with a base Wellness of 100. A positive trend gives your more health and stamina, and likewise, a negative trend has a negative effect. And, apparently since Alpha 15, a new update at the time of writing this, experience gain is also tied to Wellness.Simply put, it is a semi-permanent punishment (there are ways to increase wellness) for not only dying, but for being attacked, or for being hungry or thirsty. To use a slight exagguration, you are punished for not playing optimally, by making it even more difficult to survive. You died? Then the game will make it easier for you to die again. Quite simply, that is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t considering, again, everything else I have said about the combat.With that out of the way, we come to what I think is the biggest problem with the game. The "7 Day Horde." Every seven days, a special horde will spawn nearby your location, or on top of you, and it always detects where you are at. The reason I consider this among the game's biggest issues is it essentially shuts down a nomadic style of gameplay, and it forces the game to be specifically revolved around this particular event, requiring you to establish yourself well enough to settle down and build enough defenses to stand against this horde. And that is all you are "allowed" to do. Any time you're spending not preparing for this horde is a waste, and in early game, could get you killed, which you are then punished for. This goes back to what I said earlier, where the game not only wants, but makes you, try to play "optimally," at least in the early game.Just take this recent example. I had a small house built, upgraded the lower portions to metal-enforced wood, and had my door upgraded. These zombies broke through the door within seconds, the zombie who actually broke it down took several headshots from a pistol, only for about four or five zombies barging in through the now-open doorway. Not to mention how totally useless my wood spikes were in that scenario, considering zombies, in general, seem to be attracted to breaking doors. How am I expected to defend against such aggression in so early of the game, only to be punished for dying? Especially considering you have to explore the map for resources, which takes away time that can be spent working on your base. The simple answer is there is no balance to these hordes oncesoever.And unfortunately, the developers have expressed refusal to make an in-game option for this 7 Day Horde, expressing that it is easy to to alter an XML file to turn them off. Frankly, it should be an option, and their unwillingness to do so under an excuse of how easy it is to edit a file, or as some people have argued, "people want options for everything," are just that; excuses. It is a foundational core element to the gameplay now, one that did not used to exist. Thus it is most certainly justifiable to have it as an option.There are other problems with the game that, while small, make for an overall inconvenient experience. The removal of the minimap and hunger and thirst bars on the player's UI, in spite of the fact that the map can be accessed at any time through a hotkey, and hunger and thirst can be seen on the character's inventory screen. Why these are not easily visible on the UI any longer, as they once were, I just cannot see a good argument for.The means of crafting was changed, from a Minecraft-like item-patterns on a crafting grid, to a more generic "select from a list." This change in itself isn't an issue, as even before,  you could select from a list and have items auto-placed, however with this update, the menu UI was changed. This is a visual matter, as the earlier inventory screen had a fitting design and aesthetic, while the newer one is bland and without any real asthetic, simply being a very basic menu over a grey background. Even the health and stamina bars look like they'd belong more at home on Microsoft Excel.Overall, while the game isn't terrible, it's presence isn't exactly strong, either. You might find it entertaining enough to justify its costs and compensation over its issues. If you have the money easily available to spend, and you think you may like it, then I suppose try it. However, I personally cannot recommend the game anymore; it simply has too much wrong with it, too many inconveniences, and that is really such a shame.

								Edit :  For those who crack up laughing everytime they  see a negative review from someone with 1800+ hours sunk into the thing, please read the entire review :)Back in the days, before they lost it hard in the last couple patches, i would have recommended this game to anyone, but now, in its current state , i wouldnt recommend it to my  worst ennemy.First of all, this game as THE WORST pvp of all the survival games out there. There are SOOOO many glitches and broken stuff that you can do to enter someone elses base .For example, You can jump 13 blocks away ( yes 13 blocks) if you build wood frames up  to the sky limit  and jump down 200 feet , and you only get a broken leg and lose around 40 hp , dumbest thing i have ever seen in a survival game. You can also dig a hole in the dirt, place a ladder and then see everything underground, all the bases, the players and you can even shoot them :/. You can also dupe stuff, and trust me, every ♥♥♥♥ing noobs out there dupe a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of ammo and guns without working at all. those bugs have been here for a while now, and the devs dont do anything to correct it, so if you want a pvp survival experience, go look somewhere else, realy.Multiplayer lags alot, no matter the rig you have or your internet connexion, its just bad, if your ping is higher than 50 or 60, and theres more than 8 players on the server , expect lag. I understand that different people like different things, but some of the praise I've seen this game get makes me think these people have never played a basic survival game in their entire lives.I can't believe this game's price is near other EA games like Killing Floor 2 or Ark: Survival Evolved. This is likely the worst game in EA, it should never have made it through Greenlight.

content:

Early Access Review
								I am not often inclined to take the time to write reviews, but this game has shaken my apathy. I was intrigued by the trailer and when the game went on sale I bought it. I don't have a true dedicated gaming computer and I can't run the game on the high setting like you see on some of the YouTube videos of this game and I've never gotten my FPS past 30. That being said I love this game.       The up and down side of this game is that it does not hold your hand and tell you how to do anything. The first three days I played I spent in an adrenaline soaked fearfest. After spending the night crouching and doing nothing in my fortified prefab I made some sort of noise and within moments dozens of wicked fast zombie ripped the walls down and tore me to shreds. After logging off in a panic I went to various wiki pages and YouTube to educate myself. After learning the massive crafting system and the all important first day order of operations (check out Oak's Game Room 7 Days to Die tips and playthroughs) I have since been able to make it 7 days without dying consistantly. I have not played much multiplay and no PvP (for me the zombies are enough to think about, thank you) but I can see the draw, especially because once you've had a chance to make a base, mine ore, find and read the books, craft guns and ammo and stockpile food you become a stand alone army. You will go from hiding from the undead to carrying meat around to attract more, allowing you to further cull Zach's population. That chilling fear of ever present death will be replaced by the rush of power as you look down in complete safety as the undead rush toward your stronghold and kill themselves on your redundant defences, leaving you to tend your garden in peace.       Since the game is in Alpha (I started in 10.4) there are still some major changes coming down the road and a few bugs (very rarely crafted items will disappear from the crafting window if you search for something else), but the game is very playable and quite fun. There are plans to make a story with missions and so on, but there is none of that now and it is still crazy addictive. I would recommend checking this game out and helping the developers flesh out this game.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								(See below for Update to review)Ok, I bought this game a while back and have been playing it off and on, almost with each update.  I have to say, that I am very happy with the latest update which provides random world gen instead of the default map. I have about 4 friends that make this game very fun to play since we can work and explore together. I think this game is worth every penny. I consider it like this. Look how much it costs to go to a movie..... Or even buy a good blu-ray.  Now consider how many hours that keeps you entertained.  Then consider that this game can keep you happy for even just a 25 hours (I believe it will be almost 200.) You can see that it is quite a bargain. Then on top of it, you can restart it with another random generation map and play again. How can you beat that?UpdateSo, now that I have almost 400 hours, I feel I need to update this review.I now believe that this is one of my favorite games of all times and I will list the reasons why.Positive reasons.1. This game provides a well balanced survival experience.  Food and water, shelter and defense.2. The graphics while not spectacular, are on par for a game of this much content in my opinion.3. This game does not force you to join a server with other players.4. This game can provide a single player, local LAN or even public server experience.5. The game has a wide variety of difficulty.  From almost too easy, to insanely impossible.6. Regular updates and news from the developers, as well as screen shots of upcoming content.7. Structural physics, no floating blocks or seemingly impossible constructions.8. New atmospheric conditions and weather system. I love it, adds a whole new level of "creepy" to the game.Wants.1. More animals - Deer, rabbit, pig, and bears.  I hope they put more into the game.2. More diversity in weapons - The guns are plenty diverse, but maybe a few more melee weapons.3. Travel options - Motorized bike coming soon, but maybe a car or truck too.4. More trap options, or possibly mechanized or spring loaded traps.5. Power - Electricity for lights, cooking, maybe an electrified fence.6. Objective oriented goals - Not necessarily quests, but some sort of goals other than survival would be nice.7. Leveling perks and possibly attribute points that affect combat, crafting, survival traits.Other thoughts.This game is well worth the price asked by the devs.  I believe that I have never had as much fun in any triple A titles.  I was lucky and got the game during a sale and to be honest, the sale discount they give is substantial unlike some other big name titles that only offer a 5 to 10 % discount and only that because it's been out for 2 years.Hope this helps make the decision for you.(Update November 2016)So, I have been playing this game so long now it should be obvious by now that I find the game worth it just by the amount of hours I have put into it. If that doesn't convince you, the just read my review above. I am a little disappointed that the Devs seem to be slowing down on developement here but I understand that it's not always easy to put in all the things you want to put in. It's still worth it's price in my view.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've really been enjoying this game. For an early access game it's extremely entertaining, and has a lot of features, and constantly gets updated. As with early access games, it's lacking features or has certain gameplay issues. It falls under the zombie survival genre, with added aspects of crafting and building, and does all of those much better than similar games.The zombie aspect is very well done so far. The early game is very enjoyable and challenging. The hoards every 7 nights, as well as wandering hoards, keep more passive players challenged. High value areas with higher risk make the difficulty enjoyable. Different types of zombies make a much better zombie gameplay, though I really do hate the way dogs are. I find the current issue is being able to finalize a base and move into the late game. Going into the late game means there is very little challenge, as you've set up a fantastic base with access to many resources, and very low risk of ever being overrun, basically the zombie aspect becomes weaker. Leaving a crafting and building experience as the focus. As an alpha, that could very well be changed and would make this game even better than it already is. The crafting and building aspect of the game are decent so far. There are a good amount of block types for different stages of the game, and different types of buildings. Making a decent progression for base building. Crafting is done well so far, but I feel there is a lot of room for improvement. The RNG of needing certain books to unlock things can be very fustrating. Progressing with techology of tools and items progresses a little too fast, and slow, depending on the stage of the game. More depth would be very nice. Overall crafting and building are solid, but have lots of options and room to grow as alpha goes on.The issues it currently has are the very basic form of random generated maps, though it's a newer feature. There is a low number of Points of Interests / unique buildings. Though they are adding them regularly, and currently the core buildings are all great. I would really like to see a ton of new buildings combined with a better random generated system to make a better game. Regardless there has been good progression regarding this, and I have high hopes for the outcome.The game is not the most stable and plenty of people complain about fps drops around certain things, or with too many zombies. Though personally my pc is very good and handles it well enough. Overall this game is good with lots of room to become really amazing.

Early Access Review
								As someone who has never played Minecraft and still has no interest in it, it's strange that I have taken so quickly to 7 Days to Die. Perhaps it's because I enjoyed playing games like Left 4 Dead, but found the linear approach to the game boring. In 7 Days to Die you can survive the zombie apocalyse in the way you want to! You can be a nomad roaming from town to town, baracading yourself in buildings on the 7th night and not worrying about the place getting trashed. Or build a fortress-like base that you never leave, except to explore. Or build a nice little house to live in, but a bastion somewhere nearby to retreat to.However, I think it's the multiplayer co-op that makes the game for me. There's nothing better than raiding a town with your friends, hoping to find something special. It's going to get dark soon? Well there's one last house to raid, I've got this feeling there's an SMG schematic in there.Definitely worth getting when on sale. Probably not worth it on full price if you're going to play solo.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								After about 30 hrs. of play I can say this is my favorite zombie survival game. I have seen some reviews compairing it to Minecraft, they must have been a bit of time ago because the game has come a long way since then. The land and items are no longer blocky. Hills are a nice and smooth incline and you don't have to jump constantly to navigate it. The crafting system is great. Some things, like the stone axe (whice normally is the first thing / weapon / tool that you make) can be crafted from the onset of the game. Other items you have to find the recipie and learn it to be able to craft the item. There is also a time element in the crafting, depending on how complex the item depends on how long it takes to make it. The good thing is that if you need to craft a lot of something, like say arrows, once put the items in the grid and start the crafting you can close your inventory (which is where the general crafting grid is, there isn't a crafting table) and the items will keep crafting. It's great especially when you have a group of zombies on your tail and you run out of crossbow bolts. There are several forms of crafting in the game but I will let you figure those out.The zombies, in my opinion, look and act pretty darn good. There is a nice amount of zombie models and they look good. What might put some off is that even though there are a good amount of different models of zombies, each specific zombie looks the same. The big fat zombies look all the same, no variations. That is no big deal to me, the rest of the game more then makes up for it. The zombie animations are good as well. Sometimes they might act a bit wonkey when traversing an obstical, like when they are stuck in a spike trap they have a tendency to hop and hop. They are creepy as hell when you have a bunch of them shambling towards you and completely terrifying when they are running straight to you (if you have them set to run) with arms out stretched. If you do have them set to run at certain times of the day, the game gives you a great sense of urgency. You know you better be inside somewhere before they start running because you will be dead if you don't, unless you are armed to the teeth.The devs are great. If the community askes for something, they try to put it in. If the community then decides they really don't like the change they take it out. I have never had the oppretunity to talk with the devs, but everything I have seen on the fourms shows that they listen to what the community.This is my first review and I hope that it has helped some. If you are still on the fence check out some reviews or let's plays on your favorite video site. But if you like zombies, get this game. If you like crafting, get this game. If you like getting the ever lovin crap scared out of you when you are holed up in the attic of a house and the zombies are outside tearing the house to pieces and you know any second the house is going to collapse, then GET THIS GAME!!!!

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								After about 30 hrs. of play I can say this is my favorite zombie survival game. I have seen some reviews compairing it to Minecraft, they must have been a bit of time ago because the game has come a long way since then. The land and items are no longer blocky. Hills are a nice and smooth incline and you don't have to jump constantly to navigate it. The crafting system is great. Some things, like the stone axe (whice normally is the first thing / weapon / tool that you make) can be crafted from the onset of the game. Other items you have to find the recipie and learn it to be able to craft the item. There is also a time element in the crafting, depending on how complex the item depends on how long it takes to make it. The good thing is that if you need to craft a lot of something, like say arrows, once put the items in the grid and start the crafting you can close your inventory (which is where the general crafting grid is, there isn't a crafting table) and the items will keep crafting. It's great especially when you have a group of zombies on your tail and you run out of crossbow bolts. There are several forms of crafting in the game but I will let you figure those out.The zombies, in my opinion, look and act pretty darn good. There is a nice amount of zombie models and they look good. What might put some off is that even though there are a good amount of different models of zombies, each specific zombie looks the same. The big fat zombies look all the same, no variations. That is no big deal to me, the rest of the game more then makes up for it. The zombie animations are good as well. Sometimes they might act a bit wonkey when traversing an obstical, like when they are stuck in a spike trap they have a tendency to hop and hop. They are creepy as hell when you have a bunch of them shambling towards you and completely terrifying when they are running straight to you (if you have them set to run) with arms out stretched. If you do have them set to run at certain times of the day, the game gives you a great sense of urgency. You know you better be inside somewhere before they start running because you will be dead if you don't, unless you are armed to the teeth.The devs are great. If the community askes for something, they try to put it in. If the community then decides they really don't like the change they take it out. I have never had the oppretunity to talk with the devs, but everything I have seen on the fourms shows that they listen to what the community.This is my first review and I hope that it has helped some. If you are still on the fence check out some reviews or let's plays on your favorite video site. But if you like zombies, get this game. If you like crafting, get this game. If you like getting the ever lovin crap scared out of you when you are holed up in the attic of a house and the zombies are outside tearing the house to pieces and you know any second the house is going to collapse, then GET THIS GAME!!!!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've struggled a lot with my opinion of this game because there are some *really* good things about it.  There are also some *really* bad things about it.At this exact moment in time, the good outweighs the bad.Pros:+ Crafting system is really polished.+ Progression from nomad to established base owner is fun, natural, and works really well with the game mechanics.+ Multiplayer with friends feels like a totally different game.  It can be an incredible experience with the right friends.+ Zombies are smart enough to pose a risk to the uninitiated, but dumb enough that you can fend off huge groups of them if you plan ahead.Cons:- Very poorly optimized.  I have an i7-4770k and a GTX 980 and running on max settings gives me 20-30 FPS with regular dips into the low teens.  I can get display-capped 144 FPS consistently on much more graphically-demanding games.- Bugs.  Dear lord, the bugs.  Expect things to randomly go missing.  Expect to die without any apparent cause.- The developers (and fans) seem openly hostile to bug reports or any kind of legitimate criticism of the game.  Its early access state is routinely used as a blanket apologetic for the game's problems.  Stay away from the game's official forums and subreddit.  They are both cancerous echo chambers.In summary: play it -- but go in with the knowledge that your experience will be far from perfect.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								(See below for Update to review)Ok, I bought this game a while back and have been playing it off and on, almost with each update.  I have to say, that I am very happy with the latest update which provides random world gen instead of the default map. I have about 4 friends that make this game very fun to play since we can work and explore together. I think this game is worth every penny. I consider it like this. Look how much it costs to go to a movie..... Or even buy a good blu-ray.  Now consider how many hours that keeps you entertained.  Then consider that this game can keep you happy for even just a 25 hours (I believe it will be almost 200.) You can see that it is quite a bargain. Then on top of it, you can restart it with another random generation map and play again. How can you beat that?UpdateSo, now that I have almost 400 hours, I feel I need to update this review.I now believe that this is one of my favorite games of all times and I will list the reasons why.Positive reasons.1. This game provides a well balanced survival experience.  Food and water, shelter and defense.2. The graphics while not spectacular, are on par for a game of this much content in my opinion.3. This game does not force you to join a server with other players.4. This game can provide a single player, local LAN or even public server experience.5. The game has a wide variety of difficulty.  From almost too easy, to insanely impossible.6. Regular updates and news from the developers, as well as screen shots of upcoming content.7. Structural physics, no floating blocks or seemingly impossible constructions.8. New atmospheric conditions and weather system. I love it, adds a whole new level of "creepy" to the game.Wants.1. More animals - Deer, rabbit, pig, and bears.  I hope they put more into the game.2. More diversity in weapons - The guns are plenty diverse, but maybe a few more melee weapons.3. Travel options - Motorized bike coming soon, but maybe a car or truck too.4. More trap options, or possibly mechanized or spring loaded traps.5. Power - Electricity for lights, cooking, maybe an electrified fence.6. Objective oriented goals - Not necessarily quests, but some sort of goals other than survival would be nice.7. Leveling perks and possibly attribute points that affect combat, crafting, survival traits.Other thoughts.This game is well worth the price asked by the devs.  I believe that I have never had as much fun in any triple A titles.  I was lucky and got the game during a sale and to be honest, the sale discount they give is substantial unlike some other big name titles that only offer a 5 to 10 % discount and only that because it's been out for 2 years.Hope this helps make the decision for you.(Update November 2016)So, I have been playing this game so long now it should be obvious by now that I find the game worth it just by the amount of hours I have put into it. If that doesn't convince you, the just read my review above. I am a little disappointed that the Devs seem to be slowing down on developement here but I understand that it's not always easy to put in all the things you want to put in. It's still worth it's price in my view.

								I do recommend this game.  ----First id like to start with the negative things though (i know its a bit backwards)The dev team can be kind of finicky at times, they tend to break things in attempts to fix it, only making things more frustrating. For example they took out the viability of melee combat in comparison to ranged, i dont know why because it was in no way overpowered as you still needed tons of meds and bandages. They do realize the issue ... but wont fix it for a very long time from now(alpha 13 to be exact). i dont know about you but melee combat not working in a zed survival game is really bad. HACKING it is real... and it is alive, i dont know what the devs are trying to do to stop people from hacking but it is bruuutal, your house, everything you worked for can be gone in the blink of an eye to a hacker so beware. An easy fix to stop hackers is to disable creative mode, i know a lot of creative people would be upset and all but us online players dont like getting hacked on(i speak for us all) .Other than that of course there are the usual alpha complaints, be ready to deal with constant wipes and at times stability issues, they are easy to overlook unless you are some architect that likes spending all their time on building something pretty. --- As for the positive, The game is pretty and is getting even better over time, the environments and the textures, variety of weapons and crafting. Its super fun especially when played with a good community or even just 1 friend. the variety is just so huge you never know what you are going to find. i do recommend playing it on hard or feral though or else the game is kind of too easy. The sheer potential of this game is enormous and with every large update you find yourself in a somewhat brand new game.           HAPPY HUNTING!!!PS. They added this thing called gore blocks recently and its god aweful and i hope they fix it, at first it made sense that zombies dead bodies could pile up causing others to use them as a +1 elevation platform, but the way the devs implemented it is poorly executed in my opinion.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've really been enjoying this game. For an early access game it's extremely entertaining, and has a lot of features, and constantly gets updated. As with early access games, it's lacking features or has certain gameplay issues. It falls under the zombie survival genre, with added aspects of crafting and building, and does all of those much better than similar games.The zombie aspect is very well done so far. The early game is very enjoyable and challenging. The hoards every 7 nights, as well as wandering hoards, keep more passive players challenged. High value areas with higher risk make the difficulty enjoyable. Different types of zombies make a much better zombie gameplay, though I really do hate the way dogs are. I find the current issue is being able to finalize a base and move into the late game. Going into the late game means there is very little challenge, as you've set up a fantastic base with access to many resources, and very low risk of ever being overrun, basically the zombie aspect becomes weaker. Leaving a crafting and building experience as the focus. As an alpha, that could very well be changed and would make this game even better than it already is. The crafting and building aspect of the game are decent so far. There are a good amount of block types for different stages of the game, and different types of buildings. Making a decent progression for base building. Crafting is done well so far, but I feel there is a lot of room for improvement. The RNG of needing certain books to unlock things can be very fustrating. Progressing with techology of tools and items progresses a little too fast, and slow, depending on the stage of the game. More depth would be very nice. Overall crafting and building are solid, but have lots of options and room to grow as alpha goes on.The issues it currently has are the very basic form of random generated maps, though it's a newer feature. There is a low number of Points of Interests / unique buildings. Though they are adding them regularly, and currently the core buildings are all great. I would really like to see a ton of new buildings combined with a better random generated system to make a better game. Regardless there has been good progression regarding this, and I have high hopes for the outcome.The game is not the most stable and plenty of people complain about fps drops around certain things, or with too many zombies. Though personally my pc is very good and handles it well enough. Overall this game is good with lots of room to become really amazing.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
Early Access Review
Having fairly minor experience with free world survival games, playing Rust previously, I had a fun time... but it was missing something, you could get your bases all nice and zombie proof, and essentially player proof within a few days, it became a sniping fest after a little while.Early access 7DTD however had me screw up fairly quickly, found some unboiled water, promptly drank it while dehydrated and began vomiting everywhere. Found some meat, and had some walkers on my butt within moments. Soon after, I noticed a giant Wasp, which cottoned on to my existence and stung me to death.Now, after that whole death spam, I made it into a derelict metropolis, noticed a lovely building with plenty of easily exploited areas for drop pits, pungees, and all round safety for my scaredy-cat self. I went out after the first night had finished, hearing sounds of a plethora of walkers that wanted my tasty flesh and took axe to skull... got overwhelmed, and died. Nobody looted my corpse, so that's a bonus. I then began constructing my ultra-secure, 4 story building repairs. Not a soul made it into my place alive. I began making high powered weapons, and had a very great secondary and tertiary base, all nice and cosy, away from dogs and wasps. The downside being: your bases only have 1 mattress over all bases, so, essentially your respawn may not actually be anywhere near your homebase (really, I'm just an idiot and didn't realise soon enough).PROS:Super duper easy to kill yourself from things like - water, food, rancid food. Get drunk.So. Much. Space. I literally ran for DAYS attempting to reach end borders, or other signs of civilization. I found a few rebar drop fortresses but that was few and far between.Zombies are smarter than the average bear - they can sniff you, they can hear you.When night comes, an immense sense of oh shi~ begins. When you get weeks into survival, you can still get mobbed by ever increasing intelligence.Respawning gun safes, cabinets, book shelves; which all allow recipes and blueprint discoveries - so fun collecting whole sets!Playing with friends, especially new friends on vent, TS, Skype etc. is hilarious when they're trying to find you and hilariously get mobbed to death before you arrive.CONS:While the Zombie design is cool, there's a lot of rehashed skins, there's little variety to actual Zombies - essentially bruisers, fast walkers, slow walkers, and occasionally a bloat type... Dogs suck balls.Wasps suck even more balls, especially without some kind of Crossbow/ Gun on hand.Underestimating falls and leaps; easily gib yourself...Sometimes dogs and wasps can warp into your shoeboxes (if you're out on the hunt and need a safe area to die if you're too encumbered).Climbing Zombies, which I guess is technically a pro, because they also show you your base flaws.Overall, I really enjoy this game, it's too bad I don't get to play it more, really. P.S. While there are a dime-a-dozen free world Alpha Zombie Survival games, this one does have a certain, I don't know what that really tickles my fancy.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								As someone who has never played Minecraft and still has no interest in it, it's strange that I have taken so quickly to 7 Days to Die. Perhaps it's because I enjoyed playing games like Left 4 Dead, but found the linear approach to the game boring. In 7 Days to Die you can survive the zombie apocalyse in the way you want to! You can be a nomad roaming from town to town, baracading yourself in buildings on the 7th night and not worrying about the place getting trashed. Or build a fortress-like base that you never leave, except to explore. Or build a nice little house to live in, but a bastion somewhere nearby to retreat to.However, I think it's the multiplayer co-op that makes the game for me. There's nothing better than raiding a town with your friends, hoping to find something special. It's going to get dark soon? Well there's one last house to raid, I've got this feeling there's an SMG schematic in there.Definitely worth getting when on sale. Probably not worth it on full price if you're going to play solo.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Right now, I have over 50 hours put in so far, which about 60% of that time spent in Single-player, and about 40% of that time spent in Multi-player. Long story short? I recommend 7 Days to Die in its current state (Alpha 15).To be fair, starting basically naked, alone, and in unfamiliar territory, is not a new concept. Yes, there are other games that start this way, set in a post apocalyptic world overrun by zombies. Yes, there is food and water needs. Then there is the crafting, and base building, etc we have all seen before.So what does 7 Days to Die exactly bring to the table to set it apart? I generally hate tower defense games if that is all they are. However, when it is coupled with other genres in the right way, it adds much more to depth to some games. I like playing survival games, as I prefer the added challenge, but rarely do they present a challenge. Most of the time the challenge is dealing with the people that are being "raiders" more because they are just bored with the game from lack of a challenge. Then 7 Days to Die comes along and says, "what if the game was actually a challenge and we try to kill the player?", and try to kill you it will.Sight, sound, smell, and in some cases just existing are enough for a zombie to want to kill you. Some can climb walls, others can call more zombies, and some that sense you through walls simply because you have a pulse. Add in disease, climate, food, thirst, killer bears, zombie dogs, and collapsing structures for a touch of fear. Oh, and the zombies during the day are Walking Dead speed, but at night go full on 28 Days Later Usain Bolt chasing you fast.To top it all off, every 7th night a "Blood Moon" occures where a "Blood Horde" spawns at night intent on killing you. Yes, they are still fast, and no you cannot hide (well you can, but it's not that simple).After my first night, I was intrigued because I've never died on the first night in a survival game. Yes, I even survived Don't Starve for several days the first try. Then I hopped into a co-op game with the friend that gifted me the game, and we barely managed to survive our first "Blood Horde". By that time I was really getting into the game, and after passing Day 14 in both single-player and multi-player I was positively hooked.System Specs CPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4790K Processor @ 4.40GHz CPU Cooler: Corsair H100i GPU: GeForce GTX 970 G1 Gaming Memory: Corsair Vengeance 32GB OS: Windows 10 Pro

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Bought this as a bit of a gamble as I very rarely buy early access games and it was on sale.Best £7 I've ever spent. The game is hard to describe but it's like a cross between Minecraft, Left 4 Dead, Skyrim and State of Decay. You can craft weapons, armour, tools, clothes, ammo, medicine, food, water in fact practically anything in fact as long as you have the ingredients and the knowledge to craft the item. Some items you already know how to craft right from the start like a bow and arrows, boiled water and charred meat, others like steel you need to learn during gameplay.You'll start off in a "safe zone" where no zombies have spawned and it will stay that way for 5 in game hours (as of alpha 15). Use that time wisely to craft your starting gear which you'll find the ingredients for in your starting area, stuff like stone axes and plant finer clothes, a wooden club and a bow and arrows. This stuff is absolutely  vital to have before the zombies start spawning at 12 midday in your starting area and everywhere else once you leave the starting area.The game map is vast. It's made up of different areas know as biomes, they are pine forest, oak tree forest,  burnt forest, wasteland, desert and snow. The best ones for a noob are the pine and oak tree forest biomes. Avoid burnt forest and desert until you're more experienced apart from passing through or if you want some yucca fruit and aloe Vera plants which are in the desert biome. Avoid snow biomes due to the cold weather and lumberjack zombies who are very powerful when you first start.  Avoid wasteland biomes like the plague, this is the hardest area on the entire map, expect very harsh conditions,  very little plant life and a lot more zombies as well as the "special" zombies that spawn in the wasteland, you'll also have to deal with zombie dogs that can kill even an experienced player if you're not paying attention. You'll have until 10pm if you set the game to 18 hours of daylight before nightfall (highly recommended). During the nighttime you'll want to be inside a prefabricated building, on at least the first floor up and destroy the bottom part of the stairs. This is because at nighttime the zombies start running like in left4dead and can be hard to spot if you happen to outside at night. You can also make your own base but for your first night or two a prefabricated building is fine, just make secure it's secure. From day 2 or 3 though you'll need to start making your own base or fortify the prefabricated building you're in.So you're probably wondering why it's called 7 Days to Die? Well, on day 7 and every 7 days after that at nightfall (so 10pm on day 7 and so on) there will be a blood moon. You'll know it when you see it. You need to be in your base by 9pm at the latest otherwise you may get caught out by the lack of light or what comes next - a zombie horde. They will be running (unless you've set them to walk) and they can sense you no matter how well you hide (with a few noteable exceptions) so you'll have to fight them. They will also keep coming until dawn. Be prepared with plenty of arrows for your bow and prepare yourself by drinking and eating just before the horde arrives.Overall I highly recommend this game.

Early Access Review
								Surprisingly good... I was really sceptical at first, but as one of my friends gifted the game to me I would loose nothing by trying the game. After seeing trailers and screenshots, my expectations were incredibly low, but after the first 5 minutes the game grew on me. the Atmosphere reminds me of Fallout 3 and the game world is incredible. This game is more akin to Minecraft than anything else. The vast amount of content and the satisfying gunplay keeps me going, and I LOVE the RPG elements... I am a sucker for exp and leveling. There are servers online which you can join for PVP but the most fun I've had is playing solo or co-op with friends. Your character, which you can make any way you wish, is saved as a profile to be loaded in different worlds (no items and levels transfer, only appearance). Crafting and building is extensive. Mining far into the ground and exploring underground caves is just as much fun as exploring the huge cities. There are many blueprints and schematics to find, and there are tonnes of ways to play. If you like survival games but want to stay away from all the hectic PVP, and just loose yourself in a postapocalyptic world, building bases and min-maxing supplies... then this game is for you. I give it an 8/10.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								=HEADS UP=I had a review before this one about the game being good. This stays of course but i had to clarify some points and fix this old messy review that i made before.=INFO ABOUT THE REVIEW=1. This review might be a bit longer.2. This review is about my point of view and opinion. [If you disagree on a certain point or want to correct me: Be reasonable or i will ignore your comment.]=REVIEW=This game is just amazing. Lets start with that and go right to the first point. Most of the Zombiesurvival games promise you so many things. They promise you a great Craftingsystem. They promise you that you can build your own base. They promise you intense gameplay and that you have to stay on your toes all the time.And most of the time we do not get what we pay for. We do not get the great Craftingsystem. We do not get the cool buildings. We dont have to watch out or get killed in one second because the game is so unbalanced that you literally cant stay alive long enough to even get some kind of weapon.This game is different. Before the actual danger begins you have a full day, that you can configure (more of that later) of getting supplies up to build or just barricade you. You might be even able to find something really usefull in a nearby house or little village. And you might even be able to find a higher tier tool. And that is important. With A11 we got a new system for the tools. The longer you play the better you can craft your tools. The better you can craft the better the tools get. More damage to a block or enemy. More durability and such. But you can also find them. That will help you greatly in some cases. If you are at the beginning the pickaxe and the axe in good quality can help you greatly. Without you will have to go on just like normaly and take what the game gives you.But you have to be fast about what you are doing since there are Zombies everywhere and it is slowly turning to nighttime. But what happens when the night hits? Well lets just call it literally Hell. The Zombies begin to run and with that i mean every Zombie. On the hardest settings they are even able to sense you in your base through the walls and begin to break down the blocks you have placed or the blocks that are naturally in place.You have survived your first night? Congratulations. But this isnt over. Because now you have 6 more days. 6 more days to die on the 7nth day. And why? Well you remember that this is a horde survival? Well make sure that you are ready to face the horde. Not to speak of the infamous "Day 14" horde. That was a nice time when i suddenly heard... Oh wait i shouldnt tell you more. Heh Heh.But now we should head to the performance of the game. For my personal prefference the performance could be better but it still isnt bad. My PC is decent and so are the parts and i get a good 40 up to 50 fps with higher settings. The newer Unity engine makes the game even more beautiful than it was before. But what about the settings?Well of course you can change everything you would need. There are some things that i would love to have implemented but the game is not finished yet so we will see what comes in the future. But lets go over to the main settings that you have to set up your game.First you have a selection of which world you want to use. You can choose between the handcrafted world they present with the game and a world that is randomly generated. With both worlds you can configure everything else about it though. Like if you want a longer day or night. Or if Zombies should run at all. How hard the game should be for the world and so on and so forth. You can change everything that is important about the gameplay.

								I have been in this from the beta.This game started off as a typical Voxel game and over time has molded into a very luscious game. Regardless of some gamers reviews cause they fill they didn't get the game they wanted I'm reminding people this is the developer's game not ours, altho we do have some influence on some things that get added and done.The Fun Pimps have taken and made a Zombie game that is customizable to many play styles.There version is mutant zombies and such where as us gamers are allowed to remove them or turn off certain things and change things to suit our own Zombie Apocalypse by simply changing info in some XML files.I've opt in almost every Zombie game out but 2d zombie games an this 7 Days to Die is the only one I've personally didn't feel like I got ripped off or burnt on.What to look forward to that makes it different than any other zombie game. It is solely based on the Zombies and you and not making the Zombies a static object. Most all Zombie games start out making a Zombie game but shortly in they all focus way to much of the game on player interaction with each other turning them in a player verse Player survival game and the zombies are like grass and trees cause people fear the player more than they do the zombie. The brain then stops thinking of the Zombie as a threat and looks out for the player instead. You become to busy looking for charlie to jump out you ignore the real focus of a zombie game and just dodge the reason you started to play the game.With 7 Days to Die this is not the issue. TheFunPimps have focused the game on player survival and the Zombies. This has drawn some tension in the community of pvp players being vocal saying pvp is broken but what is pvp? Player Vs Player anything outside of the player hunting player becomes static it's all about kill and don't be killed. You don't see people play a pvp game to stand around and talk.If you play solo or coop with friends it is the best Zombie game out that has stuck to it's focus on making the Zombie the threat and survival.I recently saw a post talking about how ugly the graphics was. If you go back in kickstarter days at the very beginning you saw a minecraft clone with better assets. As this game developed the voxel minecraft look and feel started to vanish. The polishing of the game has just made it better and better. A lot of people still live in the 32 bit world and when you dealing with voxels you can not be there. TFP have tried hard to not do like AAA games and other Voxel developers have done and stopped trying to make it work on 32 bit systems and told their fan base 64 bit or nothing. They still try to bring it to the 32 bit world so they haven't forsaken them.Some of the developers are very active and even have started to do let's play showing off game footage of upcoming updates we will see. They put up with some really hateful remarks and people asking for everything under the sun yet maintain their cool. It is a amazing group of guys and a amazing Zombie game you shouldn't miss out on. Alpha 15 Experemental was put up today and I can tell you it is Gorgeous just Gorgeous.All the op stuff tweaked to be right on track now, Zombies screamers working better than ever to point they had me on my roof for 4 game hours till I starved to death lol. This game just gets better and better every alpha phase not understanding why some give it a bad review.This Game has replay value over and over and over and when with friends it has the same replay value. This is a game that is not only fun to play with other but solo as well. Can't wait to see the rest of it done and it going gold by 2017 spring time which is the final goal cause it is almost at the end of it's alpha.What are you waiting for? If you like sandbox and fun with self freinds or kids this is the game for you.

Early Access Review
								So yes, the graphics are pretty meh. Considering games like Ark which have some of the same abilities (chopping trees, rocks, etc) but feature MUCH better graphics, it does feel pretty behind the times in that regard.And the sound design/mixing is some of the worst I've ever had to endure in a game. Is that a zombie chewing directly on my skull? Or at least the wall? No, it was my friend on the other side of the lot opening a box. WOA was that the ENTIRE TOWN EXPLODING or no, nevermind, just a tree falling down, ok. Also I'm not sure why picking up rocks or hitting trees with an axe sounds like someone getting funky with a leather suitcase. Devs, I would definitely recommend hiring someone professional to spruce up the sound design...it's an incredibly powerful, relatively easy way to make a sub-par game feel AMAZING.Anyway, moving on.All that aside, the core of this game and why it's amazing is having the ability to build whatever you like, and having real genuine purpose for it. You NEED to develop a proper home base with regular food and water supply. You HAVE to fortify against attack. You MUST devise better traps and defenses to survive the 7th nights. It's extremely satisfying to have a construction game with actual purpose! The only other game I've played like this was Terraria with its blood moons.So, all in all, highly recommended. Having at least two or three people in a game makes it much easier, since you can watch each others backs while you work. :)

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								I should start by mentioning that this is extreme early access and is buggy as hell. So if you're not cool with that, better bugger off.If you wanted a game set in "The Walking Dead" universe, minus the people. This is it.You clear out a house, it's perfect. There's a gunsafe, beds, food, a fridge, multiple exits, the works. Then it gets over run and you're back on the road.Find another house, clear it out. Same deal, suits your needs. You see a far off explosion. "Oh boy" you say as you go to investigate, could be anything really. Then you see it, a huge camp surrounded by Barbed wire and Landmines.Loot the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of the joint, set up the defences around your own house, live out your 7 days sitting on the balcony watching zombies get blown to♥♥♥♥♥♥Day 1I've set up camp in a large 2 story house. It's fantastic. I have 5 guns :DDay 2House got overrun, 1 of my guns is broken and i'm out of ammo for the rest.I've found another building, it looks like an old garage (Y'know, like a repair shop)It's quiet in here but it's filthy and dark.Day 3I don't know how to craft a damn thing, i've sacrificed 2 of my remaining guns for scrap iron so i can make myself a pickaxe.I went scavenging today, raided 3 houses and a campsite. Nothing much was found, mostly food.I have too much food.Day 4God damnit. Today sucked, i'll start with the morning.Mined for a bit, killed some zombies, survived a horde, started farming blueberries, normal stuff this morning. Then I found a gas pump out the back, because I'm a god damned fool, I shot it. It exploded, blew up half the building and destroyed my gunsafe which had everything in it :/All I have is 1 hunting rifle, my pickaxe, some boiled rabbit and a torch.I'm moving.Day 5I've been searching for a house all day. All I can find are tents. Tents suck. I finally settled on a little tent next to a huge building. I wanted the building but jesus christ the place is crawling with zombies.It's a decent tent, i made a door and blocked up the windows, it will have to do until i find a real place.The last 2 days were awful, man :(Day 6GOD DAMNIT. It's the middle of the night. I just wrote the diary for day 5 and went back to playing.Y'know how I mentioned that I was a damned fool? I PUNCHED THE WINDOW IN MY TENT (Yes it had glass pane windows)This may not seem bad to you but the game has gravity. The entire roof fell down.I've had this tent for 5 minutes.Went hunting, killed a few rabbits and a pig. Cut down some trees, started melting down some iron to make a gun safe. I want one because I need storage and gun safes are the biggest kind.I started building a little shelter across the road  from my campsite. I hope I can build a huge base eventually. I'll start a fence tomorrow/So it's about to tick over to Day 7 and a giant bee thing flew up to me. It was obviously an enemy because it was marked on the map. I shot it down with my hunting rifle. It didn't drop anything or even leave a body. I'll look it up on the wiki because I've never seen one before and i'm tripping out right now.Edit: Hornets. It doesn't say anything about them being rare so I don't know why I only saw my first one on Day 6Day 7I hope this game isn't literal and I actually suvive today.So I went for a walk, found some guns in a building down the road. Nothing much else.Today was very uneventful until I got attacked by a zombie and got infected. Of course, I didn't know I was infected until I did some research.Thankfully you can craft antibiotics and fix it.Unfortunately that's not easy.I needed to scavenge some moldy bread, some potassium nitrate powder and a beaker then cook it on a camp fire.I had no beaker or bread. Crap. I've got the camp fire and the potassium nitrate from cracking open some rocks though.So I bolted to the nearest building I hadn't touched and bang! 2 beakers and 3 guns. Nice!On the way out the door I accidently pressed 'E' to search some garbage and you'll never guess what's in the garbage. Mouldy bread.I couldn't beleive my luck. I cooked it up right then and there, took my meds and went on my way with some left over. Today was a good day.I logged off before the sun went down so I'll edit later.Edit: Nothing major, cooked a bunch of meat and some more antibiotics, which was lucky because I got infected again :/Day 8This morning was boring as hell, I just cooked and stuff. Still haven't built a new place for myself. Tent's just fine. In the middle of the day a huge♥♥♥♥♥horde moved through my camp. Like 40 zombies man. I have screenshots to show for it. I killed them all and was looking for anything useful on their bodies when I heard a plane fly over. I looked around and saw it drop 2 crates! I bolted to the first one, nothing major, bandages, food, 2 antibiotics. Then I went over to the second crate. Medical supplies for days: 50 antibiotic pills and 20 bandages. I'm in heaven.Night's coming as I write this. I'll keep you posted.So another horde attacked. On the same day. It as even bigger this time, I think. I took another screenshot but I had killed most of them beforehand.Day 9Another horde attack in the morning, nothing major today. Made some leather clothing, collected heaps of water because I didn't have any. Planning on starting a farm.The tent is pretty much wrecked.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is the game I have been asking for since I first started playing zombie games, back when Left 4 Dead 2 was still new.At first I was skeptical, thinking it looked like just another Minecraft-like clone. However, after watching Markiplier and LordMinion777 play it, I decided to give it a shot.Within minutes of playing, I already became addicted and wanted to play more.My two best friends also recently bought the game and we decided to try it out together. At first it was a little rough, all of us were spawned so far from one another and it took us a while to meet up. We did have to start over a few times until we got a hang of the game. But once we were able to group up and figure out a plan, we were able to get a grip on the basics farily quickly.This game is alot of fun and well put together. The zombies are actually scary (esapecially at night), the different biomes are amazing and well put together and the survival is a bit of a challenge but fun.One of my favorite things is the consequences for your actions. Most zombie games you just charge it, weapon firing and if a zombie got too close you would just lose a bit of health that could be replenished with a health kit then you carry on. But in 7 Days, zombies are more of a threat for you not only lose health but can get infected, bleed or even break bones, each of which require something different to heal you. I also like that you to be weary of what you are carrying and what you are doing as some smells and noises will attract more zombies.Overall, this is a great game so far and I can't wait to see what the next update will bring.A few things we are looking forward to:1. Possibilty of cars- cars would be helpful for scavenging far from camp or if one person has a broken leg and can't run.2. Weather effects- this could make the game more of a challenge3. Zombie bears- I'm not looking forward to this one but my friends are...A few suggestions we have:1. Add more wildlife that may be huntable, such as birds, fish, etc.2. Clans, groups or tribes that you can create and join3. Silencers for weapons 4. Tripwires, trapdoors, etc for setting traps

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								A really well-constructive zombie game, giving you the option of playing solo or going to PVE/PVP. This game goes from crafting out of any way possible to get the item you desire; while still trying to maintain hidden from the zombies lurking around (which have special abilities as night emerges). I really enjoyed exploring the map even though i died almost 11 times to finally understand how almost everything works. The crafting is great, the experience is great, but just like every other game, there are some flaws. Here are some pros and cons:Pros:- The lot of changing settings is enormous, you can literally change things on how you want it as far as how gruesome the zombies are and etc.- Endless possibilities of random maps.- Great crafting and building system (able to construct and reconstruct anything)- Loot respawn ( Searching around for items can sometimes give you pieces for a nice weapon such as a shotgun)- Hunt/Plant ( Animals sometimes lurk around which you can kill for food or crafting materials, also plantation is available)- Unique zombie experience ( Zombies are able to sense; either from you making noise or having food that attracts them. Also the zombies are able to run fast when night hits)- Great developers and feedbackCons:-Dated graphics ( This is still on alpha)-Zombies are a bit gruesome at night, you can't outrun them as their stamina exceeds yours 3x as much =-=.-Bad community ( Just like in Rust and Dayz, You will always find a phsychopath trying to kill you)-Map design ( Just talking about the map showing you the world, hard to find houses and such with a map like that)-Lag? ( Seen people complain about this. This game runs fine to me though)- Reset ( As the game goes through updates you will find your saved game wiped out, need to start fresh)- Bugs ( Still in alpha so expect it). This are some bugs to look out for though:Breaking a leg when falling/jumping 4ftObstacles sometimes standing in your wayUnable to look at inventory or map for a few minutes. ( Happens to me not too often but still does)I haven't played much so this review will be updated as i go along exploring the game and looking for bad or good things about it. It's a really fun game overall, i had fun playing it. You will die alot as you learn about the game but it will be worth it. Went from living on a self-dugged hole to a house that i'm at recently, secured with a wooden door and a couch for extra protection, i say that's an improvement lol.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								I deliberated long and hard about which early access survival game I wanted to buy. It was a choice between H1Z1, DayZ, Rust, The Forest, Stranded Deep, 7 Days to Die and Miscreated. I watched nearly a hundred Let's Play videos and read countless reviews before settling on 7 Days To Die. At first I thought it would be a tacky Minecraft+Zombies combo, but 7 Days to Die truly captures the spirit of zombie apocalypse fiction and survival gaming. The primary selling point for 7DtD is the ability for players to construct their own narratives based on their actions and experiences within the world. After 18 hours, the folks in my server have been building and scavenging and forming a community together while having to deal with zombie hordes and the environment. If I were to record everything that happened and write a script for a television series based on the events in our server, I dare say it'd be better than anything the writers of The Walking Dead could come up with.Also, the anti-cheating system and the PvE servers give players space to play the game without getting trolled, camped or hacked by other players. In short, the experience is complete and immersive without unnecessary or fun-killing interruptions.Is it worth $25? Indeed it is. In less than 24 hours 7 Days to Die has become my favourite zombie survival game of all time. Looking forward to years of continued developments and added content from The Fun Pimps!

								I was looking for a zombie themed survival game that I could delve into with my brother for a long time. I've played some other games with similar thematics but none come close to what this game has. content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'll start with the negative since that seems to be what most people read reviews for, but stick with me because following that rather short woe, I'll do my best to convince you to buy and play this game.Firstly, the bad: The Single Player Experience. The game, being an early access game, is going to toss you the occassional bug. A zombie that spawns far too close (see, "Right on top of you", p. 46), terrain that doesn't generate, a building that decides to collapse while you're in it, etc... If all you ever experience of this game is the single player aspect, these bugs might be considered game-breaking. After all, you're your only hope for survival - so getting screwed over by something that seemed unnecessarily random and cruel might be a touch rage inducing, and even if you do survive long enough to do something decent in regards to food, shelter, and resources; you're only ever one update away from being forced to roll a whole new world and start fresh. On the whole, the game is still worth playing, but single player does it a large disservice in it's current condition.The Great: Multiplayer. Maybe not "Hop on a random server" multiplayer -- but find a couple friends and take on the world together. With more people to share in the work necessary to not only survive but thrive, you'll do better than you could have ever hoped to in single player, and much faster. This takes the edge off when you're eventually forced to roll a new world - and, in fact, allows you to look past the initial bitterness of losing that awesome fortress you and your friends spent the past few weeks on because, "Hey, this new alpha build has more building types, merchants, and drawbridges!" When starting over isn't such a burdensom task, you can actually step back and appreciate WHY you're being made to start over and recognize that this game keeps expanding; bringing you more and more content all at no additional cost. The Awesome: The devs run youtube channels, post on their forums, and interact with players all the time - so if you're interested in staying in the loop about what changes are coming in the future, you actually have that ability, unlike most other game studios out there (you know who you are)... By being active in the forums, you may even be able to test drive alpha builds before their released to the public. The devs also seem genuinely interested to latching on to good ideas they receive from the community and, if it is at all within the realm of their capabilities, implementing those ideas into the game.In short: Good game, Good Community, Good Devs, Free Updates that would probably be sold as DLC if made by someone else = Recommended Game.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is the game all of us zombie fans have been waiting for.  Even now, as the game is still in its alpha stages, it feels a lot like a completed project.  It picked up where Minecraft left off and focuses on what's important for the pure zombie enthusiast:  survival in an open post-apocalyptic world... plus the ability to create and craft your own defensive structures and weapons.  Clearly more advanced than Minecraft, it incorporates construction physics and a next-generation voxel-based system which is a joy to play with.And of course it is multiplayer! One thing my friends and I enjoy doing is taking a few days to build up our fort.  Then, when we feel satisfied with our defenses, we'll turn the zombies on full throttle to test our barricaded abodes against the raging hordes.The amount of customization of settings in this game is quite phenomenal and it shows the development team is passionate about creating an experience which everyone can enjoy.  This also extends the replayability of this game into the hundreds or thousands of hours.  And with mod support coming down the pipe apparently, I can only imagine how this game might be transformed into the future.  Thank you Fun Pimps for a glorious game that will leave a long-lasting impression on the zombie survival genre for years to come.  This is a must buy for every hardcore zombie fan.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								7 Days to Die is a very good sandbox/zombie game especially when played with friends. I play this most days with my partner (she loves the game and plays very little else). The feel of the game is very good and the night times can be truly intense if you caught out in the open, and even in your base when a full horde comes it can get very intense.Things I like:- Building is pretty solid at the moment, especially if you install one of the modded recipe packs- Defence is a lot of fun and you can be very inventive- Cities are great fun to raid provided you don’t go in guns blazing- Graphics are not bad for an indie though with alpha 11 it looks like they will get a major update- Combat is straight forward and feels about right in my own eyes.- Crafting system is good again is event better with the modded recipe packs I Have not played on public server's so can’t give a review of them as we play on our own private serverThings that could do with a bit of an update:- Building variety/biomes feel a little repetitive in random generated maps, a modded prefab pack improves the buildings but the zones still feel a bit cut and paste at times. Alpha 11 will be changing the random gen so this may well change very soon.- Need to add some prolonged goals other than getting the Sniper Rifle/Magnum, yes this is a sand box but still needs some long term things to work for - skill system may fix this to some extent but they need to add some areas that are a lot harder to loot/get in to until your better skilled/equipped or something.- Mining/chopping feels a bit slow but this is probably to stop people destroying your base to fast on PvP servers.Overall for an alpha this is a very good game that I would recommend to people as a must buy, I know there are probably better looking games but the feel of this game just sits well with me. It is so much better with friends than solo this I cannot stress enough.

Early Access Review
								I've played all the survival games out right now. DayZ (mod and standalone), War Z (now called Infestation: Survivor Stories), Rust, Unturned, etc. This is the one I stuck with hardcore, and it's not even done yet. I've played since Alpha 1, when everything was blocky and there was no stealth system. That game was terrible, yet still held its own compared to most other survival games. Looking at it now, with a complex crafting system, stealth, hordes, random gen, and so much more that's been added since those first weeks... This is THE game. If you buy one survival game, make it this one. I guarantee ya, you won't regret it.Edit: After reading a few of the negative reviews, I have to add that this game is IN ALPHA. There WILL be gamebreaking bugs, in fact they released an update (A3 I think) that crashed my buddy's computer. This was before they released on Steam, ofc. Ever since, there have been no problems as far as corruption goes, but these things CAN happen when you buy a game that isn't finished yet. Not specifically talking about anyone in particular, just sayin'. As for the forum moderators, I suggest sending a pm to Joel on the 7dtd forums. He's a great moderator, fair and funny, but he's not paid to be a babysitter. He's an actual dev who is doing his part to create this game. Still, if you have a valid complaint, I'm sure he'll listen. He helped me link the game to my Steam account when he could've just sent me a link to Google and told me to figure it out lol. Point is, this is a great game with a great dev team, and though there WILL BE BUGS, they're doing the best they can with what they've got. This isn't Bohemia Interactive, this is a group of guys making a badass game. At 900+ hours, I've gotten my $25 out of this game many times over. Best game I've ever paid for.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								First, let me start this long review by saying this:  Don't let the EXTREMELY outdated video they have uploaded here in steam be your first impression of the game or the deciding factor for you.  The game looks much different and things have been changed and upgraded/updated many times over since that video was made.  That video appears to have been in a very early alpha and is missing a butt load of features and graphical upgrades.Moving on...I've played a lot of sandbox survival games (Rust, DayZ, Unturned, etc.) and this is by far the best one I've played.  The original alphas were very fast and the game progressed so quickly it felt like there was no point - you would have end game items in a few hours which really ruined the difficulty and challenge of the game.  But the last few updates (and there are many of them and they come quite often in the form of sub-releases or new alpha versions), have really revolutionized gameplay for me.You start off with basically nothing:  a torch, a can of food, water, and a decent (upgraded) bandage.  You then have the majority of the day to get some basic gear set up - find cotton to make cloth, use that to make some clothing, plant fibers, stones and sticks can be gathered to make a stone axe and a bow and arrows for basic protection.  Then you need to find some place safe to stay the night - the zombies shamble slowly during the day, but run when the sun goes down.Seems simple enough?  Well that's just the start of it, you then have 6 more days to find better gear, hunt for food, gather recipe books to learn to craft new items, level up to craft higher quality gear and weapons, scrounge for gun parts to make some guns (if you have the recipe - if not, theres always the single shot blunderbuss...not recommended against a horde).  Zombies can see you, hear you, smell you if you're carrying raw/cooked food, and feral hordes can sense you through walls...but they only come on the 7th day unless you set all zombies to feral mode.   And you REALLY don't want to be outside with no defenses when that happens...though nothing is more terrifying than hiding in an abandoned house and hearing a feral horde beating at your walls and doors...the dogs growling and howling...and the giant wasps circling your base - all waiting for a chance to get at you.And the game world is completely interactable and everything you do has an impact.  You let those zombies beat at your base long enough, they will tear holes in the walls.  Those walls will eventually lose structural integrity and sections of the floor/walls or even the whole building will collapse - with you inside.  And if you survive the collapse, you still have the zombies to contend with.  There are status effects:  bleeding, burning, broken/sprained/mending leg, dysentery, infected, scent, stunned, etc. and stealth mechanics (including throwing rocks to lure zombies by the sound they make).  You can tunnel deep into the ground, or try to modify an existing structure and build onto it, or build an entire base from scratch using wood (basic), scrap metal, concrete, reinforced concrete, iron, etc (with more to come) and almost everything is upgradeable or reinforceable.  You can (and should) board up your windows and doors, block entry ways with plywood, and for 7th day hoards, even consider taking down stairs with an axe and rebuilding them the next day.  Just be careful with whatever you build, as if the structure is not supported, or you dig too deep and wide, the possibility of a cave in or structure collapse can result in an untimely death.Definitely worth the cash and time spent.  The sense of gritty realism, amazing graphics and ambient effects and sounds, procedurally generated sounds/skies/terrain make every map feel like a new experience.  And it's only going to get more awesome when Alpha 12 comes out...minibikes and upgraded physics and new random gen algorithms.  What this game doesn't have, the developers are likely already working on adding.Awesome game, survival/sandbox/tower defense with RPG and crafting elements, well supported and balanced pvp, challenging pve, steady releases, consistently patched to fix whatever bugs are found, and pretty much the best early access game I've ever played.  I would give it a 10/10, but it's still in development and there are the occasional bugs, and the servers are kind of small (largest I've seen is a 40 man server and it can be laggy at times) so I will rate as 9/10.
