Early Access Review
								Below this is the current review. I opted to leave the original as well for reference.------ORIGINAL REVIEW: VERSION 7.11----------I played this game for a little bit when I first purchased it, just before alpha 6 was released. I was impressed. I played again later, around version 7.11, and I can say without a doubt that I enjoy this game. Having to take structural integrity into account to make sure your buildings and mining tunnels don't collapse on you rather then just as eye candy is a very welcomed plus. While there is equipment degredation and normal needs (food, hydration, stamina,)  I have never felt that these were too prevalent, yet it's just taxing enough to make you actively think about it.  In the end, it will be very interesting to see how this game turns out, but from what I'm seeing right now... We're all in for a very good game.---------NEW REVIEW: VERSION 12.4---------   Ok, I've put a good amount of time in the game between each patch. So far I am greatly impressed with the changes that the team has made. The game is starting to take shape and it leaves so much potential for mods when it's done!  But, this isn't much a review without actually reviewing it, so here we go.   Graphics: As I said in the opening, they have upgraded the engine and it now supports better graphics as well as weather effects such as rain, fog and snow. Unfortunately, for one reason or another, there seems to be some kind of issue with high end video cards and the game. That, however, will be patched out soon enough. The night sky looks great; first thing a friend of mine said when he saw it was "Woah, check out that blue nebula!"    Sound: The ambience is much, much better then it was before. Not saying it's the greatest in the world, mind you, but it's much better none-the-less. Before, it would just repeat the same one or two ambient noises. While they aren't 100% "there" yet, the new ones at least make sense and fit the time and area. Game sounds, such as shooting, could use a touchup, but it still sounds good enough and I believe there are plans to improve upon that. In fact, I think they recently updated the reloading sounds as well gunfire.    Replayability: A lot. There have been quite a few world clears (due to patches) over the time I've played this and I generally have at least 1 SP game and 1 MP game going on in tandum. Even now, with so many of the promised mechanics not yet in the game, there is still many ways you can change up the playstyle to keep it interesting. Things like: "This time I'm going melee only!", "I can only use a crossbow! That means I can't actually kill a zombie until I get one!" and "I cannot eat canned food or drink purified water. I must eat only cooked food and tea."I don't like to give numerical ratings due to the misconception that "7/10 = crap" that reviewers such as Game Informer do. However, if I absolutely had to I'd give 7 Days to Die (in its current state) a ... 7/10 (5 = average, so 6 = slightly above average and 7 = above average)Can't wait until it's finished.

Semi-Block system from minecraft with better graphics and visuals.. add survivability with not only food and health but also water. Able to play it in Co-Op? YES! Crafting system? But normally nothing distracting me from playing the game... after first few days you'll be wearing clothes anyways. The gameplay itself got significantly better to and as it stands is actually fun to play, run around and loot, kill zombies and so on. Improvement speed: Game is developing and taking shape in big leaps, something to be expected for an Alpha, I am "slightly" concerned about them stopping "before it's baked" because for me, so far I see almost infinite potential... Small Feature Wish-list:* More different kind of zombies, maybe even "boss" varieties? As much as I understand this game's desire to strive towards realism + zombies, but I would love some other hazards, like maybe some dangerous mutated plant-life or something. * More biome-specifics, like deserts need cactuses that are useful for something ect.* More "metals" ... Cloth/Wood -> Iron -> Steel is nice, but adding a few more "tiers" would be amazing. If they want to stay "realistic" they could do:  1) Low-grade Steel -> Regular-Steel -> Damascus or Stainless/High-Grade Steel* Copper deposits/ore or some way to "mine" it.* More pre-made mapsOverall there's plenty of great ideas people are giving to them in the forums already, and I think they're seriously considering the good ideas.Game-modes & variety:* You can play it solo undisturbed.* You can play solo and at some point have some friend(s) joining and "help" them out a bit. (if they want)* You can play on a server or a lan and start with friends working in coop or racing them in zombie kills count or "recipies learned" or some other metric.* You can play on a server and even have some sort of PvP. ( not sure how good that is yet )* You can edit the xml-file for custom random gens, alter zombie behavior, items spawn rates or quantity ect.* You can ( or will be able to ) download some player-created content or balances to adjust the game, once it's released or even already now.* You can enter cheat-mode and just be building a base, or a town, or castles... There's 1 concern as of right now... Building underground is very time consuming/difficult. Only thing I DO regret is that I got the game ( 2 copies actually ) for 30 Damn € a piece , when it is now 20€ and I feel "ripped off" in a way. Because not only did they reduce the price to 20 € a piece they also made a " 2-game bundle" that costs nearly as much as I paid for 1 game back in the days. =/ But well.. you win some, you loose some.

Early Access Review
								Below this is the current review. I opted to leave the original as well for reference.------ORIGINAL REVIEW: VERSION 7.11----------I played this game for a little bit when I first purchased it, just before alpha 6 was released. I was impressed. I played again later, around version 7.11, and I can say without a doubt that I enjoy this game. Having to take structural integrity into account to make sure your buildings and mining tunnels don't collapse on you rather then just as eye candy is a very welcomed plus. While there is equipment degredation and normal needs (food, hydration, stamina,)  I have never felt that these were too prevalent, yet it's just taxing enough to make you actively think about it.  In the end, it will be very interesting to see how this game turns out, but from what I'm seeing right now... We're all in for a very good game.---------NEW REVIEW: VERSION 12.4---------   Ok, I've put a good amount of time in the game between each patch. So far I am greatly impressed with the changes that the team has made. The game is starting to take shape and it leaves so much potential for mods when it's done!  But, this isn't much a review without actually reviewing it, so here we go.   Graphics: As I said in the opening, they have upgraded the engine and it now supports better graphics as well as weather effects such as rain, fog and snow. Unfortunately, for one reason or another, there seems to be some kind of issue with high end video cards and the game. That, however, will be patched out soon enough. The night sky looks great; first thing a friend of mine said when he saw it was "Woah, check out that blue nebula!"    Sound: The ambience is much, much better then it was before. Not saying it's the greatest in the world, mind you, but it's much better none-the-less. Before, it would just repeat the same one or two ambient noises. While they aren't 100% "there" yet, the new ones at least make sense and fit the time and area. Game sounds, such as shooting, could use a touchup, but it still sounds good enough and I believe there are plans to improve upon that. In fact, I think they recently updated the reloading sounds as well gunfire.    Replayability: A lot. There have been quite a few world clears (due to patches) over the time I've played this and I generally have at least 1 SP game and 1 MP game going on in tandum. Even now, with so many of the promised mechanics not yet in the game, there is still many ways you can change up the playstyle to keep it interesting. Things like: "This time I'm going melee only!", "I can only use a crossbow! That means I can't actually kill a zombie until I get one!" and "I cannot eat canned food or drink purified water. I must eat only cooked food and tea."I don't like to give numerical ratings due to the misconception that "7/10 = crap" that reviewers such as Game Informer do. However, if I absolutely had to I'd give 7 Days to Die (in its current state) a ... 7/10 (5 = average, so 6 = slightly above average and 7 = above average)Can't wait until it's finished.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								First, let me start this long review by saying this:  Don't let the EXTREMELY outdated video they have uploaded here in steam be your first impression of the game or the deciding factor for you.  The game looks much different and things have been changed and upgraded/updated many times over since that video was made.  That video appears to have been in a very early alpha and is missing a butt load of features and graphical upgrades.Moving on...I've played a lot of sandbox survival games (Rust, DayZ, Unturned, etc.) and this is by far the best one I've played.  The original alphas were very fast and the game progressed so quickly it felt like there was no point - you would have end game items in a few hours which really ruined the difficulty and challenge of the game.  But the last few updates (and there are many of them and they come quite often in the form of sub-releases or new alpha versions), have really revolutionized gameplay for me.You start off with basically nothing:  a torch, a can of food, water, and a decent (upgraded) bandage.  You then have the majority of the day to get some basic gear set up - find cotton to make cloth, use that to make some clothing, plant fibers, stones and sticks can be gathered to make a stone axe and a bow and arrows for basic protection.  Then you need to find some place safe to stay the night - the zombies shamble slowly during the day, but run when the sun goes down.Seems simple enough?  Well that's just the start of it, you then have 6 more days to find better gear, hunt for food, gather recipe books to learn to craft new items, level up to craft higher quality gear and weapons, scrounge for gun parts to make some guns (if you have the recipe - if not, theres always the single shot blunderbuss...not recommended against a horde).  Zombies can see you, hear you, smell you if you're carrying raw/cooked food, and feral hordes can sense you through walls...but they only come on the 7th day unless you set all zombies to feral mode.   And you REALLY don't want to be outside with no defenses when that happens...though nothing is more terrifying than hiding in an abandoned house and hearing a feral horde beating at your walls and doors...the dogs growling and howling...and the giant wasps circling your base - all waiting for a chance to get at you.And the game world is completely interactable and everything you do has an impact.  You let those zombies beat at your base long enough, they will tear holes in the walls.  Those walls will eventually lose structural integrity and sections of the floor/walls or even the whole building will collapse - with you inside.  And if you survive the collapse, you still have the zombies to contend with.  There are status effects:  bleeding, burning, broken/sprained/mending leg, dysentery, infected, scent, stunned, etc. and stealth mechanics (including throwing rocks to lure zombies by the sound they make).  You can tunnel deep into the ground, or try to modify an existing structure and build onto it, or build an entire base from scratch using wood (basic), scrap metal, concrete, reinforced concrete, iron, etc (with more to come) and almost everything is upgradeable or reinforceable.  You can (and should) board up your windows and doors, block entry ways with plywood, and for 7th day hoards, even consider taking down stairs with an axe and rebuilding them the next day.  Just be careful with whatever you build, as if the structure is not supported, or you dig too deep and wide, the possibility of a cave in or structure collapse can result in an untimely death.Definitely worth the cash and time spent.  The sense of gritty realism, amazing graphics and ambient effects and sounds, procedurally generated sounds/skies/terrain make every map feel like a new experience.  And it's only going to get more awesome when Alpha 12 comes out...minibikes and upgraded physics and new random gen algorithms.  What this game doesn't have, the developers are likely already working on adding.Awesome game, survival/sandbox/tower defense with RPG and crafting elements, well supported and balanced pvp, challenging pve, steady releases, consistently patched to fix whatever bugs are found, and pretty much the best early access game I've ever played.  I would give it a 10/10, but it's still in development and there are the occasional bugs, and the servers are kind of small (largest I've seen is a 40 man server and it can be laggy at times) so I will rate as 9/10.

Early Access Review
								As far as zombie survival goes this has to be one of the best I've played especially in early access. Most game developers make a ton of excuses, promises, and plans that never deliver, while this game seems to be developing smoothly while also remaining PLAYABLE. Most of the glitches seem to be fairly negligible from my experience so far.Pros+ Building Capability   Way better than rust or any of the prefabricated excuses for building that most survival games have at the moment, infact on par with what you would find in minecraft with a better look and feel to it.+ Scavenging   No more Chuck Norris vs. tree immersion killers like they have in minecraft, rust, and other games like it. Make tools based off of materials you can gather from smaller sources before tackling the big projects.+ Zombies & AI   They can smell you, see you, and sometimes simply sense you. This is way better than the husks of DayZ, or the rabid bunny rabbits of Minecraft.+ Updates and Content   Never expected when I originally bought this for the devs to be so loyal in their updates but wow they have been progressing this game like it actually means something to them, crazy right? Devs that don't abandon their community.Cons- Hard Start   I'll admit it's a bit hard to get started in with little explaination on how to get your first tools. I personally started out scavenging till I found a pickaxe and shovel only to find out later in the game that a stone axe can work however slowly and can be made from gathered materials.- Players Per Server   Unfortunately the only huge thing is the amount of people that can play before it takes a massive dive in server sync which can ultimately drop everyone from the server or just make the few people experiencing it rubber band like crazy. Watch your server population and limit who plays or else it will happen.

Posted: December 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								7 Days To Die has been around for quite some time now. I recently purchased it off a discounted price and I have to say its quite fun. At the start it was really frustrating, you will die from lots of reasons. Running into radiated zones, getting shot by bandits, dying from zombies and even dying from lack of food/water. Your basic stats include stamina,food,hunger and health.Stamina affects your physical activites that range from running to felling a tree with an axe. The lower your stamina, the slower you interact.Food/Water are your basic survival stats. There is a constant challenge to build a decent food/water supply and foraging for food in the wild is also difficult. The more stamina you drain, the faster your food/water stats will go down.Health is the usual. You would require medicinal items like bandages or first aid kits to heal.The game crafting is quite developed but theres still room for more. When I first started, i was totally lost and i needed to wiki/google search how to do things. Although the recipes are provided, you are missing some and you have to learn these by reading skill books that can be found in various loot drops around the world. Combat is moderate. There are a couple of guns, ranging from pistols to hunting rifles or shotguns. Crossbows are also available. You can even make a bone shiv from large bones that you may come across. However, fighting with zombies is rather dull. You just need to avoid their swipes. A huge horde can become a big problem. Typical zombie swarm problems.There are a couple of zombie types. Crawler zombies crawl towards you slowly and they can sneak up on you in thick vegetation. Normal Walkers have a few variations, infected women, nurses, cheerleaders and fat walkers. Naturally the fat ones would have more health and it would take more effort to bring 1 done. There are also cop zombies that hurl acidic vomit at you. Zombies will drop loot according to their variation.I managed to group up with a couple of people and setup a huge base. Normally if you're on your own, raiders tend to pick on you more. And when i mean raiders, those are other players that attack other people for resources or for the fun of it. You will die and you will be annoyed. But thats the fun. Picking up from where you lost and rebuild.I got raided by a pair of bandits and they jeered at me. Infuriating as it is but i teamed up with other survivors and continued playing.---------------tl:dr,YOU WILL DIE. ALOT.But you learn from those mistakes and pick yourself up again.Have fun out there!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								GENRE:Post-apocalyptic zombie survival game.CONTROLS:Standard mouse and WASD unless you are on a gay consolePOINT OF THE GAME:You build up your character, scavenge items, build bases and kill zombies.  There are always zombies to kill but every 7 days there is a blood moon that brings a zombie horde that will make you♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants.  You will soon discover that what you thought was an impenetrable base is play dough to rabid zombies on horde night.  There are also other players that you can align with or fight against; animals to hunt; and foul-mouthed NPC bandits that try to murder you.GOOD POINTS:- Voxel based terrain means you can terraform (dig and build) and, unlike Minecraft, the graphics are quite realistic.  The building mechanic in this game is great - much more user-friendly than other survival games like 'Ark Evolved'.- Decent character creator with the ability to play as a female- RPG element means your character starts out like a spaz and you can build up their specs as you level up to be pretty competent. Some skills are bought with points while others increase naturally as you perform specific tasks.- Lots of loot and scavenging.  Unwanted items can be scrapped down to their base elements.  Items of the same kind can be improved by combining them in the work bench.  Also since Alpha 15, there are now NPC traders.  - Lots of killing to do (different kinds of zombies, wild animals, bandits and other players).  There are a variety of weapons (guns you can assemble, crossbows, knives, clubs, etc) and as you become proficient with them, the more fun they are to use because of an increased chance of dismemberment. - Different biomes that are randomly generated- Minibikes to get around the massive map.BAD POINTS:- A lot of the hairstyles in the character creator make it look like your character has undergone chemo and is now wearing a cheap wig.- Currently no auto-run toggle means pinkie-cramps- The minibikes glitch into the terrain All.The.Time.  This is a 'known bug' which I'm sure is on the priority fix list though.- No third person (except when you are on the minibike).  I don't really mind this but some people prefer third person.  I read somewhere that they will eventually have it, but it is not quite ready yet.  - The game still needs some optimisation to improve frame rate but it has come a long way already so I expect more improvements will come along in time.MY THOUGHTS:As I write this review, the game is still 'early access' (Alpha 15.1), but even in its unfinished state it has become my favourite game ever, overtaking games like 'Return to Krondor', 'The Witcher' and 'The Elderscrolls' franchise.  I really hope that when the developers have finished this game, they will use the same engine to make a post-apocalyptic alien themed game.

								I'm not quite sure why I bought this to be perfectly honest. It's been sitting in my library for 18 months now and I just cannot get into the game. I do not have a particularly powerful computer but it can handle most games pretty well, and yet with this game even on low-settings it feels laggy, slow and my computer quickly heats up like an oven. I'm wondering whether this game is just poorly optimised. Either way, it makes the game almost unplayable for me.As for the graphics, I tested the 'ultra' settings and they just seem very poor to be honest - and not the sort of low-resolution style that is acceptable (e.g. Minecraft). It just feels like playing a game from 10+ years ago, and feels miles behind the standards of today's survival game graphics. I particularly don't like how the game just 'fades' into black in the distance.Furthermore, from the short time I have played the game, the sound quality isn't great either. Zombies for instance, will sound as if they are a metre or two behind you with loud footsteps, and yet are barely visible when I turn around.The combined poor sound and visual quality doesn't make the game particularly immersive.Although, perhaps I'm being a little unfair. After all, graphics and sound aren't everything. Game mechanics are also important - and possibly something I haven't played enough to truly appreciate. Either way, for a survival game, I am impressed (and a little bewildered) at the character's ability to pick up countless cinder blocks without any help and yet take 100's of punches to kill a zombie.18 months and I haven't seen a huge amount of progression to address the above issues. At this rate, I feel I'll be waiting years for a playable game to be produced out of this. Sorry, but life is too short for that.£18.99 is far too expensive for a game of this quality.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Thankfully I purchased this game after ignoring some of the previous negative reviews (including one top-ranked review that listed screenshots and all this back and forth) because it turned out to be one of the best survival sim games that I have recently purchased. . I can't speak for the previous state of the game, but as of right now it is a great survival game. Let me start at the top, with the gameplay. It's FUN! There is plenty to learn, see, and do. Scavenging around there are various weapons and items, all used for something. On the default settings, it is nearly impossible to survive a night by yourself - you need friends! This is not a single player game, it's meant for multiplayer/at least one friend with you. The game has plenty of different buildings around the world, all unique. It has a lot of different building materials, all can be reproduced or placed by the player. You can dig up carpet, take paintings and tvs, then take them back to your own base to place them. Weapons can be dissasembled into parts, all weapons and tools have durability that can be repaired. Once you spend the time to learn the game, it is not difficult to maintain your weapons or tools. There are plenty of different foods, some foraged or cooked. You have health, hunger, thirst, and stamina to maintain. The variety of places and things to scavenge means it is not too difficult to maintain these basic stats. When I say 'varied', I mean it has at least multiple items of that type, unlike several other games that only have a few of each type. Even though items like food tend to be the same (they have different stats but they are similar) it is nice that they have several different ones of each type, it keeps the game interesting to find new things.Update: They released a dedicated server component that you can download via Steam by clicking on Library and selecting Tools. If you scroll through the list of games in Tools, you will find 7 days to die dedicated server. Downloading it puts all the files you need in your Steam\steamapps\common folder.The multiplayer server component is included with the game and it works similar to minecraft or terraria. You host a world on your local machine, and you can create new worlds to host. It has the ability to create new worlds or continue previous worlds. Once you select to create or continue a world, it asks you to press enter before entering - but by that time the world is already hosted. In this way, you can start a server/host a game without actually joining - the server is not a separate executable like some games but that doesn't diminish the ability to host a server. There is a list of settings you can change, and that are changed for many servers. The number of zombies spawned, whether they can run in darkness, how hard they hit, increasing the loot, etc. Right now there are around two thousand servers when you browse for a game, some labelled PVE and others PVP. You can see each server's various settings when browsing for a server to join.The map is reasonably large for current survival sim games and it looks and feels like a recently inhabited world. Doors are blocked by chairs and windows are boarded up. I can't compare it to DayZ because I haven't played much of that game, but compared to Rust the world is much larger and much more varied. The game is easy to learn and get into and the building system is easy like Rust or minecraft.One unique feature this game has, is that the world is destructible and structures require support. If you are building a bridge and destroy the support beams, it collapses. Trees fall after you chop them. Parts of houses will collapse if you destroy enough of the walls. It's not very complex, but you can only build blocks that have reasonable support and you can not build over thin air very far.As much as I can tell, everything can be mined or destroyed. Interestingly the axe works much better than a pickaxe on wood, and pickaxes work much better than an axe on metals and minerals. The game has a shovel and an auger, which work very easily on the earth. It's really nice that you can find/create different mining tools that work better or worse on different materials. Guns, knives, clubs, they all do some damage to break materials down just not all equally well on all types. Metal is not difficult to come by, many items can be broken down into scrap metal. You can smelt scrap metal into iron ingots. The forge has a "mold" system, you need to build and place the proper mold into it to produce the output you desire (iron, lead, copper molds, bullet molds etc). Scrap metal can be used to build metal siding that can be applied to wood (or anything), which make them much stronger against the hordes trying to break them down when you are inside your home. Once you learn how to craft the different items you need, it is easier to survive a night and it is a casual learning curve.The game is easily accessible, the controls are intuitive and the same as many first person games. The crafting system is easy to understand and use, and supports queued/multiples crafting. You can find most of the materials you need close by, whatever your spawn point into the world is. Destroying parts of houses usually yields materials also.The graphics are on par with modern games (as shown in the screenshots in the game store). I am using an older generation graphics card and not the latest CPU, and as long as I turn off Anti-aliasing the game runs fine. The game has settings for visible distance, view angle, anti-aliasing, etc to allow adjusting performance.The sound and music fit very well with the theme. Sound effects work well, you can tell if a sound is far away or close up and in which direction it came from.Overall it is worth the current price, and it is better developed than other zombie survival games recently released at the same (or more) price...Please thumbs up this review if it was helpful!

Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								'Another zombie survival game' - you.7 days to die is a zombie survival game. Maybe it isn't fair to review this game seeing as (at the time of writing) it is in 9.2 Alpha version. But seeing as this review is mostly positive, it should be alright.There's a few things about this game I'd like to talk about:GameplayGraphicsCraftingZombiesMultiplayerPros and Cons overall.Gameplay:7DTD is a sandbox game. At the start of the game, you get dropped at a random place in the world. This can be one of four locations:Snowy mountainsForestDeserted cityDesertFrom there it is totally up to the player to decide what they want to do. To keep survivng the player will need atleast food and water. Shelter is optional but highly recommanded, seeing as zombies get stronger at night.As player you need food and water to survive. You can also get infected, or get diseases like diarrhea. Ofcourse those things can be cured by things you find while scavenging.Graphics:In my personal opinions, the graphics aren't terrible, but they could be better. To be honest, for the graphics it has, it should be easier to run. Even on a high end pc it sometimes has lagspikes or crashes, wether this is because it's still in Alpha or not I don't know. Either way, don't excpect anything fancy.Crafting:Crafting is pretty big, most things you see outside can be destroyed and used for crafting. You can chop down trees, or chop down entire buildings and make them collapse. The remains can be picked up en used again for crafting. Bushes, rocks, and grass are things that are mostly used in crafting, espescially at first, when the player is getting started. Later wood and stone become very important, for building a base.Later, guns and armour can be crafted, But those require molds and blueprintsThere's also a farming system, but I'm not a big fan of that. Just like real life the plants need time and sunlight to grow, but it just takes too long.Zombies:There's multiple version of zombies. Zombies are both called 'zombies' or 'walkers' A few examples that you're going to see a lot are:Bloated zombie: A fat zombie, does more damage, and takes more damage. Drops better loot as well.Nurse zombie: A normal zombie, except she has more chance to drop medical items.Zombie dog: Probably the most annoying type of zombie. Fast and does a lot of damage.Snow zombies: Zombies that live in the snowy mountains. They are all a tougher than normal zombies.Police officer zombies: They're like blaoted walkers, except they also have a ranged puke attack.Multiplayer:Unfortunatly, multiplayer doesn't really offer anything new. It's just a second you running around in the world, except he isn't controlled by you. You can track other players. Also unfortunate is that you have to rent a server to play with others, but if you know how to 'port forward' you can host a server without charges. More info for that go here:http://7daystodie.gamepedia.com/Server#Port_forwardingPros and cons:Pro:- Fun to play- Multiplayer- Good crafting system- Building is well doneCons:- More fun to play with others- Once you've set up a stable base, which includes food, water, and protection, the game can get stale.- Have to rent servers- Game has lagspikes and sometimes randomly crashesOveral I'd rate this game a 7.5/10, and it's still in Alpha mode.

								GENRE:Post-apocalyptic zombie survival game.CONTROLS:Standard mouse and WASD unless you are on a gay consolePOINT OF THE GAME:You build up your character, scavenge items, build bases and kill zombies.  There are always zombies to kill but every 7 days there is a blood moon that brings a zombie horde that will make you♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants.  You will soon discover that what you thought was an impenetrable base is play dough to rabid zombies on horde night.  There are also other players that you can align with or fight against; animals to hunt; and foul-mouthed NPC bandits that try to murder you.GOOD POINTS:- Voxel based terrain means you can terraform (dig and build) and, unlike Minecraft, the graphics are quite realistic.  The building mechanic in this game is great - much more user-friendly than other survival games like 'Ark Evolved'.- Decent character creator with the ability to play as a female- RPG element means your character starts out like a spaz and you can build up their specs as you level up to be pretty competent. Some skills are bought with points while others increase naturally as you perform specific tasks.- Lots of loot and scavenging.  Unwanted items can be scrapped down to their base elements.  Items of the same kind can be improved by combining them in the work bench.  Also since Alpha 15, there are now NPC traders.  - Lots of killing to do (different kinds of zombies, wild animals, bandits and other players).  There are a variety of weapons (guns you can assemble, crossbows, knives, clubs, etc) and as you become proficient with them, the more fun they are to use because of an increased chance of dismemberment. - Different biomes that are randomly generated- Minibikes to get around the massive map.BAD POINTS:- A lot of the hairstyles in the character creator make it look like your character has undergone chemo and is now wearing a cheap wig.- Currently no auto-run toggle means pinkie-cramps- The minibikes glitch into the terrain All.The.Time.  This is a 'known bug' which I'm sure is on the priority fix list though.- No third person (except when you are on the minibike).  I don't really mind this but some people prefer third person.  I read somewhere that they will eventually have it, but it is not quite ready yet.  - The game still needs some optimisation to improve frame rate but it has come a long way already so I expect more improvements will come along in time.MY THOUGHTS:As I write this review, the game is still 'early access' (Alpha 15.1), but even in its unfinished state it has become my favourite game ever, overtaking games like 'Return to Krondor', 'The Witcher' and 'The Elderscrolls' franchise.  I really hope that when the developers have finished this game, they will use the same engine to make a post-apocalyptic alien themed game.

Early Access Review
								Thankfully I purchased this game after ignoring some of the previous negative reviews (including one top-ranked review that listed screenshots and all this back and forth) because it turned out to be one of the best survival sim games that I have recently purchased. . I can't speak for the previous state of the game, but as of right now it is a great survival game. Let me start at the top, with the gameplay. It's FUN! There is plenty to learn, see, and do. Scavenging around there are various weapons and items, all used for something. On the default settings, it is nearly impossible to survive a night by yourself - you need friends! This is not a single player game, it's meant for multiplayer/at least one friend with you. The game has plenty of different buildings around the world, all unique. It has a lot of different building materials, all can be reproduced or placed by the player. You can dig up carpet, take paintings and tvs, then take them back to your own base to place them. Weapons can be dissasembled into parts, all weapons and tools have durability that can be repaired. Once you spend the time to learn the game, it is not difficult to maintain your weapons or tools. There are plenty of different foods, some foraged or cooked. You have health, hunger, thirst, and stamina to maintain. The variety of places and things to scavenge means it is not too difficult to maintain these basic stats. When I say 'varied', I mean it has at least multiple items of that type, unlike several other games that only have a few of each type. Even though items like food tend to be the same (they have different stats but they are similar) it is nice that they have several different ones of each type, it keeps the game interesting to find new things.Update: They released a dedicated server component that you can download via Steam by clicking on Library and selecting Tools. If you scroll through the list of games in Tools, you will find 7 days to die dedicated server. Downloading it puts all the files you need in your Steam\steamapps\common folder.The multiplayer server component is included with the game and it works similar to minecraft or terraria. You host a world on your local machine, and you can create new worlds to host. It has the ability to create new worlds or continue previous worlds. Once you select to create or continue a world, it asks you to press enter before entering - but by that time the world is already hosted. In this way, you can start a server/host a game without actually joining - the server is not a separate executable like some games but that doesn't diminish the ability to host a server. There is a list of settings you can change, and that are changed for many servers. The number of zombies spawned, whether they can run in darkness, how hard they hit, increasing the loot, etc. Right now there are around two thousand servers when you browse for a game, some labelled PVE and others PVP. You can see each server's various settings when browsing for a server to join.The map is reasonably large for current survival sim games and it looks and feels like a recently inhabited world. Doors are blocked by chairs and windows are boarded up. I can't compare it to DayZ because I haven't played much of that game, but compared to Rust the world is much larger and much more varied. The game is easy to learn and get into and the building system is easy like Rust or minecraft.One unique feature this game has, is that the world is destructible and structures require support. If you are building a bridge and destroy the support beams, it collapses. Trees fall after you chop them. Parts of houses will collapse if you destroy enough of the walls. It's not very complex, but you can only build blocks that have reasonable support and you can not build over thin air very far.As much as I can tell, everything can be mined or destroyed. Interestingly the axe works much better than a pickaxe on wood, and pickaxes work much better than an axe on metals and minerals. The game has a shovel and an auger, which work very easily on the earth. It's really nice that you can find/create different mining tools that work better or worse on different materials. Guns, knives, clubs, they all do some damage to break materials down just not all equally well on all types. Metal is not difficult to come by, many items can be broken down into scrap metal. You can smelt scrap metal into iron ingots. The forge has a "mold" system, you need to build and place the proper mold into it to produce the output you desire (iron, lead, copper molds, bullet molds etc). Scrap metal can be used to build metal siding that can be applied to wood (or anything), which make them much stronger against the hordes trying to break them down when you are inside your home. Once you learn how to craft the different items you need, it is easier to survive a night and it is a casual learning curve.The game is easily accessible, the controls are intuitive and the same as many first person games. The crafting system is easy to understand and use, and supports queued/multiples crafting. You can find most of the materials you need close by, whatever your spawn point into the world is. Destroying parts of houses usually yields materials also.The graphics are on par with modern games (as shown in the screenshots in the game store). I am using an older generation graphics card and not the latest CPU, and as long as I turn off Anti-aliasing the game runs fine. The game has settings for visible distance, view angle, anti-aliasing, etc to allow adjusting performance.The sound and music fit very well with the theme. Sound effects work well, you can tell if a sound is far away or close up and in which direction it came from.Overall it is worth the current price, and it is better developed than other zombie survival games recently released at the same (or more) price...Please thumbs up this review if it was helpful!

								I'm not quite sure why I bought this to be perfectly honest. It's been sitting in my library for 18 months now and I just cannot get into the game. I do not have a particularly powerful computer but it can handle most games pretty well, and yet with this game even on low-settings it feels laggy, slow and my computer quickly heats up like an oven. Either way, it makes the game almost unplayable for me.As for the graphics, I tested the 'ultra' settings and they just seem very poor to be honest - and not the sort of low-resolution style that is acceptable (e.g. Minecraft). It just feels like playing a game from 10+ years ago, and feels miles behind the standards of today's survival game graphics. I particularly don't like how the game just 'fades' into black in the distance.Furthermore, from the short time I have played the game, the sound quality isn't great either. Zombies for instance, will sound as if they are a metre or two behind you with loud footsteps, and yet are barely visible when I turn around.The combined poor sound and visual quality doesn't make the game particularly immersive.Although, perhaps I'm being a little unfair. After all, graphics and sound aren't everything. Game mechanics are also important - and possibly something I haven't played enough to truly appreciate. Either way, for a survival game, I am impressed (and a little bewildered) at the character's ability to pick up countless cinder blocks without any help and yet take 100's of punches to kill a zombie.18 months and I haven't seen a huge amount of progression to address the above issues. At this rate, I feel I'll be waiting years for a playable game to be produced out of this. Sorry, but life is too short for that.£18.99 is far too expensive for a game of this quality.

Posted: January 7
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS REVIEWThis game is a mess; and there's a great many things wrong with it from many in game bugs to a massive memory leak that will lock up your system if you play for too long (for me it locks up after about 14 hours). In fact I could probably write several pages listing everything wrong and/or missing from it....BUT... it's early access. The game is still in development; so I'm going to let all that slide and review it based on what it does right:This is a true sandbox; "do what you want". Aside from the 10 minutes worth of introduction "missions" to get you vaguely pointed at how to craft and where to trade you are pretty much left on your own to do what you want.That is, if you can survive. The "7 days to die" in the title refers to the Blood Moon mechanic where every 7 days a horde spawns and knows exactly where you are (there's no hiding on blood moon night). The rest of your week you can kill the zombies if you want to or simply hide from them (in many numerous ways). But that 7th night (every week) you'd better have your defenses built and be ready to face the horde.Where the game shines is really only in the world building mechanics. You can dig massive tunnels and caves, build towers to the sky and come up with any number of intriticate defensive setups. Or simply scavenge constantly and hope for the best.It should also be noted that the game is far more fun with friends. Going it alone can feel very lonesome and grindy (or you can use the creative menu to cheat and go faster), but to play legit without cheats you will want to consider finding some friends to coop with. There's not much else to say. The actual combat mechanics are a bit janky, during the day it's not too bad. But at night, especially blood moons the zombies are bullet sponges (and crafting bullets/arrows is a full time job). The current best (or at least easiest) method for killing them on blood moon is to glitch them so they run in circles where they can't hit anything (while you're up in a tower that they can't reach). While this method works; it feels cheap, and unfortunately unless you have friends it's sometimes the best you can manage solo with limited time to farm ammo/arrows.Anyway, I don't want to complain too much as the game is still in development with a lot of potential.I'll put it this way: I paid $10 for it on sale, it's easily worth $10 in it's current state just for the crafting/building aspects. Some day if they ever complete it and make the combat more satisfying it may even be worth full price. Just realize: it's been in early access for 3 years already, and it still feels like it needs another year or two at the rate they are going (which is kind of slow).Anyway, if you are looking for zombie survival meets minecraft with coop options, this is a neat little game with potential to be even better as they keep adding to it.

								This game used to be good, before the zombie apocalypse of Alpha-12 hit. Now it is definitely the worst game I have installed. Here's a list of what A12 made worse/ failed to improve upon. (Also the screenshots on the steam store look WAY BETTER than the actual game. False advertising.)-Game optomization. I have a fairly good computer, game used to run on Ultra settings smooth as butter. Now I'm having FPS dips, stutters and lag even on middling settings. Weather effects make the game run like garbage.-Game stability. It crashes too much, especially on snow biome.-Other players teleport/ skip around A LOT despite less than 50 ping.-Audio desync when other players do things, I.E. he hits something then I hear it 2 seconds later. Also happens with voice chat.-Draw distance is absurdly low, terrain visibly fades into fog even with draw distance turned up. -Not enough contrast. Night is too bright, day is too dark.-Weather changes waaay too quickly.-Parts of zombies clip through the ground when killed.-Trees pop into existance when you approach them.-Flowers/ shrubs shift and "dance" as you approach them, very jarring.-Strange black "screen" over some distant tree models.-Character/ weapon models don't line up properly. Try aiming a crossbow when you can't look down the sight, its not easy.-Character model/ texture glitches. My friend was wearing armor, parts of his body were pitch black/ flickering.-Everything looks slimy when it rains, even indoors. Looks very weird.-Trees don't fall realistically, easy to get injured even when chopping down small trees.-Zombie AI is just terrible, especially pathfinding. They won't be able to follow you up a gentle slope 1/2 the time. They will sometimes forget they are chasing you as well, or just run off in the opposite direction.-No more rivers-Bears, too many bears. They also kill unarmored players in 1-2 hits-Bows are useless, ingredients for arrows are too hard to find.-Points of interest are just too far apart, with no good way of finding them save by chance.-Unworkably huge maps, I asked a friend where his base was and he said "4000 degrees NE" I spawned at about 500 degrees NE, and it took a long, long time to even meet him halfway there.-Combat is very clunky, and no combat mechanics to speak of. Once you enter melee range its all a silly gamble.So yeah. I probably left out a lot; this is just what I encountered in less than 1/2 hour of play. I cannot recommend the game in this state. If the Fun Pimps address these problems in the future then I may change my review.

Early Access Review
								This is my updated review for 7 Days to Die (alpha 13)7 Days to Die is an excellently maintained game, recieving updates based on user requests. This is a great way to develop a game.The new GUI is excellent and I can finally craft items without the infuriating need to remember where to place resources in some silly grid. All you have to do is search for the recipe and click craft. This is very simple and very effective. Interacting with items is easy and quick. All you have to do is click on an item and you can see every action which can be done with that item. (By action, I mean eat it, drink it, drop it, etc.) The new GUI is also clean and non-obtrusive. There are no silly bars of ambiguity; it's all done with numbers, overlaying a horizontal bar. Genius!Zombies in this game are truly marvelous. Thanks to the recently added motion capture technology incorporated into the game, they now move how a real life zombie would move. They limp around in the day and still pose a threat in whatever activity you are doing. What makes these zombies so excellently designed is that they repsond "well" to damage. Something that some zombie games lack. If you hit a zombie, they may become stunned. The zombies will also be knocked back slightly and won't hit you the instant you strike at them. Their growls are scary and this makes for a tense experience at night.At times, the zombie hits will be inconsistent, which can be quite annoying. However, this is an early access game in aplpha, so you shouldn't expect everything to be polished.Just a little footnote, the zombies look excellent too :-)The random world generation is (in alpha 13.2) average. Biomes have no transition between them. By this, I mean that you may have plains (Savannah-like biome) suddenly boarder a deciduous forest. I hope that the developers will add "transition biomes" to make for a realistic experience. However, the biomes do not negatively affect gameplay, so therefore, there is nothing wrong with them. I just would prefer something a bit more realistic. I have noticed that caves are generated with very, very, very low gradients. I have seen multiple caves stretch for a good 3/4 of a mile not even submerging beneath the desert plains. This is a recent issue and I'm sure it will be fixed. (Once again, this does not affect gameplay, so nothing is wrong here either)Body temperature works well for the most part, but admittedly, it needs some tweaking. The wetness  system works well though.I have a few issues with the game, though. My first is with the hydration and hunger systems. I think that there should be an option (because not everyone likes hyper-realistic games) to follow the 3 3s, or whatever Bear Grylls once said. "3 weeks without food, 3 days without water and 3 minutes without oxygen." I'd love this to be either a permenant gameplay feature or at least an option. I think it's a bit silly how you can die after 2 days without food.The final issue, if not the most important issue, is the performance. This game runs atrociously. My laptop isn't bad. I can run Killing Floor 2 at 60fps on just about everything set to max, (apart from AA of course. Who would want that on?!) which I am quite proud of, since the GPU is only a GTX 850M. Anyway, the game runs at about 20-30fps. The only time I've ever got 60fps is when I stare into space. I would recommend waiting for the game to eventually become optimised, or to buy two Titain Xs and run them SLI or whatever it's called. Then, you'll probably get a solid 32 fps. :-DIn all seriousness now, this game is fantastic. The new update is very good and lots of people negatively reviewing alpha 13, just hate change.I am positive that 7 Days to Die will continue to grow and develop and reach the pinnacle of "survival horde crafting"ness.

								7 Days to Die. I like to compare it as: DayZ meets Minecraft. It's literally just that. You have to survive day and night by finding items, such as food, water and weapons. Not only with that you can survive, you also need to build a safehome, where you are safe from zombies and hostile-players. Now go try it yourself!I recommend this game. It's fun and you really put your instincts to the test. With friends it's even more fun, on a LAN-party it would be funniest. I can play this all day long, not alone though. Just like in Minecraft: you can play it for hours, but with friends you can play it a couple hours more.For a decent price you can buy it in the Steamstore.Rating:8.5/10No 9 or 10 because the game is still in it's Early Access, it's nothing near finished. That doesn't mean it isn't fun. The game is already this fun, can't wait for the fun I'll have when the game is fully released.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is a really great game of its kind and it's always been right from the 1st of my runs in it more than a year ago. Maybe even unmatched in things it's focused on. No storyline or directly given quests(update - it has some optional quests now), it's just about surviving under harsh conditions in the post apocalypse world full of walking dead (Or running dead, depending on which settings you prefere). Kind of a fine quality surviving, which feels like a perfect subsitute to the storyline and quests as trying to make it as far as you can becomes a storyline and quests by itself.Which ever stage of this game's developement  in eary access i've tried so far, they all were a damn great survival experience. Even at times when some other people were not content with any bugs, lags or just changes brought by an update. The only issue worth mentioning i had myself was that it can't be normally  played on full hard difficulty with always running zombies from the start, there's just no chance to survive with such settings (doubtful that i just failed to find the way to do this) long enough to call it surviving. Since i've picked warrior(4th of 6) difficulty with Zs running at nights and walking at days and feral as my  regular one, there's been nothing to complain about, except my own mistakes.The game is about being spawned on the map naked and bare-handed, and then collecting resources, making yourself some basic tools, weapons and clothes, building your base, hunting, growing plants and fighting zombies.There are quite branchy crafting and building menus there and lots of recipes of advanced staff you will eventually find looting different containers and dead bodies.Recrafting things brings you some slightly better staff each time you do this. No sleeping option, but there's always a lot of things to do at night, except maybe first 2 or 3 nights when you don't have enough resources in your inventory to craft or build something. I just punch a would frame or smth else then to get some additional exp. points to the athletics skill before Zs show up and provide some entertainment (good time to explore the crafting menu, too) . Otherwise the length of night may be adjusted to end at 02.00 e.g., never done it myself  though, it's 06.00 by default.The number of Zs in your vicinity eventually grows bigger, starting from the 7th night you have to deal with an attack of a whole big horde of them once a week, which gets stronger every time, so you need to constantly improve your equipment and fortifications. The game can be played solo or in PVE or PVP multiplayer. There's a good default map of a reasonable size or you can choose playing on a randomly generated endless map.Food and water gauge and environmentally triggered effects like cold, heat, being set on fire, a couple of deseases, bleeding, being stunned by a slap from a zombie or getting your leg sprained or broken or whatever else, are all of crucial meaning, each brings you special trouble and requires special treament or action.In fact, there's too many good things to tell about this game, but that would soon degrade down to unnecessary spoilers or epic episodes from author's own in-game experience. You better try it yourself, that's a must have if you're into fighting Zs and surviving. PS Just remember to find a safe place to hide or convenient to defend, a bow and several dozens of arrows before it's 22.00 if you set Zs as running at nights:)), 3 block long 3 high wall of  wood frames upgraded with wood and  a little scrap iron if you have some, with a row or two of spikes on the ground around it was enough for first couple of nights until the last update but now it seems to be 4 high, optionally with unupgraded frames or ramp frames(to be able to remove one to shoot down through the gap) around the top, and you will need 4 or 5 high, 3 or 4 thick and 3 long upgraded(as much as you can) wall with frames around the top to survive the first couple of hordes(days 7 and 14). A friend of mine says Zs can't dig down, so another option for spending nights is having an underground shelter with level(not a slope e.g) and as hard as possible terrain above it. Best of all if it's 2 block thick at least, fortified with a layer of upgraded wood frames and with support pillars (avoid flights longer then 3-4 blocks, to prevent the ceiling from falling down on your head). The entrance should be stopped up and levelled with the surface and you shoudn't be close to it when Zs show up..PPS English isn't my native, my apologies for any inadvertent errors i could have made.

								Destroyed, Cold, Hot everything you could think of to Snowy hills to warm deserts this open world sandbox filled with rather 'exciting but scary zombies' makes the game more intense and a more viscous terrain, So what is 7 Days to Die you ask?Well, 7 Days to Die or the acronym 7DTD what most people know it as is a zombie sandbox which has not only zombies but zombie dogs! which is rather scary if you ask me, I was once looting and completing reansacking a building then all I heard was a growl and it wasn't a normal growl it sounded alot more angrier and scarier so I looked out the window and all I can see is a dog circling the building and I was like "Oh lord." it wasn't what I expected to see so early but I infact did so I just had to leg it out the building and try to run as fast as I can into the wilderness of tree and grass. after a long run of getting out of there and excluding myself from the infected and building I found more building but in the distance I saw a desert with building nearby and this was on a randomly generated world, (You have two choices at the moment to choose to have a randomly generated world or choose a map call 'Navezgane') I continued you my journey and I found myself a weapon and a little bit of food to keep me going for the meantime and I think this is a really fun game to play, It's alot more fun with friends and I managed to get some friends to play with me on my server a while back and I played this when a bit later it came out and I miss some of the old thngs they had back in the day.I like the fact that you can now have vehicles, I have a bike and a underground bunker with on the surface a large wall excluding the dead and on top a small house to store misc and other items in case I am lazy to go all the way down, I didn't ofcourse make it all me and my friend did and it was ages from completion, We still have not finished the base what we have come to this day and still it's a work in progress. I recommend this game to everyone if you like first person zombie survival horror. It's quite atmospheric in some places where it can turn really quiet and audio of wind and whistles to loud screeching and infected crawling up on you. Be warned it can be a scary game but rather fun one aswellI recommend this to everyone who likes this sort of game remember to look at the trailer so you can have a basic idea what you are stumbling upon.Thank you and I like this game alot!

								Right now, 4th October 2014, this game has been improved a lot since I bought it, I guess a year ago. Here's what's happened since then: bees are not so noisy nor numerous nor everywhere, world is bigger, there's snow, glitches and bugs fixed of course, a little performance improvement, graphics improvement, smooth terrain, new weapons like crossbow and bolts, better crafting system (this one's a big thing), you can wear armor, forge system for metalworks, and improved multiplayer. I've not checked the quests nor randomly generated world that are supposed to be there yet.What's still missing: a better movement of enemies, cause they still move in 8 directions instead of having a free range of movement. Makes then harder to hit, worse combat. I'd assume they work out that one. NPC:s, dont know if there's any nor if they gonna add any, but hope so. Weather, there might be some, haven't noticed yet, but I'll change this if I notice it.Overall, I feel it's very good. They could work a bit more on the mood but I guess that's more a last line polish thing, it's pretty good as it is now. Very realistic for a game, different animals, lot of different things to craft etc. Many options on what kinda game you wanna play, like in zomboid: how much enemies, how strong and alert they'll be, how much loot, how long days, airdrop frequency... great customisation of gameplay. I really enjoy the long 240 minute day, gives you a lot of time to get used to the game without having to rush and you can adjust the difficulty as you like then.Works best in my opinion when you put a bit too much of a challenge for yourself and play with a friend and mess around a bit and go daredevil. Not for♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥who take the easiest failsafe way out, you'll get bored if you're one.

Early Access Review
								OUTDATED AT THE MOMENTReview updated/rewritten on 2014-03-15This game had some serious performance issues at its alpha launch and I considered the game unplayable. I fell in love with the idea of the game - a minecrafty zombie survaval, where you're never safe. You would have to survive endless hordes of zombies, charging your defenses, breaking it down, piece by piece.My biggest downsite uppon launche was that the game was poorly optimized and basically completley unplayable with a computor that's within their system requirements. The game simply wern't playable at that state on those specs and that really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off - i felt as if they tricked me into buying a game that i couldn't play, even though the system requirements "promised" that it would be playable. Sure, the game was (and still is) in alpha, but i felt ripped of at that moment, but is till loved the idea of the game and kept waiting for this to be fixed.I redownloaded the game earlier yesterday, to give it another chance, to see if it performed any better.I am happy to say that things have improved, it runs better now (though still far from perfect), but the game has seen so manny other improvements that i really loved. The "blocks" had changed, making the game different from minecraft - the blocks are no longer squared and it makes everything look and feel so much better. I've spent hours digging tunnels and it really feels like i'm digging a tunnel, not a perfect rectangle, they have added new zombies and also a stealth system, etc etc. The list goes on and I really like what's happened.My old verdict was that the game wasn't playable in its former state, and I told people to wait for a few patches before buying it. I told people that this game needed to be optimized and was bareley playable in it's state, but that the basic idea of the game was wonderful. My current verdict:I am now happy to say that so much has improved that I now accually will recomend this game to people who are interested in a more "hardcore" minecrafty survivalgame. This game is great fun and I see a huge potential in it, though it still could use some more optimization. If you are playing the multiplayer you notice that the server can't really handle bigger ammounts of zombies - if your friends allerts a horde in an area far away from you - suddenly there are almost no zombies at where you are. This game still has some work left untill it's complete, but it's getting there and I now consider it much enjoyable.

Early Access Review
								2 Hours into the game and here is my review.Overall: I like the concept and I found the atmosphere truly frightening, the sounds the zombies make, the difficulty seeing them and ambient music is quite terrifying at times. I would recommend this game if you like the concept and you are willing to support the developers financially. However the games is alpha, and quite early alpha it seems. Therefore below is a list of things I think the developers should work on as a priority.1) Movement and combat mechanics: the way you move and fight is very reminisent of games like fallout 3, it is clumsy and slow, this is bad with mouse and keyboard and terrible with a controller. I think they should improve this first as it will massively improve the enjoyability of the game.2) The inventory and crafting UI and management system: This again is tedious and slow to use and as it is necessary to use it alot it becomes a little tiresome.3)The game textures: They are pretty low resolution even on ultra setting, I think that this game could do with some major update to the quality of the textures.Final Remarks: I think developers get a little hung up on adding new content when they should focus on the game mechanics and how fluid the movement and combat feels.This game certainly requires attention in this area. If I were to score the game from 0 - 10 I would give it a 7 at this stage in development.

								About 80 hours in I'm still nowhere near done playing this game. If you love making forts then you will love this game. There is just so much to this game that I love and the upcomign graphics update will make it even more immersive.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Although I haven't played it recently I have enough game time on the "very" early access to say I thoroughly enjoyed it.           I'll start with game machanics; the crafting system is vast with usefull items pretty much all the way through, you wont want to leave anything behind because pretty much everything has a use some where along the way. The challenge of making molds for certain parts is clever aswell, adding a nice feel to the craffting system. It makes making the more complicated items all the more worth it. To follow on from this, buildings and construction are done very well. Searching buildings is standered, but the buildings them selves look very good for the enviorment they are in. For example the destryed city with it's half destryed buildings look dangerous and with the meterial strengh machanic (talk about that in a second) the buildings look like they are about to fall on your head, be careful. While other buildings like one found on its own in a foggy area look very creepy and mysterious. Construction is fun and simple while feeling really cool and characteristic to real construction. The fact you have to put a wood frame down first that can be destryed easily makes home building effecient and easy. Then using your tools add meterial to the frame, I also had to make frame scafolds around my house to get to certain reaches, very cool. This along side the meterial strengh system where some meterials can reach out further without support than others made building a home with the correct supports very imptortant. This just had a really nice feel to making my house and made it worth the effort.          The zombies! Like I said i haven't played it recently but when I did this was something that kinda spoiled the game for me. I'm happy to fend off zombies attracted by the smell of my raw meat, or empty a house of the masses because there might be vaulable loot inside. But when the game turns into a wave survival game, it gets pretty annoying. At random points the game will throw a hord of zombies to the posistion you where standing when they spawned util they see you. Now, when the position they are heading for is the center of your home, and maybe I'll sneak out the back to avoid confilct, they will happily tear a hole in your walls, look for you, and then tear a new hole out of your home again. So if you dont kill them with guns, 5 rows of spikes (not very asthetically pleasing) or lead them away your home will be trashed. I had 3 hords come attack one straight after another and frankly I was getting bored of it. This is probably the main reason I stopped playing.           The multiplayer is fun so long as you are with friends. The textures do well to make it look nice. And they are always adding new content, they seem dedicated.           Overall I did enjoy this game with the building and scavenging, killing zombies and finding new equipment, crafting tea (too English for words haha) and making molds, along with a very neat mining system that i love. Tis game is all round fun to play, gets some friends on, build a safe house and beat the crap out of any zombies that come near. Enjoy o7

								Many years ago, someone gave me a trial disc for World of Warcraft. I was given this verbal warning - "Call your friends and family, and tell them if they don't hear from you for the next 6 months, don't worry, you're not dead, you're just in another world."If you buy this game, Call your friends and family, and tell them if they don't hear from you for the next year, don't worry, you're not dead, you'll respawn on your bedroll. There are still some pretty severe glitches. On a multiplayer server, if you face the direction that most of the other players online are, you'll lag if your machine isn't top notch. Frequently the campfire and forge will glitch, and not consume fuel, or allow you to cook, frequently everything you're trying to cook or forge will vanish into the ether. Rarely when repairing a tool, the tool will vanish into the ether. The Easy Anti-Cheat is apparently a joke, a friend recently had his base destroyed by someone flying around with a rocket launcher, we're starting our own server because the game really is about surviving, and helping your fellow man.The zombie hordes will teach you what it means to be afraid to be outside after dark. The crafting system is amazing, you can craft all kinds of things, and even though you may know what you want to do, it could take you a week of real time to accomplish it. In the base Navezgane map, there are so many places to explore, things to find, zombies to slay. It will keep you on your toes, and you'll keep coming back for more, and more and more. I won't give you a pros list, I'm only taking a break from playing it because of item #1 on the cons list.Cons:#1 People are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. #2 if Friendly Fire is on, people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.#3 People are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.#4 Crafting in Forges or Campfires frequently makes you lose all your mats.#5 Sometimes when underground, the world will glitch and you're on the surface.#6 You haven't bought this game yet.In closing, buy the game, play the game, and don't be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ just because you can. 								Based on single player game.This game has improved no end since the early versions. 								i have played this game thoroughly fronta'back, and ill be completly honest. There is almost nothing wrong with this game. Except theres not enough game. now you see i have 209 hours there. what i didint know going in is that i would end up seeing most of the items, and weapons in the game, by the 7th hour. Some of handful of weapons i think in total including all melle theres not even 20, 4 blunt, 2 slash, a pistol, a revolver, 2 shottys, a bolt rifle, and ak, and 1 military grade sniper, along with a bow, and crossbow make up all the weapons that i can think of off the top of my head, besides the rocket launched but you will almost never be using that as i will discuss later.To be direct with this review is to say the game needs lots of updates, theres stuff to do, but as i said in the first 10 hours you will see everything the game has to offer, and the other 190 hours will be spent leveling the skills the game has, that although it has many skills, only a handful of them actually unlock anything. For example leveling the shotguns skill from 1 to 100 just increases shotun damage by around 28%, theres no reload boost, no spread tighting, no aiming speed boost, nothing like that at all.No to go to why im recommending this game. This game is litteratly 1 of the only, if not thee ONLY zombie survival game that isint in a self induced meltdown of bugs glitchs, hacking, and bad design. The guys that run this game do weekly casts of upcoming content, and look to the community for future updates. However.many of the updates never seem to add enough to the game. For a close example the upcoming giant update to the game at this moment would be alpha 15, whitch is going to up the graphics for the game greatly, increase render distance options greatly, add several new basic zombie types, and a few advanced zombies, no new special infected, but essentially zombies in military garb so you have to pop them in the face, some tree house stairs, along with a few new building items, and 1 new trap, now this might sound like a lot, except that 85% of there work time was spent on the graphics and render distance part of the update. The part essentialy no one really cares about. Ending: The game horribly needs at the very least half a dozen new traps, 20 or more new guns of varying types, and class's, several new skills, and update to existing skills to make them more worth leveling. plent of new wearable gear, not neccesarily craftable, but something that doesent conflict with the pain in the♥♥♥♥♥temperature controls, and above all else. The game needs more zombies. not just any zombies very dangerous ones, even the deadlist feral zombies in the game can be brought down quickly, there needs to be many new special infected, and slight detensed movement and feel to the existing guns to make them feel less clunky, or useless. ~jake

Early Access Review
								UPDATE: Out of all the Alpha/Open beta games i have player - This is the most promising by far.I sort of hate that im playing it so much as it will take all the challenges out of the final release.If you buy an Alpha release game - I HIGHLY recommend this.Over the past few years we have seen a lot of games try and re-create minecraft. Once DayZ came about, we then had games try and recreate that. 7 Days to Die gives me a feeling that these two met nicely. When I first played this. I was not overly impressed. I spawned in a barron land, which made the game look very empty upon first glance. I walked around to find a few cinder blocks and scrap metal on the floor, before having a dog just appear out of nowhere and kill me... Right! *Looks at the wiki, gets a friend, hosts a server*Okay, so as I started playing until now, I feel as ive seen more then just a barron wasteland, the graphics aren't that bad. Similar to minecraft, the game still works on a block system, however, the benefits are the fact walls can go N, E, S, W as well as NE SE SW NW. meaning the fandation work can be a lot more fun the minecraft.I did enjoy the fact the ground was not all as blocky as minecraft either. When you dug a hole, it blended well with the environment, often making trench and spikes fun to play with with friends, as you could make them discrete.I would like to see a lot more pluggins and addons for this game, user content. Possible reskins and remodels on this game could make it very good.My only downside to this game is the random gen world. Each one I have tried has been VERY spaced out, and I am running a couple of km before I find prefabs/towns together. I think if the random Gen world was touched up, this would be very good, as on the main map, I always see myself running to the same location and fortifying it.Overall I give this game a good rating and would like to see a lot more content added over time such as items like gates to be used with spikes or barbed wire to make trap usage better and more efficient.
