content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Im well over 200 hours into this game and have loved every moment after the first initial learning curve.  Make no mistake, the begining of this game is not for everyone and it does take a plan with some knowledge of in game mechanics to be successful.  This is not dayz or lfd2.  You do not go in rambo style and kill zombies right off the bat.  It takes practice and a plan.  The begining is hard.  With that said there is so much opportunity they are recognizing adding tons of different ways to die and ways to survive.  I have owned this game for awhile and did not care for the first few Alphas but now its pretty much one of the best I have played.My GF and i have both over 200 hours in game and love the base building along with the survival / treasure hunt aspects which they are only improving on with every release.Basic premise, you start out naked and alone in the forest.  Survive... the first 20 minutes of your life are probably the hardest and it gets easier as you gain levels, make better loot, etc.  Knowing things like crafting 2-4 stone axes in the begining and checking the durability so you keep the good one can go a long way from being "wtf this game is impossible why cant i cut a tree down" to "oh ok, thats how that works".  Hunting could definitely be expanded on at the time of this review there are only three animals to hunt.  Rabbit, pig and deer.  All with varying food recipes that you can make like stews and steaks.  Boiled or grilled, etc.  Farming is pretty cool and you can become self sufficient eventually (Baked potatos!!) and growing things like Coffee and Golden Rods really go a long way for making things easier.  Coffee and beer give you stamina regen allowing you to do more things without tiring for a bit while golden rod can help you level, quench thirst and regen stamina instantly.  Its knowledge of the mechanics and a small learning curve.  Once you figure it out this game is deeply rewarding.Base building is pretty good with a lot of options with the objects you can create like wood, stone, hay, dirt, etc.  The physics system is getting upgraded this next release so that will help with the destruction of things.  Its pretty satisfying building castles, houses and bases with moats and wood spikes and other defenses around protecting you from hordes.  One of my favs is placing dynamite sticks around the outside and shooting them when hordes walk by :DThere is a night and day system, the night time can be configured to have zombies be a bit quicker.  One thing about this game is they allow you to tweak or mod anything you want since its just changing a script.  Dont like the dogs?  Take them out.  Dont like the bees?  take them out.  Want more zombies, increase the spawn level.  Tons of options if you modify some .ini files plus they give quite a few tweaks in the initial world setup which you can change at anytime.  So starting out on a easier difficulty helps and once you get established increase it or increase zombie spawn levels.  They are adding weather in the next release and eventually you can freeze to death and the weather will have effects on you.  Desert making you drink more, etc.Like i said, its got a bit of learning curve but it is absolutely a blast and fun ride once you get the hang of it.  Awesome coop game if you just want to play with friends.  I anxiously await every release.  Make no mistake though, this is Alpha and you will encounter bugs.  I have yet to experience anything game breaking but we have had things like disappearing supply crates (the ones from the planes, currently was just fixed), breaking of legs too easily (also just fixed), abnormalities with the voxel system like floating water or floating land pieces, looting of animals broken.  The pimps are usually pretty good about getting them hotfixed but the game could use some polish and we all know that but its Alpha and polish is what Beta is for.  If you are not ready to play a game in Alpha then wait it out.  The forums are great for finding work arounds.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								You can build a super fortress and live like a king, or you can accidentally cut a tree down wrong and die. You can kill more zombies than Rick Grimes or you can eat broken glass and die from internal bleeding. 7 Days to Die is about choice, and it is choice that sets this game apart from other survival games.Essentially this game is a zombie survival game, but rather than be like Day Z or other games of similar enviornments 7 Days to Die has a large focus on both exploration and building. The greatest thing about it, is that it forces you to participate in both aspects if you want to survive. The game is brutal. Don't be surprised if your first night i the game is spent warding off 50+ zombies from your tiny refuge inside a local house. And as the game progresses don't be surprised when you're warding off more than that from your fortress built from the ground up by you. Did I mention that this is just the default normal difficulty? The game's difficulty brilliantly forces you to explore the world around you for necessary supplies, while also forcing you to build a safe haven because you won't find one anywhere prebuilt. So now that you hopefully have a basic understanding of the game, let's get a little more in depth. Exploration Exploration in 7 Days to Die is not going to be a big surprise to you if you've played any other survival game ever. You walk around a world and look inside any possible thing in hopes to find something of value. While it may not always make sense (oh sure, killing a zombie dog in real life always gets me two cans of gas), it is certainly rewarding to open up another bag of trash and find that last pistol part you needed to complete your weapon. There is nothing particularly original about the exploration, but it keeps it rewarding and entertaining so there really isn't much to complain about. I will however say that exploration is key to the game, as most supplies you will need to find to stay alive, especially in the beginning. In fact most items you can't even craft without finding schematics that teach you recipes for things such as ammo and armor. So there is always a reason to get back out there and explore, which does go aways to keep you interested in affairs outside your own stronghold. Building/Crafting This is where I believe 7 Days to Die really shines. Where as most survival games are about finding supplies and minimal building, 7 Days to Die is about finding supplies and  A LOT  of building. You are offered a wide range of building blocks and all around construction tools to really create and personalize your own base in ways not many games have. I hate to make this comparrison, but the building is most comparable to minecraft albeit with many more things to create. On top of buildings, you can also craft your own weapons, tools, armor, and accessories such as chairs and tables for your house. Very few games have a fleshed out building system like 7 Days to Die, and to miss out on it would just be a shame.  The World When starting up a new world you have the option of one of two things. You can choose their prebuilt game world "Navezgane" or you can choose a randomly generated world. While both are similar in the fact that they have buildings, heaps of supplies, and all different biomes on them, Navezgane is generally a little more organized simply because of the fact that it was hand crafted by the devs rather than randomly produced by a computer. Either way both world types are a joy to be in and produce a fresh experience with every play through. Several biomes are available in the game including forests, tundras, deserts, and burned forests. Buildings are also spawned frequently throughout the world, with each biome having its own set of building types. Admittedly though it would be nice to see a broader range of building types. Many of the houses are essentially copy/paste with small adjustments in a poor attempt to hide the lack of variety. Overall the world is interesting enough, but I'd like to see a greater variety between housing types to keep the game from getting stale. Graphics/Optimization This is probably the game's weakest point. The game looks ok, but far from breathtaking. To give the devs some credit they have improved the graphics dratically from previous builds I've seen online, but some work is needed. Speaking of work needed, optimization is an issue for this game. I'm on a pretty up to date PC that can run games like Battlefield 4 on ultra settings like a charm, yet I still get frequent frame dips when running the game on the lower middle settings. Once again this has improved through updates, and the game is definitely playable it would just be welcomed if the game could run a bit smoother. However there are many bugs that plague this game. While I haven't found any game breaking ones, you will have frequent issues of general things getting wonky on you. The game is of course in early access however, so this should be expected. Combat There really isn't too much to write about the combat in 7 Days to Die. You find or craft weapons to use against massive hordes of zombies. These weapons (as well as tools) must be maintained using varoius repair items to keep a weapons damage up. The melee weapons can be a little hard to usae at time given they require you to come close to a zombie to use them, but guns feel powerful and are fun to use albeit smalll glitches sometimes pull you out of the immersion. You also have a range of explosives such as TNT and mines to use againt your undead foe. Overall the combat is a rewarding experience that may require a little work but gets the job done in a satisfactory manner. Community/Devs The community is fantastic! Any issue I've had was openly welcomed by the community, and the willingness to help out was a welcome breath of fresh air from other games with a toxic community. And the devs on this game at The Fun Pimps are some of the most interactive and helpful I've ever seen. They release frequent patches and updates about progress, ensuring that this game won't be abandoned half way through like so many other early release titles. I have no doubt that this game will continue to grow under their development. Overall Overall this game is a unique and brilliant experience. Whether you love the slow and careful nature of building for a few hours or the fast paced rushing nature of killing undead freakbags I have no doubt you will find yourself having a lot of fun with 7 Days to Die. I've had the game for less than a week and have 38 hours on it. So just make sure you're ready to abandon your friends and family when you purchase this game!

Early Access Review
								As a side note, I'd prever a ~ vote rather than Y or N, but I'll ere on the side of nice because this has potential.When I bought this game, I figured I'd have a survival horror Minecraft clone that wasn't blocky, but was visually pleasing and somewhat realisitc. I was disappointed on one end of this. The graphical quality right now is a tossup. Damaging 'blocks' does change their appearance notably (Doors loose planks and you can see through them, et cetera), but the actual textures are worse than Half Life. No, Not HL:S, the original Half Life. In time, I hope to see this get some high-res textures, but for now, don't be too hopeful. They have bigger issues than how your rocks look, seeing as this is an Alpha-stage project.The fighting, while I did very little thusfar, is hit and miss, quite literally. I'm not overly sure how this is to work, but with a bow, I find aiming for the head to be quite difficult, and the crosshair is for nothing beyond centering your screen. The damage is seemingly low on even the most basic zombie, and therefore you're very much at a disadvantage with low tier weapons. A nice horror touch to my original idea, which compared this to minecraft at first glance. I'm more apt to play a game where you can't survive the night in the woods by punching everything you see.The construction in this game is amazing. I jumpped right into creative and have not been disappointed in the system for building. There are in fact 'blocks' of material, but you only notice them when you are placing building blocks, at which point you have a green cube and highilighted area within that shows exactly where you will place if you click place right then. Very nice, and doesn't subtract from the potentially beutiful end result when this game is finalized in the least bit.Movement, without the cheat-mode Flight enabled, is slower than the creeping death by old age of a newborn. I visited three separate biomes (Desert, Fallout Zone, and a Snowy Forest of some sort), and decided temperature has no influence on speed, you just are that slow. Maybe getting clothes helps (Yes, you start in your boxers//bra and undies), but I didn't bother with that because I was focused on the creative aspects of this game.Overall, hold your breath for later updates! This shows a great deal of potential, and just needs a few things fixed up here and there. This IS an ALPHA game, afterall.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Although I haven't played it recently I have enough game time on the "very" early access to say I thoroughly enjoyed it.           I'll start with game machanics; the crafting system is vast with usefull items pretty much all the way through, you wont want to leave anything behind because pretty much everything has a use some where along the way. The challenge of making molds for certain parts is clever aswell, adding a nice feel to the craffting system. It makes making the more complicated items all the more worth it. To follow on from this, buildings and construction are done very well. Searching buildings is standered, but the buildings them selves look very good for the enviorment they are in. For example the destryed city with it's half destryed buildings look dangerous and with the meterial strengh machanic (talk about that in a second) the buildings look like they are about to fall on your head, be careful. While other buildings like one found on its own in a foggy area look very creepy and mysterious. Construction is fun and simple while feeling really cool and characteristic to real construction. The fact you have to put a wood frame down first that can be destryed easily makes home building effecient and easy. Then using your tools add meterial to the frame, I also had to make frame scafolds around my house to get to certain reaches, very cool. This along side the meterial strengh system where some meterials can reach out further without support than others made building a home with the correct supports very imptortant. This just had a really nice feel to making my house and made it worth the effort.          The zombies! Like I said i haven't played it recently but when I did this was something that kinda spoiled the game for me. I'm happy to fend off zombies attracted by the smell of my raw meat, or empty a house of the masses because there might be vaulable loot inside. But when the game turns into a wave survival game, it gets pretty annoying. At random points the game will throw a hord of zombies to the posistion you where standing when they spawned util they see you. Now, when the position they are heading for is the center of your home, and maybe I'll sneak out the back to avoid confilct, they will happily tear a hole in your walls, look for you, and then tear a new hole out of your home again. So if you dont kill them with guns, 5 rows of spikes (not very asthetically pleasing) or lead them away your home will be trashed. I had 3 hords come attack one straight after another and frankly I was getting bored of it. This is probably the main reason I stopped playing.           The multiplayer is fun so long as you are with friends. The textures do well to make it look nice. And they are always adding new content, they seem dedicated.           Overall I did enjoy this game with the building and scavenging, killing zombies and finding new equipment, crafting tea (too English for words haha) and making molds, along with a very neat mining system that i love. Tis game is all round fun to play, gets some friends on, build a safe house and beat the crap out of any zombies that come near. Enjoy o7

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								You can build a super fortress and live like a king, or you can accidentally cut a tree down wrong and die. You can kill more zombies than Rick Grimes or you can eat broken glass and die from internal bleeding. 7 Days to Die is about choice, and it is choice that sets this game apart from other survival games.Essentially this game is a zombie survival game, but rather than be like Day Z or other games of similar enviornments 7 Days to Die has a large focus on both exploration and building. The greatest thing about it, is that it forces you to participate in both aspects if you want to survive. The game is brutal. Don't be surprised if your first night i the game is spent warding off 50+ zombies from your tiny refuge inside a local house. And as the game progresses don't be surprised when you're warding off more than that from your fortress built from the ground up by you. Did I mention that this is just the default normal difficulty? The game's difficulty brilliantly forces you to explore the world around you for necessary supplies, while also forcing you to build a safe haven because you won't find one anywhere prebuilt. So now that you hopefully have a basic understanding of the game, let's get a little more in depth. Exploration Exploration in 7 Days to Die is not going to be a big surprise to you if you've played any other survival game ever. You walk around a world and look inside any possible thing in hopes to find something of value. While it may not always make sense (oh sure, killing a zombie dog in real life always gets me two cans of gas), it is certainly rewarding to open up another bag of trash and find that last pistol part you needed to complete your weapon. There is nothing particularly original about the exploration, but it keeps it rewarding and entertaining so there really isn't much to complain about. I will however say that exploration is key to the game, as most supplies you will need to find to stay alive, especially in the beginning. In fact most items you can't even craft without finding schematics that teach you recipes for things such as ammo and armor. So there is always a reason to get back out there and explore, which does go aways to keep you interested in affairs outside your own stronghold. Building/Crafting This is where I believe 7 Days to Die really shines. Where as most survival games are about finding supplies and minimal building, 7 Days to Die is about finding supplies and  A LOT  of building. You are offered a wide range of building blocks and all around construction tools to really create and personalize your own base in ways not many games have. I hate to make this comparrison, but the building is most comparable to minecraft albeit with many more things to create. On top of buildings, you can also craft your own weapons, tools, armor, and accessories such as chairs and tables for your house. Very few games have a fleshed out building system like 7 Days to Die, and to miss out on it would just be a shame.  The World When starting up a new world you have the option of one of two things. You can choose their prebuilt game world "Navezgane" or you can choose a randomly generated world. While both are similar in the fact that they have buildings, heaps of supplies, and all different biomes on them, Navezgane is generally a little more organized simply because of the fact that it was hand crafted by the devs rather than randomly produced by a computer. Either way both world types are a joy to be in and produce a fresh experience with every play through. Several biomes are available in the game including forests, tundras, deserts, and burned forests. Buildings are also spawned frequently throughout the world, with each biome having its own set of building types. Admittedly though it would be nice to see a broader range of building types. Many of the houses are essentially copy/paste with small adjustments in a poor attempt to hide the lack of variety. Overall the world is interesting enough, but I'd like to see a greater variety between housing types to keep the game from getting stale. Graphics/Optimization This is probably the game's weakest point. The game looks ok, but far from breathtaking. To give the devs some credit they have improved the graphics dratically from previous builds I've seen online, but some work is needed. Speaking of work needed, optimization is an issue for this game. I'm on a pretty up to date PC that can run games like Battlefield 4 on ultra settings like a charm, yet I still get frequent frame dips when running the game on the lower middle settings. Once again this has improved through updates, and the game is definitely playable it would just be welcomed if the game could run a bit smoother. However there are many bugs that plague this game. While I haven't found any game breaking ones, you will have frequent issues of general things getting wonky on you. The game is of course in early access however, so this should be expected. Combat There really isn't too much to write about the combat in 7 Days to Die. You find or craft weapons to use against massive hordes of zombies. These weapons (as well as tools) must be maintained using varoius repair items to keep a weapons damage up. The melee weapons can be a little hard to usae at time given they require you to come close to a zombie to use them, but guns feel powerful and are fun to use albeit smalll glitches sometimes pull you out of the immersion. You also have a range of explosives such as TNT and mines to use againt your undead foe. Overall the combat is a rewarding experience that may require a little work but gets the job done in a satisfactory manner. Community/Devs The community is fantastic! Any issue I've had was openly welcomed by the community, and the willingness to help out was a welcome breath of fresh air from other games with a toxic community. And the devs on this game at The Fun Pimps are some of the most interactive and helpful I've ever seen. They release frequent patches and updates about progress, ensuring that this game won't be abandoned half way through like so many other early release titles. I have no doubt that this game will continue to grow under their development. Overall Overall this game is a unique and brilliant experience. Whether you love the slow and careful nature of building for a few hours or the fast paced rushing nature of killing undead freakbags I have no doubt you will find yourself having a lot of fun with 7 Days to Die. I've had the game for less than a week and have 38 hours on it. So just make sure you're ready to abandon your friends and family when you purchase this game!

Early Access Review
								Excellent game and one of its kind. Zombies are more threatening, creating a suspenseful atmosphere that no other zombie game I have played compares to. In dead island you can hack and slash a group of zombies, in this game they are just as threatening as Rick finds them in episode 1 of The Walking Dead; it creates the game feeling that survival horror gamers crave. While the graphics arent the best (yet), games mechanics are unique and realistic (if a zombie apocalypse were to occur) and the physics engine requires players to strategically construct their base. I am posting this after having my entire base attacked by zombies and causing my building to collapse, ultimately losing my game but boy it was a thrill. It is very atmospheric and exciting to play, and theres a lot to do. The only downside that really stood out to me was the sheer difficulty of the game. The game is harsh and if 99 things wont kill you, the 100th one will (i.e, you could be going great and so lucky then bam you fell off somewhere and broke your leg, good luck surviving). I could only properly enjoy the game on the easiest setting which I would HIGHLY recommend for new players. While fun, the game is extremely difficult. That's why it doesnt tire - you dont really get to stable plateu of feeling safe and secure even after hours of playing it. There is always the exciting suspense that horror survivalists crave. You are never safe, even in your cozy wooden shelter....And the game is only Alpha. I cannot wait to see what more content makes this good game even better.Would recommend 100%

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I speak Portuguese, so probably this review contains grammatical mistakes. I apologize in advance.This review is about Alpha 14.7. The next version (Alpha 15) will add new features!In a few words, it is a survival game about zombies, where you need defend yourself against hordes every seven days. But this game is not focused in building a base in the beginning and wait. On the contrary, it forces the player to explore the world gathering resources, since you spawn with nothing more than a bottle of water, one torch and few medicine. Each new release, the game is balanced and some resources (like food and water) becomes more scarce (I believe that they don't need balance these two any more), giving a better and bigger challenge - just like a survival game would be. There are some RPG elements, where each action gives you experience, leveling up the character, giving points to spend in some stats (or skills and perks, in this case). This is important since every day the number of zombies rises and spawn some harder ones. Also, you will start from pretty nothing and will have a progression path, learning some recipes and leveling up, until you can craft some better equipment (tools, weapons and armor). After a while it is possible build a self-sufficient base (or upgrade the existent ones), with forges, plantations and digging the ground for mining, which stops the real need to explore the map. In this stage it is possible hunt animals but you can not domesticate them (plantations works just fine though). I hope they add some new features to force at least some roaming from time to time (just my gameplay style preference, not a problem at all). Oh! I almost forgot... If you are playing in the default settings, you will need to be very careful to roam at night. Take a look for yourself - no spoilers. hahaThat said, it is a solid game even for an alpha. Not many updates as other alpha games, but the developers usually informs the community what they are doing in each minor release. Major updates only occurs in major releases (from alpha 14 to 15, for example), which will break your saves, unfortunately (I believe it is OK, since is an alpha). Most bad reviews are about the save breaks from release to release. Be advised!It is a voxel game, so, if you do not like, that is not for you. They implemented physics, so take care about foundations! If you want to build a mine, for example, you will need some support pillars. The same goes to walkways and bridges. Almost everything is destroyable... I believe only bedrock (the foundation of the game world) is not. Not sure about the height limits of the world, but is pretty big. The default map also is pretty big in length too. It will take a lot of time to explore and loot all.I'm not adept of high graphics settings in my games, but I see a lot of people saying they are having problems with performance. I play in medium with my laptop (i5, 6GB RAM and nVidia 930M) only with 'no shadows' and it runs fine. Every update and release they are trying to optimize the game as much as they can, so let's hope.As I said, if you keep in mind that is an alpha game and they are working every day to bring some new features and balance the game, it is a very good and fun game. Pretty solid in features and gameplay. I believe that optimization, as I said, is the only bigger problem, but the developers are working hard on this. I believe the game has some problem about some hit boxes as well, where some zombies can hit you from distance even if their arm don't hit you in the animation.It is known that some MAC users are having problems each new release, but it seems like is and engine issue... So, if you are a MAC user, you need to go to the forums and find if the issues were fixed. In the Windows, where I play, I had no problems.Never played multiplayer, but the mechanics is the same.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you were like me you seen the graphics in this game and said nope not for me...but I liked the concept of the game. My brother in-law bought this for me as a gift during the summer sale and I have been addicted ever since. Im going to list some pros and cons of this game in my eyes.Pros-The game play and core concept are amazing its like rust/ dying light / mine craft /day z all mixed together. The crafting and amount of craft able items/lootable items is nothing short of amazing they have really put some thought into a zombie apocalypse situation. Everything from caned cat food to a mini bike!I like the fact that you can dig down in the earth and build a base... this gives you a feeling of security...i mean all major military installations are underground bunkers why wouldn't your base be?You can garden food...but not after a lot of searching for seeds. Nothing is handed to you in this game, if  you are thirsty yea you could just drink straight from the lake but you run the chance of getting dysentery, which takes antibiotics (which are also craft-able) to cure it.  Hunger and thirst are a real problem in this game and ive only played on lvl 3 difficulty it goes to 6 to my knowledge. I play with 3 other people on a private server and we had a hard time with hunger for a while we set up base right next to a water source. But we are just not to the point 17 hours of game play in that we have a garden big enough to sustain us but we still have to hunt. This unlike other games drives your to keep grinding!Every 7 days! Well every 7 days a horde of zombies come to your location on the map and destory everything in sight.. my first 7th night was not bad we read some reviews and put up a 5 deep spike wall around our base not one zombie made it through I was kind of sad I thought it would be tougher Day 14-- keep the same spike wall didnt think much about it...went up after dark and the zombies had destroyed the spike wall and started to dig down to or base!!!Day 21-- We beefed up our base and added reinforced metal doors...it didnt work the feral zombies smashed everything and were still alive in the morning.. about 5 of them we had to go out our escape tunnel that lead adjacent to the main entrance just to be able to kill them it took around 20 shots from a bow each to kill them even after they we already weakened from the  spikes.Day 28-- still hasnt come but ive read up and every 7 days it gets worse and worse. Up until day 49 which its suppose to be the peak. This also makes you constantly grind and gather resources and upgrade you base all the time the first two days after a horde we gather wood, food, etc after that we build the base and loot for blue prints gun parts etc.You can host your own server! This is one of the best things if you have a group you can play with no hackers, no bs, just game play!!!! Cons-Poorly optimized--> I have ran this on both my desktop and my gaming laptops both with Intel I7s desktop has Gtx 970 and Lappy has a GTX 880m.  Both get random lag spikes the 970 really never drops below 60fps. The 880m will drop to around 35-40 but averages around 45fps.  These cards should eat this game up no problem the laptop will play DOOM 2016 on ultra at 45fps. But the devs seem to constantly be updating the game so no worries there. Zombies swim like dolphins when they hit the water you are screwed if you mess up and get near one while swimming you are done for. Random bugs → But its still in alpha so no points docked there!Price of the game I feel $24.99 for this game is way way to high. I would gladly pay $15.00 for a game at this stage of development no problem. If the graphics were better I would have no problem paying $40.00 for a game like this. But that's really my only problems with the game.  Overall I would give this game a 8/10 and a must buy if its on sale! Dont let the graphics fool you of how fun the game play can be! If they make it more graphic this could be hands down the highest selling zombie survival game out there!!!

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								You can build a super fortress and live like a king, or you can accidentally cut a tree down wrong and die. You can kill more zombies than Rick Grimes or you can eat broken glass and die from internal bleeding. 7 Days to Die is about choice, and it is choice that sets this game apart from other survival games.Essentially this game is a zombie survival game, but rather than be like Day Z or other games of similar enviornments 7 Days to Die has a large focus on both exploration and building. The greatest thing about it, is that it forces you to participate in both aspects if you want to survive. The game is brutal. Don't be surprised if your first night i the game is spent warding off 50+ zombies from your tiny refuge inside a local house. And as the game progresses don't be surprised when you're warding off more than that from your fortress built from the ground up by you. Did I mention that this is just the default normal difficulty? The game's difficulty brilliantly forces you to explore the world around you for necessary supplies, while also forcing you to build a safe haven because you won't find one anywhere prebuilt. So now that you hopefully have a basic understanding of the game, let's get a little more in depth. Exploration Exploration in 7 Days to Die is not going to be a big surprise to you if you've played any other survival game ever. You walk around a world and look inside any possible thing in hopes to find something of value. While it may not always make sense (oh sure, killing a zombie dog in real life always gets me two cans of gas), it is certainly rewarding to open up another bag of trash and find that last pistol part you needed to complete your weapon. There is nothing particularly original about the exploration, but it keeps it rewarding and entertaining so there really isn't much to complain about. I will however say that exploration is key to the game, as most supplies you will need to find to stay alive, especially in the beginning. In fact most items you can't even craft without finding schematics that teach you recipes for things such as ammo and armor. So there is always a reason to get back out there and explore, which does go aways to keep you interested in affairs outside your own stronghold. Building/Crafting This is where I believe 7 Days to Die really shines. Where as most survival games are about finding supplies and minimal building, 7 Days to Die is about finding supplies and  A LOT  of building. You are offered a wide range of building blocks and all around construction tools to really create and personalize your own base in ways not many games have. I hate to make this comparrison, but the building is most comparable to minecraft albeit with many more things to create. On top of buildings, you can also craft your own weapons, tools, armor, and accessories such as chairs and tables for your house. Very few games have a fleshed out building system like 7 Days to Die, and to miss out on it would just be a shame.  The World When starting up a new world you have the option of one of two things. You can choose their prebuilt game world "Navezgane" or you can choose a randomly generated world. While both are similar in the fact that they have buildings, heaps of supplies, and all different biomes on them, Navezgane is generally a little more organized simply because of the fact that it was hand crafted by the devs rather than randomly produced by a computer. Either way both world types are a joy to be in and produce a fresh experience with every play through. Several biomes are available in the game including forests, tundras, deserts, and burned forests. Buildings are also spawned frequently throughout the world, with each biome having its own set of building types. Admittedly though it would be nice to see a broader range of building types. Many of the houses are essentially copy/paste with small adjustments in a poor attempt to hide the lack of variety. Overall the world is interesting enough, but I'd like to see a greater variety between housing types to keep the game from getting stale. Graphics/Optimization This is probably the game's weakest point. The game looks ok, but far from breathtaking. To give the devs some credit they have improved the graphics dratically from previous builds I've seen online, but some work is needed. Speaking of work needed, optimization is an issue for this game. I'm on a pretty up to date PC that can run games like Battlefield 4 on ultra settings like a charm, yet I still get frequent frame dips when running the game on the lower middle settings. Once again this has improved through updates, and the game is definitely playable it would just be welcomed if the game could run a bit smoother. However there are many bugs that plague this game. While I haven't found any game breaking ones, you will have frequent issues of general things getting wonky on you. The game is of course in early access however, so this should be expected. Combat There really isn't too much to write about the combat in 7 Days to Die. You find or craft weapons to use against massive hordes of zombies. These weapons (as well as tools) must be maintained using varoius repair items to keep a weapons damage up. The melee weapons can be a little hard to usae at time given they require you to come close to a zombie to use them, but guns feel powerful and are fun to use albeit smalll glitches sometimes pull you out of the immersion. You also have a range of explosives such as TNT and mines to use againt your undead foe. Overall the combat is a rewarding experience that may require a little work but gets the job done in a satisfactory manner. Community/Devs The community is fantastic! Any issue I've had was openly welcomed by the community, and the willingness to help out was a welcome breath of fresh air from other games with a toxic community. And the devs on this game at The Fun Pimps are some of the most interactive and helpful I've ever seen. They release frequent patches and updates about progress, ensuring that this game won't be abandoned half way through like so many other early release titles. I have no doubt that this game will continue to grow under their development. Overall Overall this game is a unique and brilliant experience. Whether you love the slow and careful nature of building for a few hours or the fast paced rushing nature of killing undead freakbags I have no doubt you will find yourself having a lot of fun with 7 Days to Die. I've had the game for less than a week and have 38 hours on it. So just make sure you're ready to abandon your friends and family when you purchase this game!

Early Access Review
								*Review of Alpha 11.6*My hapless survivor awoke in a wilderness next to a beat up car with nothing but a few scraps of clothing to hide her nakedness. She was beaten bloody by zombies time after time, finally holing up in an abandoned lodge in a wood where she cowered overnight, suffering with diahorrea and chilled to the bone by the low moaning of zombies outside the door. It seemed like she'd never find another thing to eat or drink.Fast forward to week 2, and she is now living in a deep underground bunker, mining and forging by night and exploring towns overrun by zombies in the daytime, whilst also working part time as a lumberjack and gardener. Things are certainly looking up!This game is brutally hard to begin with. You will die multiple times trying to figure things out and the first few days in-game are a truly punishing experience. However, once you find your feet and have your defences and life support set up, I feel like it becomes almost too easy. I am still really enjoying building and exploring, but after 30 or so hours I feel I have found most stuff there is to find. For a game that's still only in alpha, I'd say it's really really fun though, particularly if you have an imagination! I've only played solo but I would wager that playing with friends would make it even better.I can see this game becoming a real classic if the devs continue to introduce awesome new stuff. NPCs would really give it a lift, particularly if there were assaults on your base from roaming gangs or something.

								7 days...You will die in 7 days...7 Days to Die can be pretty challenging. The zombies are way harder to deal with than zombies from other games like DayZ or H1Z1. This game actually puts a little more focus into fighting zombies and defending your base from them. They're not just all slow-walking target practices, but they actually start running during the  night which makes you actually go into hiding or you'll die.On the crafting side, it's pretty much like Minecraft in that you place everything as blocks. There is actually a pretty deep crafting system in this game and there are loads upon loads of things to make. You can pretty much get creative and build anything you want. However, you better have a good defense or what you build will probably be destroyed during the night.I've died many times. 53 times to be exact. 1 death for each hour I've played, but once you start getting how everything works, you start to live longer. Once you're done building a base and make it zombie-proof however, you may start running out of things to do. So let your creative juices run wild and definitely play this game with friends!See you on the other side.Godspeed!

								I have to say. This game has actually came a long way since its release. I played this game quite often when they first released into Alpha. Right! *Looks at the wiki, gets a friend, hosts a server*Okay, so as I started playing until now, I feel as ive seen more then just a barron wasteland, the graphics aren't that bad. Similar to minecraft, the game still works on a block system, however, the benefits are the fact walls can go N, E, S, W as well as NE SE SW NW. meaning the fandation work can be a lot more fun the minecraft.I did enjoy the fact the ground was not all as blocky as minecraft either. 								Logged 150 hours here. I personally recommend this game. It is a very fun and interesting game that you can play hours on. I am a very picky person when it comes to my games, but I really like this one. It is a very hard game to get a hold of to be good. It is totally worth it after the first ten hours of learning how to rock at it. I like the graphics and all the gameplay except the dogs. The dogs are the bane of my existence. They used to be bearable when they spawned rarely, but now that they spawn all over, the game has become extremely hard. It is a very fun game. IF you have time.EDIT #1: Logged 230 hours here. Alpha 13. I have come to love and hate this game. It was a really great game once upon a time... There were some rough patches recently that made the game quite unplayable. I was rather disappointed considering that this is the game the I have logged the most hours on. It was a great game a year ago, but now it is just a another zombie killing game. I like the new system for building and gathering resources. It is a change for the better in this game. Although, it still has a long ways to go. I seem to travel about three thousand whatevers from the middle and the map seems to become a total mess. There are no rivers anymore. I really liked the rivers; they were able to save my butt a couple times when a horde would start chasing me. The maps have just gotten a bit ugly now. If you want water you might just have to travel ten kilometers to get it. I like that little aspect, but when the only nearest water is a tiny pond that has three buckets worth of water it can get a bit difficult. I may be attached to the old memories that I have of this game frome when I used to play it, but that helps me prove my point here. What I am trying to say is that if the developers really want to make a big difference to the game they should go way back and implement a few new things there. Like the minibike for instance is a great idea that helps me in my gameplay, but can become a nuesance. It is an extremely glitchy peice of work. I was driving to my base one day when all of a sudden it felll through the world and I havent been able to find it since. The dogs still seem a bit over powered but that might be me. And I am going to say the same about this patch as I did the other; you can play this game and you will probably enjoy, but you are going to sacrifice a lot of time learning how to play and adapt to the changes as new updates come out. I still recommend this game as of 1/4/2016. No matter how hard they mess this game up I will most likely like it. It has a great concept and I am a very picky person when it comes to my games.

								2 Hours into the game and here is my review.Overall: I like the concept and I found the atmosphere truly frightening, the sounds the zombies make, the difficulty seeing them and ambient music is quite terrifying at times. content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Feels like Skyrim, Dead Island, and Minecraft had a lovely, slightly glitchy baby. As each Alpha update comes out, the variety of things to do and the fun potential increases. Zombies are getting harder to kill, physics more realistic, and the community participation on servers is A+The game itself lfeels more like Beta than Alpha, with a few more obvious weird spots (Strange deer running animation and occasional floating buildings come to mind) Why do I have so damn much fun playing this?It has ALL THE THINGS. Hunting/Gathering? Yup. Plenty of variety in that, plants need sunlight and some need tilled earth, and certain items can only be found by exploring dangerous areas. Building artistry? Have at it! While you can't MAKE floating cities very easily, like is possible in minecraft, there is still a TON of different blocks and rotations and ways they support each other that makes customizing your own place - or building a grand castle - something that is both time consuming and very satisfying. ZOMBIE SLAYING GOODNESS - Hell yeah~ There are normal zombies that take a headshot and fall, and variations all the way up to Feral zombies, who take 10 shots to the head with a pistol, and keep coming at you. Run. Run for the hills. Your armor cannot save you against that horde. EXPLODE EVERYTHING! - With a bit of time invested in mining and crafting, you can build some pretty stellar explosives and weapons - even a minibike now, for faster travel! All in all, even in its alpha stage, this is my absolute favorite game. It has the 'Huge, explorable world with acceptable graphics for immersion' appeal of skyrim, 'EVERYTHING IS BLOCKS YOU CAN BUILD IT ALL' bonus of Minecraft, with lots of scary zombies that you may or may not want to approach, because they could potentially kick your♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Reviewed edited to account for the massive amounts of updates that have been added to the game since I last played.Tl;dr: The devs have taken this game a long way since it was added to early access (for that alone, how many early access survival/zombie games compare?) For the most part the devs have delivered on there promises when it comes to content. This game is easily one of the best survival and voxel based games that I've played. 7 days to die offers a LOT for an alpha game. The survival and crafting mechanics are in a depth that beats most fully released games. The construction of bases offers vast amount of variety and care, and if youre the type who prefers doing so with an editor mode, its an option available to you. Upon starting a game you have a multitude of options to choose from that mark the settings of your world, including the value of loot you can find, the difficulty of enemies (via changing zombie behavior and so forth) and the strength of structures, among so much more.The combat is similar to most other fps survival games, however much of what you can fight with comes from either scavenging or crafting it yourself. Based on your settings things can be found in plenty, though among my friends and I, we prefer a difficult to survive and rarely scavengable outlook. We like to struggle and this game provides that option for us.If you enjoy zombie survival, base crafting, and character development this game has everything you could want and more. Don't let the looks fool you, this game is easily top-tier when it comes to the survival market, which as of late has been flooded with nonsense. 10/10 would recommend.

Early Access Review
								Excellent game and one of its kind. Zombies are more threatening, creating a suspenseful atmosphere that no other zombie game I have played compares to. In dead island you can hack and slash a group of zombies, in this game they are just as threatening as Rick finds them in episode 1 of The Walking Dead; it creates the game feeling that survival horror gamers crave. While the graphics arent the best (yet), games mechanics are unique and realistic (if a zombie apocalypse were to occur) and the physics engine requires players to strategically construct their base. I am posting this after having my entire base attacked by zombies and causing my building to collapse, ultimately losing my game but boy it was a thrill. It is very atmospheric and exciting to play, and theres a lot to do. The only downside that really stood out to me was the sheer difficulty of the game. The game is harsh and if 99 things wont kill you, the 100th one will (i.e, you could be going great and so lucky then bam you fell off somewhere and broke your leg, good luck surviving). I could only properly enjoy the game on the easiest setting which I would HIGHLY recommend for new players. While fun, the game is extremely difficult. That's why it doesnt tire - you dont really get to stable plateu of feeling safe and secure even after hours of playing it. There is always the exciting suspense that horror survivalists crave. You are never safe, even in your cozy wooden shelter....And the game is only Alpha. I cannot wait to see what more content makes this good game even better.Would recommend 100%

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I speak Portuguese, so probably this review contains grammatical mistakes. I apologize in advance.This review is about Alpha 14.7. The next version (Alpha 15) will add new features!In a few words, it is a survival game about zombies, where you need defend yourself against hordes every seven days. But this game is not focused in building a base in the beginning and wait. On the contrary, it forces the player to explore the world gathering resources, since you spawn with nothing more than a bottle of water, one torch and few medicine. Each new release, the game is balanced and some resources (like food and water) becomes more scarce (I believe that they don't need balance these two any more), giving a better and bigger challenge - just like a survival game would be. There are some RPG elements, where each action gives you experience, leveling up the character, giving points to spend in some stats (or skills and perks, in this case). This is important since every day the number of zombies rises and spawn some harder ones. Also, you will start from pretty nothing and will have a progression path, learning some recipes and leveling up, until you can craft some better equipment (tools, weapons and armor). After a while it is possible build a self-sufficient base (or upgrade the existent ones), with forges, plantations and digging the ground for mining, which stops the real need to explore the map. In this stage it is possible hunt animals but you can not domesticate them (plantations works just fine though). I hope they add some new features to force at least some roaming from time to time (just my gameplay style preference, not a problem at all). Oh! I almost forgot... If you are playing in the default settings, you will need to be very careful to roam at night. Take a look for yourself - no spoilers. hahaThat said, it is a solid game even for an alpha. Not many updates as other alpha games, but the developers usually informs the community what they are doing in each minor release. Major updates only occurs in major releases (from alpha 14 to 15, for example), which will break your saves, unfortunately (I believe it is OK, since is an alpha). Most bad reviews are about the save breaks from release to release. Be advised!It is a voxel game, so, if you do not like, that is not for you. They implemented physics, so take care about foundations! If you want to build a mine, for example, you will need some support pillars. The same goes to walkways and bridges. Almost everything is destroyable... I believe only bedrock (the foundation of the game world) is not. Not sure about the height limits of the world, but is pretty big. The default map also is pretty big in length too. It will take a lot of time to explore and loot all.I'm not adept of high graphics settings in my games, but I see a lot of people saying they are having problems with performance. I play in medium with my laptop (i5, 6GB RAM and nVidia 930M) only with 'no shadows' and it runs fine. Every update and release they are trying to optimize the game as much as they can, so let's hope.As I said, if you keep in mind that is an alpha game and they are working every day to bring some new features and balance the game, it is a very good and fun game. Pretty solid in features and gameplay. I believe that optimization, as I said, is the only bigger problem, but the developers are working hard on this. I believe the game has some problem about some hit boxes as well, where some zombies can hit you from distance even if their arm don't hit you in the animation.It is known that some MAC users are having problems each new release, but it seems like is and engine issue... So, if you are a MAC user, you need to go to the forums and find if the issues were fixed. In the Windows, where I play, I had no problems.Never played multiplayer, but the mechanics is the same.

Early Access Review
								Reviewed edited to account for the massive amounts of updates that have been added to the game since I last played.Tl;dr: The devs have taken this game a long way since it was added to early access (for that alone, how many early access survival/zombie games compare?) For the most part the devs have delivered on there promises when it comes to content. This game is easily one of the best survival and voxel based games that I've played. 7 days to die offers a LOT for an alpha game. The survival and crafting mechanics are in a depth that beats most fully released games. The construction of bases offers vast amount of variety and care, and if youre the type who prefers doing so with an editor mode, its an option available to you. Upon starting a game you have a multitude of options to choose from that mark the settings of your world, including the value of loot you can find, the difficulty of enemies (via changing zombie behavior and so forth) and the strength of structures, among so much more.The combat is similar to most other fps survival games, however much of what you can fight with comes from either scavenging or crafting it yourself. Based on your settings things can be found in plenty, though among my friends and I, we prefer a difficult to survive and rarely scavengable outlook. We like to struggle and this game provides that option for us.If you enjoy zombie survival, base crafting, and character development this game has everything you could want and more. Don't let the looks fool you, this game is easily top-tier when it comes to the survival market, which as of late has been flooded with nonsense. 10/10 would recommend.

								Based on a true story, probably, i think, maybe, yeah...A dark night, with stars like chocolate buttons twirling through the fog which is falling, a normal night for the fellow survivors of the safezone which might be safe, but probably isnt, this is 7 days to die after all, with time running out, they expend their stamina reaching the hovel they now call home, a reminiscent of life before the suspiciously similar events of minecraft and the walking dead somehow broke out.  The sound of rabbits being eaten in the distance and pigs getting killed by glitchy chunks have shredded the survivors morale.  As the time reaches midnight the survivors check their rations, only to find that they are down to the last can of peas and their last two pieces of corn, the last of the beer had been stolen by some guy who probably didnt survive the night, This could only mean ome thing, the end is near.As the foggy morning rises over the plains of plainland one survivor notices a pig rummaging around their forging area, and he though to himself, hmm, Bacon.  With his thought he grabbed his Rifle and crossbow, not forgetting his handy knife as he left the warmth and comfort of the shack to track and eat this pig.  He followed its tracks for several miles untill he could get a clear enough shot to kill it, and turn it into bacon, He fires, He hits, and the pig runs off like nothing happened, the Survivor is mort annoyed by this and started spamming crossbow bolts at the pig, which appears to be eating them as the bolts are nowhere to be seen, after several hours of this the pig finally gives in and collapses, But what do you know, there is a growling noise not to far away, the survivor crouches down, edges towards the pig, never bothering to look behind him, big mistake, he harvests his bacon, turns around, and there was a FERAL!!!   Demon zombie with an attitude which wasnt very nice.  An extaordinarily tense batle broke out between survivor and feral which resulted in the feral dropping dead with a hunting knife wedged in its frontal lobe, the feral gave what he got back though, as the survivor was now bleeding out and with a sprained leg, night was aproaching on the infamous day 7 he had heard so much about.He was hobbling, as fast as his now damaged leg would carry him, but he did not make it back to the shack, as the horde of many zombies and death doggies had descended, right across his path, how convienient.  a walking buffet the walkers thought, and decided to run towards our dear survivor, While i would like to say that the survivor fought the good fight, he did not, he screamed and ran like a little B***h and fell off a cliff, along with several dogs and angry bloaters, that was the last they ever saw of the survivor, and the last they ever heard, as his screams carried over the night like an eerie sirenBasically, Yeah, great ganme, 100/9/3

Early Access Review
								If I was going to boil this game down to one word it would be "FUN".Yes its an alpha and it has its share of issues but nothing game breaking at least for me. The graphics are pretty good and the mechanics of the game are much better with alpha 6 than in alpha 5. If your familiar with the game Minecraft than you will be familiar with this game when it comes to the crafting and mining aspects, just the graphics are much better as well as the graphics engine. The new forging system in Alpha 6 make for more realism and some added complexity but its a welcome change for me. Crafting houses, farms, furniture, farming for food, mining for ore and stone, making your own ammo and weapons are what make the game fun. I can only see this game getting better with time. Not sure what is next on the features list but here is a wish list from me.Some basic vehicles (I have a ton of gas and no chainsaw yet. Maybe a horse!. Or just to get around the map faster when you don't want to walk)Ability to make more furniture and household items. (I saw double and queen sized beds as well as lamps)More faming options (more crops, and tools)Fence gates (just can't keep out those pesky critters)More food and crafted food options.Double doors that work (They seem to be inthe premade buildings but thedon't work correctly.)Boss zombies (know they were listed as a coming feature but just stating how much I would like them.)Ramdom Dungeons (Something to explore. Might even be filled with zombies and that zombie boss)Third person view (So I can take a look at myself) Seems F5 does the trick in Alpha 6.Clothes and hats ( So I can see myself all decked out. Can you say hunting outfits so I can hang around the abandon hunting lodge)Item slots (For the clothes and hat)The only problem that I can see with the game is that the zombie aspects are fun but at night its pretty much death city because there is no way even at the highest daylight to night time period setting that you can gather enough resources and defend yourself. The zombies are way to aggressive at night and seem to make a bee line right for you even though they can't even see you. Its almost like at night they can sense where you are, even when I was at the bottom of a deep pit. If they would not seek you out then the game would be more playable in my opinion with zombies turned on. Mostly I just play with them turned off which also is a nice feature.Grampybones

								I normaly dont spend much time on reviews of games becouse i tend to play them, but this game deserves it.Its been what, over 2 years now since i bought the game? I pretty much got it when it got on steam, and wow what a great 2~ish years it has been.If you are looking at a game in early access, you want one thing, and thats propper development.Well stop looking since this game had exactly that and much much more.In the years i played it up till now, this game has always been great, and it just keeps getting better with every update. This review is for version 14.5, but i will also take the development in the past years into account.Ill give an overview of pros and cons, then a summary of when to buy this game, and last some game tips and tricks for when you start off.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Pros;+ Large open world, multiple biomes each with a unique feel to them+ Interesting, realistic and versatile crafting system+ Great gameplay (controlls, movement etc)+ Skill and level system+ Good grafics, and music+ Lots of  tools and weapons, for everyone something (melee brawling, guns blazing or stealthy, you can play how you like)+ Lots of loot and building materials+ Weather system, that changes depending on the biome your in.+ Set world, random generated worlds, single player and multiplayer (with easy to set up server)+ Propper development, every update makes the game betterCons;- Its an early access game, meaning you might encounter some bugs, and saved games might not work after major updates. - Loading screen takes long when you start the game up.The few bugs or gliches that i have encountered in the past years are few and got fixed in a matter of days sometimes even hours.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------When should you buy this game?--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------If you like Zombie games, Survival, Crafting, Building, Lots of loot, the option to play the way you want, and a game that keeps getting better with every update, this is the game for you.If i had to compare this game with other games, i would say it reminds me of Minecraft, and survival games like DayZ, Rust etc.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Below i will give some tips on how to start off, beware of MINOR SPOILERS!--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Last updated: April 2016---------------------------When you start off in the world you get only the most bastic needs, a bit of water, and food, a torch, and a bandage.First thing you want to get as fast as posible, is a stone axe, the game tells you in a little tuturial what to do. You need to pick up stones laying arround with the button ''E'' or hit some boulders with your fist (left mouse button), then you need some grass, hit it with your fist to pick some up.Then you need wood, any tree or bush will give you some when hit.You can craft the stone axe in your crafting menu by pressing ''TAB''.The stone axe is a multi purpose tool that is your new friend, you can use it as a club to smash zombie heads, use it as an axe to chop down trees, and a pickaxe to get stone.Make sure you pick up a lot of stone, wood, and grass becouse you will be making lots of stone axes.You might want a save way to kill a zombie here and there, the bow is a cheap and easy item for this.You will need some wood, and grass to build the bow, the arrows can be made with stone, wood and feathers.Feathers can be found in bird nest that are scattered on the floor here and there (and in or on some buildings)Food/Water; you can fill glass bottles and empty cans with water from rivers and lakes, also you can cook the water on a campfire so you wont get sick. Food can be cooked in different ways, altough not all food needs to be cooked to savely eat it, all canned food can be eaten right away.Surviving is your main priority at the start of the game, you want to loot as much as you can and stay away from zombies, getting hurt early in the game is a bad idea, and dieing (if you dont have perma death on) will lower your wellness, wich is the maximum hitpoints and stamina you have.Only take out the lone zombie here and there if they are in the way of a building you want to loot, by using a bow and/or using the hit and run tacktic. Try hitting zombies in the head.You can find Cloth fragment by looting, breaking down clothing you find, and by crafting it from cotton plants (those bushes with white fluffy balls on it). You will need it for making bandages, and first aid bandages in case you get hurt.Where to survive your first night: Its best to find 2-4 buildings together, and choose the highest one. There you would want to make your first base at the top floor or roof. While one of the  buildings will be your starting base, the other buildings can provide food and materials to survive.If you play with a seed or random generated game, you might have to do with what you find, always try to be from the ground so zombies cant reach you straight away. (shops have a flat roof with a ladder at the back and will do just fine)Every 3 days, unless set differently a plane will fly over and drop a supply crate, this always contains resources like antibiotics, medkits and sometimes other suplies. If you get infected you have 3 days to live unless you take antibiotics or honey, so make sure you get that crate, since its a great help.Usefull loot: Canned food, Water, Medical suplies, Mining helmet (great protection and flashlight that you can turn on with ''F'')Tips!If you are having trouble with surviving at night, instead of setting the dificulty lower, you can also set the zombies to always walk. As default the zombies run when its dark and walk when in (day) light. I always have them set to walk becouse it feels to me like zombies should walk.This however does not affect zombie dogs.Dont go into cities or any big cluster of buildings, more zombies and also stronger zombies spawn here.Every 7 days at night time a horde will come for you, if you are having trouble with them or find them anoying, either keep moving when they come or go back to menu when they have spawned and then go back into the game, and they will be gone.___________________________________________I hope this review was usefull to you.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Day 1 - I'm alone in the snowy wilderness with nothing on me but my underwear. Must of been one heck of a night, but that's over with. I rip what little weeds are around me from the ground, pick up a stone, and punch some shrubbery to make a simple stone axe. From here I can scavenge and forage until I find enough to make some bows and arrows. Night is coming, so I decide to crash into an old semi-abandoned lumber mill...just have to clear out the frozen lumberjacks first...Day 2 - I scavenge the nearby areas for supplies, while honing my skills with a bow and arrow on frostbitten zombies. There's a nice lake with some cabins, and a big hunting lodge in the other direction. I take what I need and crash at the lumber mill. I fortify it a bit to help out at night. Day 3 - A dog bit me and infected me. I will die without antibiotics in roughly 3 days. I need to find them fast. I scavenge some more, but no luck. I board up all the windows to the 2 story house next to the lumber mill and add a shooting platform out back. Day 4 - The infection has spread; I must leave to find medicine. My health is dropping slowly...but dropping. After a while, I stumble upon a holy grail of weapons - the Shotgun store in the frigid wasteland. They must cater to hunters. I manage to find an antibiotic and clear the infection. Zombies are everywhere, but things are looking up. I have weapons to even the playing field.Day 5 - I scavenege for supplies only to come across what looks to be like a small military outpost. It's abandoned except for a few zombies throwing themselves on landmines for some reason. I take all 66 landmines and bring them back home. Suprisingly there were no weapons in the outpost. It was much to open-air for my taste, so I bring everything of use back to my lumber castle.Day 6 - I spend the day gathering supplies to build additions to my wooden fortress. I build a forge, smelt metal and craft better tools and improve my weapons. I place landmines all around my house and dig trenches. Day 7 - An ominous feeling of dread approaches in the morning. I don't want to go out. I don't want to leave my house, so I spend the day adding mazes of wood to herd hostiles into landmines and trenches. This is oddly relaxing, but the feel of dread approaches. Night 7 - I stand on my shooting platform and watch the sun go down over my minefield and oil drums scattered in the snow. If I had a cigarrette, I'd smoke it. I wait, and wait, but nothing happens. Midnight approaches, and still nothing. I am getting on edge each minute, but still nothing but silence. At 3am, I step away from my shooting platform and head for the door to go in when I hear a dog growl. It shrieked in pain as it slammed against wooden spikes below me. I turned around to see 50 zombies running at full speed. Charging through my landmines and blowing their faces off just to make me bleed. I shoot some oil drums nearby and take out about a dozen. Ten more were unfortunate enough to step on landmines. Another dozen impaled themselves on spikes as their undead comrades climbed their bodies to try and reach me. I pull out a shotgun and shoot wildly at any survivors. An hour passes of rampage and carnage, but I survive. My fortress pulled through as well. I pack up everything and decide to move to greener pastures.Day 8 - I am a zombie slayer. I have survived against hordes, dogs, and everything else I have come across. I pack up and leave my lovely winter fortress to explore. I pass through lovely forests, deserts, and some sort of charred ground shooting every zombie I come across. Nothing can stop me. I make it to the ruins of a city and start looking for a good place to set up for the night. I shoot a few zombies, nothing I can't handle. I see a movie theatre that looks pretty fortified, so I break down the doors. More zombies aproach, but I take them out. I break down the doors and hear dogs. One jumps on me before I can get a shotgun blast off. More zombies bang on the doors all around me. I run around the corner and come face to face with 3 more zombies. One shotgun blasts drops all three. Another dog lunged at me and caused me to bleed. I took him down but need to heal or I will bleed out. I run around the corner to the theater room. The emergency exit door busts open and 4 zombies come in. I shoot them and head up the stairs to bandage myself. I can see a dozen rotten bodies slowly approach me from the bottom of the stairs of the movie room. I pull out the bandages and first aid kits from my inventory. The last thing I hear is glass shattering from above me, and a famished shout as undead arms grab me from behind. I didn't have the high ground...TLDR - This game is in alpha stage, but it is extremely fun. The graphics aren't great yet, but I have seen developer posts of really good graphics, so I assume they will be implemented at some point (beta or later). Basically all you need to know if you should buy this game.Do you like crafting and building games like minecraft?Do you like tower defense games?Do you like open world exploration games like skyrim?If you answered yes to all 3, then you will like this game. There will be story lines and npc quests in later updates, but none are in the game so far. That said, this game is very fun even without those things.

content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								Extremely fun to play crafting survival game where you get to fight a zombie horde (that you can't hide from) every 7 days.Between the hordes you will be scavenging, gathering materials and upgrading your base/tools/equipment. This happens in a huge open world map that zombies spawn/roam in. There are also roaming hordes that wander around. There are also different types of mines on ground (tin cans, hubcaps etc.), so watch your step.The game uses a skill system where you have skills for making tools, weapons, gathering materials etc. and using them. These skills are trained either by doing activities associated to said skills or by spending skill points. At the start collecting materials is going to take some time, but it gets better after a short while.There are also skill perks that can only be trained by using skill points, so it's advised to save your skill points for these. Notable ones include being able to produce concrete and steel.You can make the game either easier or harder by changing various settings that include zombie spawn rate, amount of loot, daytime lenght and zombie movement. By default zombies only run at night, but that can be changed.Bugs. Lots of them. Not surprising for a game that is in Alpha state, but the game is in an excellent condition for it's state.The game is also very easily moddable, which unfortunately makes cheating easier, too.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game somewhere around Alpha 12, and it has gone from strength to strength ever since. It has everything a zombie survival game should have and a whole lot more to boot, which includes :-•	A great variety of weapons and armour to suit a number of play styles.•	The ability to construct any base your imagination can conceive, above or below ground.•	A levelling up system that allows you to specialise in certain weapon or armour types.•	The ability to improve your crafting, construction and mining skills.•	The flexibility to hunt for food or grow your own.•	A large predetermined map with the option to play a randomly generated one.•	The impetus to prepare for the inevitable horde every 7 days, lest you be caught off guard.I could go on, however the point is this game is fantastic, adaptive and a must for anybody who is a fan of the genre. People often complain about how slow updates are being released, about how a console version was released before it was finished in order to make money etc. Guess what? That is how small development teams, like The Fun Pimps, have to operate in order to survive and to continue game development and production. The game can be buggy in places and glitchy in others, but so what, it is in Alpha after all and they rely on player feedback to help them iron out the creases. I have 273.9 hours of play time at the time of writing this review and I will add many more to that total as time goes on. I can't recommend this game enough, just bare with the progress and I know we'll all be rewarded in the end.Update-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Having watched the weekly Q&A YouTube sessions and Alpha 16 updates from one of The Fun Pimps development team, Mad Mole, it is clear to see that the game will definitely have the experience enhanced. Additions in future Alpha's include electricity, enhanced base defence options, different modes of transport and alternative ways to gather food; this is only a small selection of the additions to the game so I would recommend going to YouTube and seeing for yourself.

Early Access Review
								7 Days to Die is a brutal and unforgiving game where the player must survive against countless zombies in harsh environments. The fact that the game incorporates a hunger and hydration system adds to the survive theme as well as overall health and stamina. With multiplayer also available you and your friends can take on all the zombie hordes you desire, hours of fun! The crafting system in this game is a little tricky but you should not let that discourage you, put a little time into it and you can build pretty much any kind of structure you want to survive the zombie apocalypse in, however, the building mechanics have real physics so build carefully because your structure will collapse under the many loads you have applied. The game also includes a map pre-made but now you have the option to randomly generate a map for you to fully explore and discover new and interesting locations. Despite this game being in alpha, the development team works very hard to add new content as well as working tirelessly to remove any bugs that might arise.Overall I give this game a 9/10 but it receives a 10/10 for survival fun.If you are looking for a good zombie + survival + horror + crafting + multiplayer, buy this game and have some fun!- Dovah Vick.
