content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								This was my first survival horror game on PC. After a friend convinced me to purchase it we have continually come back to explore the new additions and updates when they come out. I believe we started playing on alpha 10 or 11 and after many changes we still come back and enjoy this game. The gameplay is very basic. You start out with very few things and must find resources and set up a base. You have to keep track of basic hunger and thirst stats and recently temperature. Other stats like wellness determine how healthy your character is and other illnesses like dysentary, infection, or a broken ankle can heavily hinder or kill your character. Day time will be spent gathering resources and exploring and night is usually spent huddled in your house or base hoping you don't attract attention from a passing hoard. There are two map variations, one premade by the devs and one randomly generated. There is plenty of exploration and is highly encouraged to find food, weapons, or the ever elusive calipers. The crafting options have only gotten larger and better and later in game when you're not worrying about dysentary you can build and customize a fortress to withstand any hoard. I'd like to mention I never actually play this game solo. For a fully enjoyable experience play with some friends. In every new game we play the first few nights are a scramble as we rush to find each other and set up a base to keep ourselves safe from the night. After playing many new games the first week or two in game are definitely more fun. Eventually when you find better weapons and have a system going things get pretty easy and the game loses it's luster. However with the newest updates adding quests and new materials to craft the end game stays interesting for a little longer. Overall I would highly recommend this game. It only keeps getting better.

content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								Extremely fun to play crafting survival game where you get to fight a zombie horde (that you can't hide from) every 7 days.Between the hordes you will be scavenging, gathering materials and upgrading your base/tools/equipment. This happens in a huge open world map that zombies spawn/roam in. There are also roaming hordes that wander around. There are also different types of mines on ground (tin cans, hubcaps etc.), so watch your step.The game uses a skill system where you have skills for making tools, weapons, gathering materials etc. and using them. These skills are trained either by doing activities associated to said skills or by spending skill points. At the start collecting materials is going to take some time, but it gets better after a short while.There are also skill perks that can only be trained by using skill points, so it's advised to save your skill points for these. Notable ones include being able to produce concrete and steel.You can make the game either easier or harder by changing various settings that include zombie spawn rate, amount of loot, daytime lenght and zombie movement. By default zombies only run at night, but that can be changed.Bugs. Lots of them. Not surprising for a game that is in Alpha state, but the game is in an excellent condition for it's state.The game is also very easily moddable, which unfortunately makes cheating easier, too.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game somewhere around Alpha 12, and it has gone from strength to strength ever since. It has everything a zombie survival game should have and a whole lot more to boot, which includes :-•	A great variety of weapons and armour to suit a number of play styles.•	The ability to construct any base your imagination can conceive, above or below ground.•	A levelling up system that allows you to specialise in certain weapon or armour types.•	The ability to improve your crafting, construction and mining skills.•	The flexibility to hunt for food or grow your own.•	A large predetermined map with the option to play a randomly generated one.•	The impetus to prepare for the inevitable horde every 7 days, lest you be caught off guard.I could go on, however the point is this game is fantastic, adaptive and a must for anybody who is a fan of the genre. People often complain about how slow updates are being released, about how a console version was released before it was finished in order to make money etc. Guess what? That is how small development teams, like The Fun Pimps, have to operate in order to survive and to continue game development and production. The game can be buggy in places and glitchy in others, but so what, it is in Alpha after all and they rely on player feedback to help them iron out the creases. I have 273.9 hours of play time at the time of writing this review and I will add many more to that total as time goes on. I can't recommend this game enough, just bare with the progress and I know we'll all be rewarded in the end.Update-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Having watched the weekly Q&A YouTube sessions and Alpha 16 updates from one of The Fun Pimps development team, Mad Mole, it is clear to see that the game will definitely have the experience enhanced. Additions in future Alpha's include electricity, enhanced base defence options, different modes of transport and alternative ways to gather food; this is only a small selection of the additions to the game so I would recommend going to YouTube and seeing for yourself.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Probably the best Zombie Apocalypse survival game out right now. The game is still relatively buggy, but has become quite polished since its early days. It is in my opinion one of the most beautiful voxel-based games now that lighting has been updated and distant terrain is supported now, as well as significant improvements to random world generation. It is essentially Minecraft on steroids and everything that DayZ was supposed to be. Unlimited replayability makes this game definitely worth the price.A few people seem to be under the impression that updates are going to be delayed and halted because of 7DTD's console release. This is false; a different team is working on the console version and will not have any sort of effects on the PC version's development. Updates are still released quite regularly and the game is nowhere close to falling into the notorious forever-"early access" pit.

content:
Posted: January 2
Early Access Review
								7 Days to Die is a very good game - especially if you play it with friends, so you can all co-operate together.It's like a cross between Minecraft and Rust/H1Z1.You start out with nothing, but you quickly farm a few grasses, trees, and stones to make a stone axe, and start upgrading from there.If you get a well-built defensible base built, then you can survive the zombie hordes and craft bigger and better items.The game has a high-ish learning curve, as you have to make quite a few items before you can learn to craft others.But once you have your furnace going (and other advancements) you can start to upgrade your crafting abilities.The map is very big, and there are zombies roaming all over the place, so it can be quite hard to survive, especially at night (10pm to 4am, in-game) when the zombie hordes turn up (and they are faster and more vicious during the night).And then, every seventh night, the zombies come for you in earnest; if you're not prepared for that, then you're dead.I've only played this game on PVE (Player Versus Environment) servers, which was hard enough - I hate to think how bad it would be when you're playing on a PVP (Player Versus Player) server, where you have to fight other people as well as the zombies.Mind you, on the PVE servers, there is a lot more scope for creating buildings - I've seen some great structures made by players. On PVP, you''ll probably be too busy watching your back (unless you have a gang to back you up).Get some friends to join you, to help you build.Or go it solo, if you're a hero.Either way, you can have a good time.If you like Rust, H1Z1, and Minecraft, then 7 Days to Die would be worth getting.Even if you haven't played similar games, I would still recommend giving this one a go.Well worth a try.

content:
Posted: January 5
Early Access Review
								If you told me there was an early-access zombie survival game on Steam that featured an rpg-like leveling tree, a crafting menu, and Minecraft-esque destruction and construction system, I would tell you to stay well away from that game, just on principle.Having said that, 7 Days to Die is an early-access zombie survival game, available on Steam, that features leveling and crafting, along with a Minecraft-esque building system.And 7 Days to Die is better than it has any right to be.For me, this game is right up my alley.  I love going around and looting everything that I can see, and then bringing my haul back to my base and sorting it into neat piles.  On top of that, you can build your own base and fortify it against the zombies.  They can be a bit tenacious, which makes it all the more important to put some thought into your base design.  However, seeing as this game is still in an Alpha state, their AI is more than a little abuse-able, so at this point in development, you don't have to put too much thought in.The leveling system is quite brilliantly done.  As you train certain skills, they level up, which means that the skills you use regularly level up quickly.  On top of that, you also get skill points after you earn a certain amount of experience or complete fetch quests, which you can then put towards skills that you don't use that often, removing the grind through boring skills. Next, is the crafting system, which I also feel is quite brilliantly done.  You craft tools and weapons which degrade with use, and then can be repaired with raw materials or by smooshing a second copy of the tool into the first at a workbench (think Minecraft).  However, not only does this repair the tool in question, but it upgrades it to be more effective.  This can be done repeatedly for stacking results.  Contrary to what one might think, this does not completely break the game’s system of progression.  Yes, you can make a hundred stone axes at the beginning of the game and combine them all to make an extremely high-quality stone axe.  However, workbenches are difficult to make and rare to find.  Furthermore, that stone axe will still be out-performed by all but the shoddiest iron axes.  This ability to combine like tools simply reduces the grind if you're mid-game and suddenly find yourself without mid-tier tools.  Did you die and lose your steel shovel?  No worries, you're not back to square one; just make a bunch of stone shovels, combine them at a workbench, and you have a semi-decent shovel to work with until you get your old one back!Finally, I couldn't talk about a zombie survival game without talking about the combat.  The melee combat is average.  While it isn't terrible, it's not very engaging.  Run in, swing, run out, repeat.  I definitely would like some more feedback as to what I'm doing.  Sometimes the zombies will stumble or fall down randomly, but there's no indicator as to what I did to cause that.  Sure, I cracked the zombie over the head with a tree branch, but I've hit thirty other zombies the same exact way and they didn't react like that.  A more dynamic melee system would make combat so much more engaging.  Thankfully, you're given the resources to craft a bow and some arrows right at the start of the game, and the archery mechanics are so much more fun to play with than the melee mechanics.  Archery at least introduces arrow drop-off; melee is just “hit the thing until it stops moving.”7 Days to Die is filled with so much potential; however, there is one caveat to this review: I don't believe it is worth the full price at the moment.  If 7 Days to Die was guaranteed to live up to its potential, I would definitely recommend it at its current price; however, the game is currently in Alpha and has been in Alpha since December of 2013.  There’s nothing wrong with spending a long time in Alpha but, while it would be incredibly disappointing to see such potential go to waste, there’s nothing stopping the developers from dropping the game tomorrow.  There are bugs as well as balance and optimization issues that still need to be addressed and there is so much potential for new content and polish around the edges to push this game up to the twenty-five dollar range.  I’m having a blast with the game as it is, but until some of the major issues are addressed I would say wait for a Steam sale, and if you can get the game for ten or fifteen dollars, that would be a wise investment.

								After only 21 hours of gameplay, I've got to say this is a very good game, though it is still the alpha version. Also, don't get: a broken leg, an infection, diarrhea, a bleeding wound, and more...But for every complaint is a solution: bandages, first aid, antibiotics, painkillers, a splint... find one or craft one, the possibilities are (almost) endless!

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Day 1 - I'm alone in the snowy wilderness with nothing on me but my underwear. Must of been one heck of a night, but that's over with. I rip what little weeds are around me from the ground, pick up a stone, and punch some shrubbery to make a simple stone axe. From here I can scavenge and forage until I find enough to make some bows and arrows. Night is coming, so I decide to crash into an old semi-abandoned lumber mill...just have to clear out the frozen lumberjacks first...Day 2 - I scavenge the nearby areas for supplies, while honing my skills with a bow and arrow on frostbitten zombies. There's a nice lake with some cabins, and a big hunting lodge in the other direction. I take what I need and crash at the lumber mill. I fortify it a bit to help out at night. Day 3 - A dog bit me and infected me. I will die without antibiotics in roughly 3 days. I need to find them fast. I scavenge some more, but no luck. I board up all the windows to the 2 story house next to the lumber mill and add a shooting platform out back. Day 4 - The infection has spread; I must leave to find medicine. My health is dropping slowly...but dropping. After a while, I stumble upon a holy grail of weapons - the Shotgun store in the frigid wasteland. They must cater to hunters. I manage to find an antibiotic and clear the infection. Zombies are everywhere, but things are looking up. I have weapons to even the playing field.Day 5 - I scavenege for supplies only to come across what looks to be like a small military outpost. It's abandoned except for a few zombies throwing themselves on landmines for some reason. I take all 66 landmines and bring them back home. Suprisingly there were no weapons in the outpost. It was much to open-air for my taste, so I bring everything of use back to my lumber castle.Day 6 - I spend the day gathering supplies to build additions to my wooden fortress. I build a forge, smelt metal and craft better tools and improve my weapons. I place landmines all around my house and dig trenches. Day 7 - An ominous feeling of dread approaches in the morning. I don't want to go out. I don't want to leave my house, so I spend the day adding mazes of wood to herd hostiles into landmines and trenches. This is oddly relaxing, but the feel of dread approaches. Night 7 - I stand on my shooting platform and watch the sun go down over my minefield and oil drums scattered in the snow. If I had a cigarrette, I'd smoke it. I wait, and wait, but nothing happens. Midnight approaches, and still nothing. I am getting on edge each minute, but still nothing but silence. At 3am, I step away from my shooting platform and head for the door to go in when I hear a dog growl. It shrieked in pain as it slammed against wooden spikes below me. I turned around to see 50 zombies running at full speed. Charging through my landmines and blowing their faces off just to make me bleed. I shoot some oil drums nearby and take out about a dozen. Ten more were unfortunate enough to step on landmines. Another dozen impaled themselves on spikes as their undead comrades climbed their bodies to try and reach me. I pull out a shotgun and shoot wildly at any survivors. An hour passes of rampage and carnage, but I survive. My fortress pulled through as well. I pack up everything and decide to move to greener pastures.Day 8 - I am a zombie slayer. I have survived against hordes, dogs, and everything else I have come across. I pack up and leave my lovely winter fortress to explore. I pass through lovely forests, deserts, and some sort of charred ground shooting every zombie I come across. Nothing can stop me. I make it to the ruins of a city and start looking for a good place to set up for the night. I shoot a few zombies, nothing I can't handle. I see a movie theatre that looks pretty fortified, so I break down the doors. More zombies aproach, but I take them out. I break down the doors and hear dogs. One jumps on me before I can get a shotgun blast off. More zombies bang on the doors all around me. I run around the corner and come face to face with 3 more zombies. One shotgun blasts drops all three. Another dog lunged at me and caused me to bleed. I took him down but need to heal or I will bleed out. I run around the corner to the theater room. The emergency exit door busts open and 4 zombies come in. I shoot them and head up the stairs to bandage myself. I can see a dozen rotten bodies slowly approach me from the bottom of the stairs of the movie room. I pull out the bandages and first aid kits from my inventory. The last thing I hear is glass shattering from above me, and a famished shout as undead arms grab me from behind. I didn't have the high ground...TLDR - This game is in alpha stage, but it is extremely fun. The graphics aren't great yet, but I have seen developer posts of really good graphics, so I assume they will be implemented at some point (beta or later). Basically all you need to know if you should buy this game.Do you like crafting and building games like minecraft?Do you like tower defense games?Do you like open world exploration games like skyrim?If you answered yes to all 3, then you will like this game. There will be story lines and npc quests in later updates, but none are in the game so far. That said, this game is very fun even without those things.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								It was day 7 and I knew I wasn't going to be ready. Too little ammo found in time, too few hours spent prepping the walls. Worst of all, I didn't have enough light, not by a long shot. Those last few flicks of sun glimmering gold through the trees made my stomach lurch. Behind me, where the shadows of night grew, there was screaming in the distance. The dogs reached me first, packs of baying hounds, savagely driving across the field laden with spikes. Some went down, yet others ran even with prongs of wood embedded in them, uncaring, mindless zombies. I unloaded rifle rounds with unsteady shots, I couldn't help but shake, the sound of wailing grew ever stronger and before even a few dogs were down the rest of the undead were swarming the front wall. Flesh clambering over flesh, driving some down into the spikes only to climb over thier own dead and ascend. Spider zombies scaling the walls from behind, forcing me to turn my back to them and fire the last of my ammo. There was nothing left to do but desperate measures. I had found her in the trunk of a car, pure steel, heavy as sin. I named her Vera after my lost ones. Zombies were soft, and the sledge was hard as it arced down onto the first. Bones crunched, it collapsed, step back, swing again. More screaming. This time it was me. They were going down, but so was I. No choice. I lied about the ammo thing. I left one. In the pistol. Under this entire thing I had placed every last barrel of gas I had found. And that last bullet well... it sank into the metal with a flash and as I watched pieces of zombie all around me and my fort shatter I was sure I was done for, ears battered and ringing from the explosion. When I opened my eyes in a fine haze of falling red mist, I could see the blast was just right. Just far enough away to spare me, shivering, bruised, covered in gore, atop the shattered smouldering ruins of my fort. It was time to eat some soup and splint my arm, in a few hours the sun would rise, and I would need to prepare much. Day 7 it seems, was just the beginning.This game keeps getting better and better.

content:
Posted: April 25
Early Access Review
								7 Days to Die is probably the best zombie survival base-defense game out there. The mechanics are great. You don't need to demolish or move blocks to upgrade your base. You can upgrade blocks in-place so long as you have the required materials. Progression makes nighttime more dangerous to the player. This forces players to plan their bases accordingly. For example, running several furnaces and workbenches will attract more zombies to your base. This is because 7 Days to Die uses an 'actions per area per time' feature that most people call a 'heatmap'. This can become problematic, or not, depending on your base design.The graphics are good. This is especially true if you like the gritty-style art textures. I am not necessarily a fan of the world textures or character models but it fits with the rest of the game. If you're looking for great HD textures and models, play Rust. If you're looking for great PVE, PVP AND base building that doesn't wipe every week or month play 7 Days to Die.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Plain and simply; this game is fantastic and has tons of potential.     I started playing 7 Days to Die when it was first released. No matter how cliche or bad a zombie game is, I just can't wait to get my hands on it. Naturally, I bought the game and immediately and started playing it. Like any alpha game it was quite rocky, but it was incredibly fun. The ability to break and sculpt the world like minecraft has always been appealing to me, but adding in a sense of realism and a zombie apocalypse sold it. I wasted hours running around searching empty everythings, transforming houses into piles of collectable cubes, and building poor excuses of houses that looked weird and broke under the physics engine. It's just really fun to do, even when the terrain wasn't smoothed, a roof would cave in under your feet, and bees wouldn't ruin camping out on top of a building while grabbing a snack. Adding in the sense of survival and the need to build and collect bigger and better while fending off walking corpses was just great.    I just recently came back to the game after a long break waiting for more content and I was amazed. The game feels very different now compared to before, and all for the better. The updates have been phenominal, from terrain smoothing to beautiful lighting, to forging, random map regen, and frozen zombies in the winter landscape. This game is just tons of fun especially with other people. Nowadays I'm enjoying converting log cabins into concrete, barbwire, spikes, and sandbag fortresses while blowing up buildings and scavenging the randomly generated worlds for better jank.    That all said, the game is still an alpha and has room for improvement. There is definitely an amazing game sitting at the end of this undead rainbow, but it needs some more solid content first.     The two things this game needs before it's completely solid; A more defined progress/difficulty curve, and much more world content. I find that there isn't much of an "end-game" and less in-between. It doesn't take much effort to get the resources for reinforced concrete blocks to buff out a house, and have a decent belt of gear. I think the devs tried to limit how easy it is to get to end-game content by making the best guns very rare, which sadly only amounts to grinding out loot resets and hoping you have luck on your side. The book-reading aspect was clever, but needs to be flayed out more and possibly tiered. Honestly, I think there should be a tier between a rock axe and a fire axe, something like a "shoddy tool" tier, where the tool is made of metal but is crudely put together, requiring a forgery/blacksmithing book before you can make or repair the regular versions. The same goes for reinforced concrete, and anything of higher defense levels. Either way, the progress curve is short and only limited by spawn-rates. High tier books could even be put in the back of a library or other such building guarded by a nasty spawn of zombs. Leading to another point; zombies should have a progressive difficulty. I find by around the 10th day, I have all the gear and bullets I need to take down anything other than the mega horde, a vicious spawn of cops and dogs and everything in between. Normal zombies and hordes become dull, and upping the difficulty and tweaking settings does little more than make them sort-of challenging if they can actually hit you. Possibly adding more types of zombies, zombies in riot gear, or making hordes larger/more frequent/multiple at a time/hostile survivors, increasing with the days survived, would really add to the longevity of the game. *Edit; they've added increasingly hard hordes every 7 days, as well as adding risk to staying in an area too long/producing too much noise, smell, etc. Great stuff.    My final point is the in-game locations. In both the newly added random gen, but more importantly in Navezgane there are a limited number of interesting buildings. I feel Navezgane could be bigger, and I have a list of suggested things that will likely get lost in the sea of comments that I would really love to see in the game; convenience stores, shopping mall, hospital, grocery store, library, restaurant, office building, subway/sewer? (if at all, would probably be much later content), a large cemetary, full military base, ship port, docks, airport, news station, reinforced dead survivor city, disease center, train station?, highway, pharmacy, gun store, carnival?, apocalypse bunker, trailer park, prison, sports arena, fast food joint... The list could go on, but the game needs more places to explore, preferably with a more intimidating zombie spawn inside of them to create risk of exploring. When I came back for the Alpha 9 I was way too excited to see new places to explore such as rich houses, apartments, movie theaters, the destroyed city, and so forth. It was always exciting to find something new. After playing for a while, each new discovery feels like a disappointment as they really boil down to things you've seen MANY many times already. The loot also starts to sort of blend together leading you to forget about the need to explore most non-unique buildings.    Closing thoughts; great game, tons of fun, multiplayer is awesome, however it's still an alpha and has a long way to go before it is everything that it can be. I'm glad I spent the money to support the dev team and have spent the same amount of money on worse games that are fully released. Just add in a gameplay curve and much more to explore and I'll never put this game down. 10/10 would buy again.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is Fantastic! And it's still in the beta. In this game you have no objectives but to survive, its open world with lots of loot and toggleable loot respawn settings. The zombies in this game are realistic in that they do heavy damage. The health bar was designed fantastically, it doesn't just go up by eating food or using bandages, health going up is only a minor side effect of eating. Bandages are only useful when the should be, when you are bleeding and will bleed to death if bandages are not applied. The entire world is destructible, both you and zombies can destroy everything, so you can never be truly safe, as it should be. There are many toggleable settings about how the zombie world you enter will work, and later in the beta there will be a world generator so you can have more original worlds. The variety of items is great, lots of stuff and a very complicated but nice crafting system. There are some crafting recipes you can't do until your character reads a book about that particular field of survival. The crafting system remembers allrecipes you know, so no need to memorize any recipies. There is a great cooking system in the game, you can boil water you get from lakes to clean it, and you can make coffee among other things, though it may still be too early in beta for working cooking for most recipes or it's just difficult to figure out. This game doesn't have awkward looking blocks everywhere like you see in minecraft, it smooths out landscapes and even in player created caves. This game has good physics, there is very rarely any floating blocks(floating would be a glitch), and all blocks  have weight, durability and strength that determine how they can be used architecturally.Complaints: (most of this stuff is minor that doesn't take away much from gameplay.)->Its probably because its still in beta but, when you exit and reenter the game you can force zombies nearby that are chasing you to despawn, which could be used as a cheap solution to survival.->As i said above, the cooking system is confusing or unfinished.->There is no tool in the game to desmooth the block smoothing, i dug a cave house and if i want it to have corners i'd have to dig out the walls and replace them with a different block.->When respawning on your bed, you can spawn partially in the wall and see through the world, idk if you can jump into the void(I haven't tried).->When in a 1 block wide and 2 block tall tunnel that has block smoothing when your back is to a dead end you can look up and see through the world.->If you chop down a tree, then stack those logs on top of each other, the logs will look way wider than they were before, the game should make them 2 different wood blocks that can be broken down into different amounts of planks, other wood stuff, etc.->Zombie pathfinding could use a lot of work, when i scavenge a house and quickly close the doors the zombies won't attack the doors, they will attack the base of the house itself, meaning they are incredibly inefficient at breaking into houses, and you can easily just loot the house quickly then get out of there before they break in.->As I said above, some items can somewhat float as they are currently, if you destroy the block under a gunsafe the gun safe will not fall until all adjacent blocks are gone.->When you destroy a gun safe, Stove, air conditioner and many other things, no items fall as loot from them falling apart, there should at least be some scrap metal or something.->When cooking no lighter or ignition is required, it just magically ignites when you put fuel on it.->Not all blocks in the game are craftable from what i've seen, cabinets, refrigerators, lights for houses, and lots of other things can't be made. I think they should think ahead in case they add a book on how to build solar panel or generator for players that have been in the world a while and have the available resources to make one, so that things like light can be powered.->Related to the last complaint, as the game is currently there are some lights that are lit up mysteriously when some others aren't. I think they should just have all lights not work unless they add a power station building and somewhat allow the player to operate it.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								With the newest A15 update, which has updated the game even further and brought much more substance to the game, I figured it was a good time to do a review.Originally, I hated this game back when I first bought it, back around the time the original game came out. It has become a complete turnaround for me, and currently it's a game I'm very addicted to.Before I go on, I do want to say that the majority of my experience in this game is in single player. But I'm sure multiplayer with randoms can be just as exciting as a game like DayZ. And playing the game with just friends, well.. it can become an incredible co-op experience.First off, I love survival-type games like DayZ and the like (more specifically, DayZ Epoch/Overpoch and DayZ Origins). I also love base building, hording weapons/items/etc, and stuff like that. In this game, building a base, as well as going out and getting supplies, building up my arsenal and so on, is a lot of fun. Build a base, build defenses, take care of your survival needs such as hunger and hydration (which goes even deeper with having to be careful about your temperature, and diseases), and survive the hordes that come every seven days - hence the name of the game. To make everything all the more better, the game includes RPG elements that reward you for killing zombies, scavenging, building and much more. It all becomes together as an incredibly addictiveIf you're new and you want to get settled in before getting overwhelmed, there are plenty of options in single player that allows you to change the difficulty. You can even turn off zombies, which can allow you to build a base in peace, before you decide to take on the hordes. There are a lot of options, from changing how much loot there is out in the world, to how thick the zombie population is in the world.. from difficulties varying from "Very Easy" to "Very Hard."As you work on your base, you can go out and loot, level up, kill zombies and try to find weapons, equipment and building supplies to make your life a lot easier. The RPG system makes the game all the more addicting, as I stated before.There are a lot of options now when it comes to building bases, whether you're using different materials (wood, scrap metal, concrete, etc). Making an ultimate base that can stand a beating will takes time to build, as you'll generally want to use concrete, which will take awhile to craft. It's a good end-game type scenario to go for, and while you wait, you can make bases made out of wood to start you out. It doesn't take that long to build a simple base with wood, and with the right supplies, you can even upgrade your wooden base to more solid materials, such as scrap metal, brick, concrete and more. Meaning, you don't have to destroy your starter base made out of wood. Instead, you can upgrade it/build around it. And with the A15 update, there are a ton of different things you can build for your base, to make it your own original fortress. Just look up images of what people have done with their bases in the game, especially bases built in the current A15 build. Create a simple log cabin in the woods and live out your days in the wild. Dig yourself a secret underground bunker, with a giant maze of underground mining tunnels. Find a mountain and dig in, build a fortress that zombies and bandits alike would have trouble getting into, using both your structures and the mountain to protect you and your loot. Or make it easy, find an existing building in the world and customize it to your liking (just be aware of zombies spawning nearby). Heck, you can actually build a castle with a moat and a working drawbridge - though I'd recommend filling the moat with spikes and other defenses, as zombies aren't really bothered by water!Even if you aren't into base building, there's still a lot to do. Killing zombies, collecting items.. and if you're playing multiplayer, and if you're into that sort of thing, you can hunt players if you prefer a more PvP element. I don't have much experience with that in this game so I can't really go into it, but with my experience, I can't imagine it being bad.There's so much to collect and build on, and the game is still in early access.. meaning, there'll be even more added. And there's already a lot of different items to collect in the world as is, so it's extremely exciting to think about how the game will turn out once it's officially out of early access!In the end, the base building and looting mixed with the RPG element makes it a game that's not only incredibly addictive, it also gives it endless replayability. Your skills in the RPG department can effect many things. It can effect the level of loot you find, with the more you level up, the better level of loot you'll find. You can level up your Rifle skills, Handgun, Blunt or Bladed Weapons, and more. Focus on leveling on one in particular, or try to raise all your skills at the same time.Each time you level up - or complete missions - you are rewarded skill points. You can level up your skills by using these skill points, and/or you can also level up certain abilities by other means. Such as, if you want to raise your Scavenging skill, you can spend points in it. Otherwise, each time you loot an object, you gain experience towards your Scavenging skill. Same goes for pretty much all the rest of the skillsets, such as using Rifle weaponry to level up your Rifle skill level, using/building mining tools to level up your Mining and so on. There are also special abilities that can only be bought, that can make some of your base skills even more powerful, such as buying an ability that gives your bladed weapons a better chance to dismember your opponent's head/arm/leg, and much more.I could go on for quite awhile, so I'll just say.. if you aren't convinced yet, just go on Youtube and watch videos of other people playing the game. If you're into survival games, looting and base building.. or if you're into games such as Minecraft or DayZ, then chances are you'll enjoy it.Pros -- Endless replayability, whether you're playing alone or with friends.- Base building is a lot of fun, and there are a ton of blocks and such that'll allow you to create your own unique base.- RPG elements that end up mixing extremely well with the survival and base building aspects of the game, which ends up making the game incredibly addictive.- A lot of variety when it comes to items you can find in the world, and a good amount of variety when it comes to zombies, clothing, building blocks and more.- If you get bored of the main map, you can create a random map - complete with seeds - similar to Minecraft.- You can build a motorcycle once you get the right materials, making traveling the world a lot easier and faster. The better the engine, the faster it'll go, making it so the game isn't a complete walking simulator.- Too much to list, honestly. Read the TLDR version above and you'll get the gist of it.Cons -(First off, chances are these will be changed - hopefully for the better - as the game is still in early access.)- Weather system can be incredibly frustrating. You'll generally need to plan out what clothing to take with you, depending on what biome you go to. Some of the biomes are WAY too sensitive. It's not too bad once you get used to it and have the clothing you need, but it could definitely be annoying to new players, or experienced players creating new characters that are starting off from scratch.- While I don't mind this myself, some may be turned off to some of the grinding you may have to do to build concrete bases, or to find good items, such as the Auger which allows you to dig underground/collect rock and ores extremely quickly. It will take time.- Addictive! :] Which is.. bad for some people, I guess? lol.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Please note - this is an early access review.First off, let me say that I postponed reviewing this game due to having reviewed another early access game a bit too soon, and being forced to revise my review of that game because of it.Several of my friends bought into this game much earlier than I did. I held out because I'd been burned by early access before. But eventually I decided that, while 7 Days to Die was on sale, I should give it a try. So I did. I have not been disappointed.I'll list the good and bad first, then give a synopsis. Most people seem to like that kind of review style.Pros Game is currently playable and has plenty to do. Game has random world generation that is currently infinite - never run out of things to explore. Game uses voxels similar to Minecraft making everything interactive on some level. Game has hundreds of recipes for crafting. Game has farming, with 5 (soon to be 6) plantable seed types. Game has zombies to keep you on your toes, including running and fast variations. Game menu offers a wide variety of options to allow you to play the game the way you want to play it. Game has building with a wide variety of block types - make a hut, a cave or a castle, you are only limited by your imagination. Game has a wide variety of weapons with many more coming soon, from melee to projectile (clubs to guns). Game has buffs, debuffs and player attributes that must be maintained for optimal character performance. These include stamina, hunger, thirst, health, caffeine, broken bones, infection, bleeding, drowning, and several others. Game has day / night cycles with varying levels of light. Relatively low system requirements with decent framerate even on a laptop.Cons Currently no transportation methods, so infinite world can be daunting. These should be coming in the next few months. Limited zombie types with common skins - not a lot of zombie variety (roughly 12 different types). This should increase in the next few months. Lots of bugs - some that prevent an enjoyable multiplayer experience, but most aren't game-breaking.Synopsis / SummaryHaving played over 300 hours in the past 4.5 months, I'd say I already got my money's worth out of this game. I spend a lot of time on the official forums and have gotten a good feel for how the developers and moderators react to many things. Though the players and developers do defend their game when something negative is said, it doesn't feel like a hostile conversation for the most part.7DTD is a great game, even now in its uncompleted form. I have enjoyed playing numerous hours with my son and a few friends. The focus of the game is cooperative survival, but there's definitely a place for PvP. Nothing really feels like it was tacked on as an afterthought, although many of the sub-systems within the game are or feel like placeholders.If you're looking for a destructible world where survival and sandbox gameplay mix beautifully with a zombie apocalypse, look no further. I've never played Minecraft, but as far as I can tell, this is what mature, adult Minecraft would be. If you find someone else's review that states they do not recommend the game, look at their hours. Anything less than 10 hours and they have barely scratched the surface. Anything over 40 hours and they obviously enjoyed the game enough to keep coming back.I don't like to compare games unless they have a lot in common, at least regarding play style. But as far as early access goes, 7DTD has restored my faith in indie development teams. I've never put this many hours into a game before. And I'm far from bored, or done, playing it. Go buy it, or watch some youTube videos, and see what you're missing out on.

Early Access Review
								This is one of my favorite games I have ever played. With the saturation of gathering/crafting games in the last few years it almost seems like the genre will be played out soon. But this game, in my opinion, outshines any of the other games remotely similar to it by far. The developers are always active and you can follow what they're working on via their development blog. A lot of people complain about the fact that they estimate a release date and sometimes the update won't be out until a little bit after but, in my book, that's the sign of a good development team. They're willing to push back a release to make sure that it is how they envisioned it, functioning properly, playable. You can tell they love this game and put their all into it.Hosting your own server is pretty awesome, I love the options you have to make the game however easy or difficult you desire. I originally was hosting my own server off of my second computer during alpha 11 but as I was running into issues. I ended up joining a server with similar settings I enjoyed and had a much better experience with letting someone else manage the server so I could just play and enjoy. I believe my map data was corrupting but I didn't spend too much time troubleshooting so I'm not positive.To sum things up, I love this game and would highly recommend it to any one who ever enjoyed minecraft and left4dead...This game is kind of like those two had a kid. Zombies run at night, every 7 days there is a feral horde that will stop at nothing to kill you, PvP servers are pretty brutal (and super fun!), active developers...whats not to love?**************************************************************************************************************Here it is about a year later, Wrote a second review forgetting I had already wrote one:I've been playing since version A-9. I enjoyed it back then and it has come a long way since then and I still love it. I have probably spent 3X more time playing this game than any other game I have ever owned. It is a unique open world zombie survival game. It's like minecraft and left for dead had a baby. The devs, The Fun Pimps, have been pretty on top of this game and, if not pushing frequent updates out, allowing you to follow their progress and work via their Tumblr account. The shear amount of rebalancing and overhaul that they've done on this game gives it a fresh feel everytime I play through it again. If you get this game and it feels like you have everything you could ever want...well my advice is start over from lvl 1 on a new random gen map and have another go at it. Try joining a different server, PVP servers are a whole different experience from PVE servers. If you've only ever played single player, join a pve server and try to join up with a group or get your friends to join you, it really changes the dynamic of the game.I ran my own server for a little while, there are plenty of options to change and customize the game play to your liking from loot spawn frequency and amount, day light hours and over all 24 hour cycle real to real time ratio(zombies sprint at night), zombie spawn frequency and difficulty, and many more options to get it just the way you want it. I highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys survival games and zombies.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								With the newest A15 update, which has updated the game even further and brought much more substance to the game, I figured it was a good time to do a review.Originally, I hated this game back when I first bought it, back around the time the original game came out. It has become a complete turnaround for me, and currently it's a game I'm very addicted to.Before I go on, I do want to say that the majority of my experience in this game is in single player. But I'm sure multiplayer with randoms can be just as exciting as a game like DayZ. And playing the game with just friends, well.. it can become an incredible co-op experience.First off, I love survival-type games like DayZ and the like (more specifically, DayZ Epoch/Overpoch and DayZ Origins). I also love base building, hording weapons/items/etc, and stuff like that. In this game, building a base, as well as going out and getting supplies, building up my arsenal and so on, is a lot of fun. Build a base, build defenses, take care of your survival needs such as hunger and hydration (which goes even deeper with having to be careful about your temperature, and diseases), and survive the hordes that come every seven days - hence the name of the game. To make everything all the more better, the game includes RPG elements that reward you for killing zombies, scavenging, building and much more. It all becomes together as an incredibly addictiveIf you're new and you want to get settled in before getting overwhelmed, there are plenty of options in single player that allows you to change the difficulty. You can even turn off zombies, which can allow you to build a base in peace, before you decide to take on the hordes. There are a lot of options, from changing how much loot there is out in the world, to how thick the zombie population is in the world.. from difficulties varying from "Very Easy" to "Very Hard."As you work on your base, you can go out and loot, level up, kill zombies and try to find weapons, equipment and building supplies to make your life a lot easier. The RPG system makes the game all the more addicting, as I stated before.There are a lot of options now when it comes to building bases, whether you're using different materials (wood, scrap metal, concrete, etc). Making an ultimate base that can stand a beating will takes time to build, as you'll generally want to use concrete, which will take awhile to craft. It's a good end-game type scenario to go for, and while you wait, you can make bases made out of wood to start you out. It doesn't take that long to build a simple base with wood, and with the right supplies, you can even upgrade your wooden base to more solid materials, such as scrap metal, brick, concrete and more. Meaning, you don't have to destroy your starter base made out of wood. Instead, you can upgrade it/build around it. And with the A15 update, there are a ton of different things you can build for your base, to make it your own original fortress. Just look up images of what people have done with their bases in the game, especially bases built in the current A15 build. Create a simple log cabin in the woods and live out your days in the wild. Dig yourself a secret underground bunker, with a giant maze of underground mining tunnels. Find a mountain and dig in, build a fortress that zombies and bandits alike would have trouble getting into, using both your structures and the mountain to protect you and your loot. Or make it easy, find an existing building in the world and customize it to your liking (just be aware of zombies spawning nearby). Heck, you can actually build a castle with a moat and a working drawbridge - though I'd recommend filling the moat with spikes and other defenses, as zombies aren't really bothered by water!Even if you aren't into base building, there's still a lot to do. Killing zombies, collecting items.. and if you're playing multiplayer, and if you're into that sort of thing, you can hunt players if you prefer a more PvP element. I don't have much experience with that in this game so I can't really go into it, but with my experience, I can't imagine it being bad.There's so much to collect and build on, and the game is still in early access.. meaning, there'll be even more added. And there's already a lot of different items to collect in the world as is, so it's extremely exciting to think about how the game will turn out once it's officially out of early access!In the end, the base building and looting mixed with the RPG element makes it a game that's not only incredibly addictive, it also gives it endless replayability. Your skills in the RPG department can effect many things. It can effect the level of loot you find, with the more you level up, the better level of loot you'll find. You can level up your Rifle skills, Handgun, Blunt or Bladed Weapons, and more. Focus on leveling on one in particular, or try to raise all your skills at the same time.Each time you level up - or complete missions - you are rewarded skill points. You can level up your skills by using these skill points, and/or you can also level up certain abilities by other means. Such as, if you want to raise your Scavenging skill, you can spend points in it. Otherwise, each time you loot an object, you gain experience towards your Scavenging skill. Same goes for pretty much all the rest of the skillsets, such as using Rifle weaponry to level up your Rifle skill level, using/building mining tools to level up your Mining and so on. There are also special abilities that can only be bought, that can make some of your base skills even more powerful, such as buying an ability that gives your bladed weapons a better chance to dismember your opponent's head/arm/leg, and much more.I could go on for quite awhile, so I'll just say.. if you aren't convinced yet, just go on Youtube and watch videos of other people playing the game. If you're into survival games, looting and base building.. or if you're into games such as Minecraft or DayZ, then chances are you'll enjoy it.Pros -- Endless replayability, whether you're playing alone or with friends.- Base building is a lot of fun, and there are a ton of blocks and such that'll allow you to create your own unique base.- RPG elements that end up mixing extremely well with the survival and base building aspects of the game, which ends up making the game incredibly addictive.- A lot of variety when it comes to items you can find in the world, and a good amount of variety when it comes to zombies, clothing, building blocks and more.- If you get bored of the main map, you can create a random map - complete with seeds - similar to Minecraft.- You can build a motorcycle once you get the right materials, making traveling the world a lot easier and faster. The better the engine, the faster it'll go, making it so the game isn't a complete walking simulator.- Too much to list, honestly. Read the TLDR version above and you'll get the gist of it.Cons -(First off, chances are these will be changed - hopefully for the better - as the game is still in early access.)- Weather system can be incredibly frustrating. You'll generally need to plan out what clothing to take with you, depending on what biome you go to. Some of the biomes are WAY too sensitive. It's not too bad once you get used to it and have the clothing you need, but it could definitely be annoying to new players, or experienced players creating new characters that are starting off from scratch.- While I don't mind this myself, some may be turned off to some of the grinding you may have to do to build concrete bases, or to find good items, such as the Auger which allows you to dig underground/collect rock and ores extremely quickly. It will take time.- Addictive! :] Which is.. bad for some people, I guess? lol.

								Have you ever played a Zombie game where you get your gun, scrounge some ammo, then farm till you're bored?ever played where you wall yourself in somewhere, get overwhelmed and just decide it's not fun anymore because you did all you could?Spend in-game days in some room somewhere wondering "when was the last time this guy ate?"... ever wished you could just take a buiding apart with your sledgehammer?how about blow the ever-loving smeg out of the floor with your rocket-launcher?THIS IS NOTHING LIKE ANY OF THEM!I have played this game for hours. Crafting. Food farming. Weapon repairing. metal forging. looting. running like heck through a snowy hill surrounded by dead things without any kind of light source!oh yeah... this game has all that AND MORE!best played with the lights out, headphones on, best bro backing you up and with lots and lots of sugar to keep you allert!you're going to need to free up a few hours to play this because you won't believe how much you can do!I spent nearly three hours barricading a petrol station.. zombie dogs baying at the windows, huge zombies beating at the doors... i was desperate. i gathered my resources, built a ladder, broke a hole in the wall beside the door and shot the gas pump! the explosion bought me enough time to get to the roof, destroy the ladder and hole up for the night to repair my weapons and eat something before i starved to death!got bored of that... so i made another game, made a pickaxe and dug straight down! my friend built a farm and i got him the materials to make bullets! now, we're living like dwarven kings in an underground structure bigger than the houses on the surface!This game isn't even finished yet and it's one of the best ever zombie games i've ever seen![EDIT]I have been following the developers as this game updates through the alphas. I can't think of many other games that deserve a console-release as much as 7Days and I am increasingly glad with every new feature they impliment with each new alpha.My only regret is that it takes so long to make a game. TFP work hard and this is not a sleight on them, but making a game THIS EPIC takes a lot of man-hours and there are not enough hours in the day haha!

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Fantastic game that I'm enjoying more and more each day as I discover something new. Similar to minecraft with the crafting, mining and trying to survive but with added realism. EDIT: Put a few more hours in now and love it! Perfect to play in single player but I think it plays best with others so you have other players and zombies to worry about.Zombies can pose a real threat and will break through your defenses to hunt you down. Your buildings need to take in to account physics / gravity - you can't place blocks in "thin air". Mines will colapse on top of you if not adequately supported. If you carry raw meat or cooked food then the zombies can smell it if they get close.Multiple ways to play as well. Play by yourself against the zombies, bring friends along to work with you or against you, or go online and join P v P v E servers for some real carnage.Highlight for me so far is a zombie horde tearing our base to pieces just as I was thinking that we were pretty well established.So for an alpha I'm very impressed with the content and how it plays though the game still has a few things to iron out:Hackers - First few online games I played in had the odd hacker. The latest release has an additional cheat protection that is being trialled so hopefully this will help.  EDIT: Not really had problems with hackers since finding a good server with good admin and good protection (IP blocks, Ping limits, EAC and GBL enabled). Glitches - Some graphical glitches allowing me to get out of a sealed underground mine. Not a massive problem. Cooking mechanic can get glitchy and mean more fuel is needed to cook things. EDIT: Still some glitches though gets better with each patch. Not really an issue for single player or PvE and only becomes a slight problem for PvP if people abuse exploits.I think it is worth buying at normal price and a MUST BUY if it goes on sale again (which it no doubt will soon enough).

								I am writing this review in response to Holly nielsons post on how this game is 'wasting its potential'...Ok first of all, it's still in alpha. No this isnt Call of duty where you get kills all the time bc in this game its about survival and dying is really rough. These things are positives for someone who uuses their brain and makes hidden drop boxes with extra sets of gear and thinks ahead for these things. Further more you can always turn up the setting to have zombies set to 'Always Run' a challenge ive been working on for some time now and its very possible and very fun! overall 7 days to die is amazing and the only way to get bored in the game is to stop being creative..mic drop

								7 Days to Die is good zombie apocalypse game that holds on to a realistsic game play style. As a survivor you have to scavenge for everyday necessaties like food and water while avoiding being eaten. The only thing that would make this game better is if it have a few more weapon options and if there was more of a goal to achieve, since after a while you are able to build up a steady supply of everything you need. All in all this game is very good and has been well crafted together. I strongly recommend this game to anyone who is into survival crafting games.

								I am writing this review in response to Holly nielsons post on how this game is 'wasting its potential'...Ok first of all, it's still in alpha. Secondly, for me graphics and animations are by far the least important aspect of a game...gameplay is whats important and 7 Days to Die has some of the funnest gameplay out there, If your a creative person. You see, someone like holly likes to be handed fun on a silver platter where as if you create fun things in a sandbox the limits are endless. The crafting/building aspect of this game alone is better than minecraft and then you add in zombies and the tower defense aspect and you have pure 500 hours plus of fun and andventure without even reaching a max level character or seeing everything in a random gen map. No this isnt Call of duty where you get kills all the time bc in this game its about survival and dying is really rough. These things are positives for someone who uuses their brain and makes hidden drop boxes with extra sets of gear and thinks ahead for these things. Further more you can always turn up the setting to have zombies set to 'Always Run' a challenge ive been working on for some time now and its very possible and very fun! overall 7 days to die is amazing and the only way to get bored in the game is to stop being creative..mic drop

								7 Days to Die is a fun and refreshing survival/horror game. I enjoy the exploration of different biomes and the ability to search and loot practically every building and trash bag in the universe. It's great to play and search alone in singleplayer, but even better when you team up with friends and raid enemy bases and massive skyscrapers! 								7 Days to Die is good zombie apocalypse game that holds on to a realistsic game play style. As a survivor you have to scavenge for everyday necessaties like food and water while avoiding being eaten. A key and realistic feature, however, is the discipline required to effectively survive this onslaught; Ammo conservation and combat restriction (knowing when to pick fights or when to just run) is important as running straight into the zombie horde, guns ablazing will waste valuable resources and your life. The only thing that would make this game better is if it have a few more weapon options and if there was more of a goal to achieve, since after a while you are able to build up a steady supply of everything you need. All in all this game is very good and has been well crafted together. I strongly recommend this game to anyone who is into survival crafting games.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have a policy that I can't "not recommend" any game that beats the $4=1 hour ratio. No matter how much i wind up disliking a game, at the end of the day its there to distract me and if I comit a ludicrous amount of time to it. Then it could be about potato chip eating and I still have to thumbs up it. This game will do what you pay it to do, distract, because it takes alot of time to experiment and discover how shallow the game is.I imagine my reaction to this game was similar to alot of others, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥its like minecraft but the monsters attack your place and you have a reason to set up proper defences. I was ready for a tower defense game, using my wit to slaughter hundreds of enemies instead of brute force.Well, I was wrong. Looking through the crafting menu it would APPEAR that I was right, wood spikes, land mines, fire based items. Buuuuut;  mines you have to replace and screw up the landscape, fires you have to start by hand in the campfire through their ui, and their effeciency is questionable. The only reliable defense are the spikes which degrade pretty rapidly and often times straight up break in 3-4 zombies. They also consume material like no tomorrow via repair and upgrade.So that means Every. Single. Wandering. Zombie you hear bashing at your walls, you have to deal with by hand. This is a brute force game. However, "brute force" basically means having to grind your head off for feathers to make arrows until you find the book and parts to make a yellow (medium) or higher shot gun. Usually by day 10 or so, then you win the game, as nothing will pose a challange anymore. Make a 3 layered wall with iron bars and at that point you're just fighting at night and repairing during the day. There are no more curve balls other than maintenance which is a fricken chore.I don't play alot of multiplayer as many people have complained about having all their work destroyed by other players, so I don't know much about straight pvp. But frankly that concept boggles my mind as there is nothing to gain by killing another player and everything to lose. All of their resources, I guarentee you, are just as prevelant and by consequence worthless as yours. There is no mega difference between a purple hunting rifle and a green one other than the 15% extra times it can be fired before being repaired.My comments would be - get rid of the asinine tempature mechanic, honestly what the ♥♥♥♥! my inventory is small enough without having to devot 6 slots to heat opposites.- and just add an electricity mechanic. That's it, some pistons and redstone and let us use our creative minds to deal with the zombies.TL:DR Consumes hours to find out its pretty shallow, but still consumes them. I would give a f*ck but I hear a zombie outside and now I have to take another 3 sh*t blistering minutes to deal with him by hand like the last 6.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								A11.6 Review (Currently 27 hours played)This game is on track for an awesome release.   The current meat of the game is a very solid apocalyptic zombie survival game that allows a multitude of options from difficulty, to day-night cycle length, to zombie AI behavior (and more) when setting up a single player or multiplayer game.  The combat handles well, the crafting is fun, and the building and upgrading of your home base seems to be coming along great.  Right now you can adventure in the preset world, or let the game procedurally generate a new world for you.  With the ability to generate new random worlds, there's endless territory to explore.Hunger, thirst, health, stamina, wellness - these are your current stats that you need to keep an eye on.  And of course, there's all sorts of injuries and sickness you need to watch out for as well.  Almost everyting in the world is destructable, and most of it yields items or parts you can use to craft something else.  And the main selling point for me, is the ability to setup a co-op, non-friendly-fire game, where I don't have to worry about PvP.  It's just me and my friends, against the zombies and the cruel, harsh environment.Of course, there are bugs to contend with, as it's still alpha, but with monthly updates, and an exciting list of improvements to look forward to, if you like survival games, this one is definitely one to watch.(Will update this review as the game progressess!)

Early Access Review
								A11.6 Review (Currently 27 hours played)This game is on track for an awesome release.   The current meat of the game is a very solid apocalyptic zombie survival game that allows a multitude of options from difficulty, to day-night cycle length, to zombie AI behavior (and more) when setting up a single player or multiplayer game.  The combat handles well, the crafting is fun, and the building and upgrading of your home base seems to be coming along great.  Right now you can adventure in the preset world, or let the game procedurally generate a new world for you.  With the ability to generate new random worlds, there's endless territory to explore.Hunger, thirst, health, stamina, wellness - these are your current stats that you need to keep an eye on.  And of course, there's all sorts of injuries and sickness you need to watch out for as well.  Almost everyting in the world is destructable, and most of it yields items or parts you can use to craft something else.  And the main selling point for me, is the ability to setup a co-op, non-friendly-fire game, where I don't have to worry about PvP.  It's just me and my friends, against the zombies and the cruel, harsh environment.Of course, there are bugs to contend with, as it's still alpha, but with monthly updates, and an exciting list of improvements to look forward to, if you like survival games, this one is definitely one to watch.(Will update this review as the game progressess!)

Posted: January 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Don't let my 116+ hours fool you; I was playing 7 Days to Die in 2013.  Today we are at Alpha 10.4 - well over a year from initial release and I still can't get enough.   For those with a creative mind and a love of all things zombie - you may skip my review and purchase the game with confidence.  For the curious or undecided, please read on.This is a game that stands head and shoulders above all other early-access-survival offerings by far.  Unlike some of those work-in-progress titles, 7 days delivers uncommon depth and the opportunity for unlimited hours of enjoyable gameplay today.  Exciting, challenging and content heavy - you will gather, loot, hunt, farm, cook, mine, forge, craft and build as you fight to survive the zombie apocalypse.RPG elements don't overwhelm but enhance the experience and include full character customisation.  Through a clever 'wellness system' with buffs and debuffs (including clothing, armor, infection, broken bones, hunger, thirst etc.) you have a real reason to invest in your characters upkeep.   The healthier your lifestyle, the stronger you become and the longer you live.   Death - whilst inevitable - is not permanent but comes at the cost of said wellness.  Let it fall too low and as a weakling, you will struggle.Hundreds of loot types from full weapons to tools to scrap metals and seeds must be managed and stored in your custom base.  Build Fort Knox, Edinburgh Castle, an underground lair or a shed made of wood, the choice is yours and with hundreds of materials to use, you are limited only by your imagination, skill and dedication.  Keep in mind - zombies *will* pay your base a visit.Through that dedication, you will go from undressed and unarmed to being an iron clad, heavily armed killing machine, (relatively) safe in your spiked fortress.Other reasons to recommend this wonderful game include :- Tight controls- Handsome visuals- Highly customisable game options- Procedurally generated endless maps or 'Navezgane' - a prefab map- Real physics (think 'Minecraft with gravity')- Free of game-breaking bugs- Tower Defence elements- Large and growing online community- Detailed Wiki and stacks of Youtube content for the beginner- Guaranteed further development by passionate devs (Alpha 11 due late February)- Value for money!- ZOMBIEZ and SHOTGUNS!I've been a gamer since the 1980's, starting with Grundig Pong.  7 Days to Die is *the game* I've always wanted.Thank you Fun Pimps.   My rating : 9/10 (leaving 1 spare point for the completed release!)Right, I'm off to kill some zombies.Besos,Max xP.S.  If I can tack on one slightly negative comment :  Some public servers do currently contain hackers and griefers intent on spoiling your experience.  This said, it is a mostly helpful and friendly online community.

Early Access Review
								Although still Early Access, currently Alpha 14, this captivating game has enough content and replayability to entertain and keep you busy for hundreds of hours if not more. Going forward there is amazing potential and plans in the development process as well. Developers are constantly working on improving and adding new features to this sandbox game. A premade and a random procedurally generated map are the current options for the game world. Haven't played on the premade "Navezgane" map very much but random generated world is fantastic and so much fun, be it single player mode or multiplayer. There are public servers to play on as well. One very noteworthy experience I would like to share is playing on a public PvP server. There are a handful of properly managed servers out there, but when done right with active admins etc., the PvP server experience is comparible to Rust itself and the game struck me as a super detailed (in terms of base building and crafting) and a more relaxed, less hostile PvP version of Rust. It is still kill on sight, but bases are much more safe and durable, which is configurable. As a player who is frustrated with the PvP experience in Rust, this was the perfect alternative for me, couldn't have asked for a better improvement over Rust! Cities and towns to loot, spawn containers to control, air drops and hidden treasures to snatch, base(s) to defend both vs. players and zombie hordes, hunt the wildlife for food, character progression, design a base for security AND aesthetics using many different types of building materials, taking into account gravity and block pyhsics in this voxel based world. Dig an underground bunker, build a tower to the skies, whatever you want!An amazing zombie survival voxel based sandbox game. Much recommendo.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
In Brief7 Days to Die is Day Z-style zombie survival strongest in collaborative play.Most valuable resource: Moments of genuine fear for your life.Of interest to: people who want their zombie apocalypse to be gritty rather than comic-book, or who want to work with their friends to survive.I wrote a review for this game way back when I got it, when I had six hours in it, back in Alpha 5.  Now in Alpha 9 the game has developed and improved so much that I routinely point at it whenever people lambast Early Access as a concept.  7 Days is the very best example I know of an Early Access game on steam that was already a good, playable experience and which has, with community involvement, only become better with each update.I don't want to start listing off features as the game is adding new and improving existing features all the time - just like zombies, I want this review to remain timeless.  What I will say is that since the inclusion of infinite randomly-generated maps, the game has really opened up.  My friend an I originally holed up in the city at which we spawned, hiding on the top floor of an apartment building, scavenging food from the fridges and cupboards of the departed, eking out a meagre existence, until finally, terrorised too many times by acid-vomiting cops, ferocious dogs and the patient stalking of giant wasps, we just picked a direction and walked out into the wilderness.  We walked for hours, raiding every house we passed, watching our food and water supplies slowly diminishing, until finally, out of food, miles from our city base, in a great canyon in an open plain, we made crossbows and started hunting deer.  It took time, and we developed skills needed to take down the beasts.  We fought off zombies attracted by the smell of fresh meat, tracked down every air drop, came up with a plan to gather essential resources and cook food on the go, and then, after days of playing the game together, we felt like we had a handle on things.  With new armour, improved combat skills and a sense of confidence we returned to the city ... and spent a solid hour screaming other over vent as we struggled to survive.Zombie survival is a flooded genre.  What makes this game stand out are that the developers are constantly balancing those elements that focus on survival.  Food drops with just slightly less than the frequency you need it to, but the fullness of your belly is linked to your stamina and health.  Your health regens, but slowly, making you run away from fights that go south and cower for in-game hours waiting until you have recovered.  The crossbow is an exceptional weapon, but requires you to constantly gather feathers for bolts, compelling you to scavenge and keep moving to keep your ammunition count up.  Killing every zombie you see uses time, weapon durability and ammunition, and risks injury, but it also reduces the zombie spawn rate in an area, forcing to decide whether to kill or to avoid.  Zombies will always attack your base, so you make it strong enough to survive the night and then spend the morning repairing the damage.  Guns are powerful weapons, but also make noise, attracting other zombies.  Like no other zombie survival game 7 Days actually feels like survival.Special reference needs to be made to the variety of zombies.  Each looks, moves, sounds and fights a little differently, but the design is perfectly cohesive.  You don't feel you are fighting a cavalcade of comic book nasties; there is a consistency to the way the different zombies operate.  Terrain makes crawlers hard to shoot, but they can injure your legs, making it harder to run away, so you don't want to close with them.  Bloated corpses are really tough to take down, but go down quickly to a head shot, compelling you to stop and aim mid-fight to remove them before they reach you.  Burned corpses have a weird shambling gait that means their head is constantly ducking and bobbing, messing up your shots at range.  The charge of a dog is terrifying, but if you can hold your cool a clean head shot will end them before they reach you.  Wasps - and this is really clever - you can hear coming, their buzzing taunting you, but they don't attack immediately, and in fact targetting them with a weapon causes them to back off, making fighting them - especially when there are other targets to focus on - a real game of stoplight.  Nurses are always worth killing as they sometimes carry essential medications.  Big men may drop sham sandwiches which might keep you fed if you are starving but at the risk of reducing your stamina, preventing you from running from enemies.There are still some balance issues with the game - weapon damage is not in line with materials cost to make them, certain very cheap building materials have very high damage resistance, hordes on the new infinite map are far too scarce.  There are some bugs and some missing features - most notably for me the server time advances when you are not playing, meaning hard work and progress and using up resources from one session don't carry through to the next.  But these are all being tweaked as the game develops, and they are minor things.  If they change nothing else about this game it is already well worth the price, and is a complete experience.As one final word I encourage you to play this game with friends.  Get a private server, set up a skype call, and work together.  It only enhances the survival apocalypse feel of the game.
