content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
Early Access Review
Fans of Telltale's The Walking Dead series will be excited to learn that pre-ordering7 Days to Die will give them exclusive access to 5 character skins from Telltale's hit series, including Michonne and Lee Everett. The console version of 7 Days to Die adds a new multiplayer mode supporting local split-screen for couch play, additional online multiplayer modes and features will be revealed in the coming weeks. 7 Days to Die will be supported by exciting DLC content, with details to be revealed in the near future.Turns out 7 Days to Die is now going to consoles! Good thing the game isn't finished yet. There's also new talk about DLC! Not just any DLC, though, there's also Preorder exclusive DLC,with possible console exclusive splitscreen and multiplayer modes. All with the announcement of a new publisher, Telltale Games. This game is still very broken, full of game breaking bugs, multiplayer dsync, unbalance, crashes, and lack of content and optimization, yet here we are talking about (preorder exclusive) dlc plans, and console ports. The Fun Pimps have lost most of the remaining respect I have. Finish the game before all this new publisher game ruining bull♥♥♥♥♥♥ Pimps. The game isn't even close to being done. Why on Earth would you think this is a good idea? Is this really how you want your game and (its) reputation to die?---------------------------------------------------- Alpha 13 Review7 Days to Die started off pretty good. It seemed really promising and update after update it continued to improve. Now, before I get into the review, I want to say used to love this game. It was my favorite game that I would defend to my grave and have spent nearly 300 hours enjoying. However, after awhile bugs started appearing, and updates kept coming, but they never got rid of the bugs. Not only did the amount of bugs rise, so did the small design flaws and simple mistakes that they can't seem to get around to fixing. In the games current state, it's hardly playable. I find myself either just quitting or resorting to using console commands to cope with the sheer amount of bull♥♥♥♥♥♥that has been taking over this game. Things like weapons iron sites or aim being slightly off, leaving you to use trial and error for awhile until you learn which weapon aims where. The first person animations also leave your weapon stuck in the middle of the screen blocking your aim entirely and preventing you from firing accurately. In addition to FP animations, almost all the animations in the game look really laggy. I assume somehow they all render at 30fps? but it really breaks the look of the game when half of everything plays at half the FPS you do. Console errors are also rampant, removing your mouse cursor, preventing you from searching objects (even your own storage chests which means loss of items), or spamming so many errors you can't play the game anymore becuase the console won't close.If you think that sounds bad, you haven't seen the multiplayer. The netcode is horrible. Zombies snipe you with undodgable lunge attacks, players float all over the place with broken animations, all movements take almost a full second to register with others. It's not too bad if you play PvE, but PvP is out of the question. If you try and host your own private game, have fun only playing with 1-2 other people without the game not working. I have a 6/12 core i7 with a GTX 770 and decent internet. If more than one other person is in my game, the game no longer works for them because they can't open/interact with anything or die from invisible zombies. In addition to that, every player who joins takes off ~20 FPS from my game, taking me from 80 fps down to 30 with a couple of people. The framerate also isn't stable to begin with have constant FPS drops and stuttering.The terrain is a huge pain to work with. Placing blocks/items if there is grass is one of the most infuriating things ever, so you have to punch every individual piece of grass if you want to build there but don't want to struggle. If you're like me and want your bases to look nice and neat, you have to take wood frames and place them on every block in order to level it out. This one is kind of hard to explain unless you've experienced it, but the ground is very uneven and can't be fixed without placing blocks on it to level it out.There's also the wellness system, which remains very unbalanced. It takes a couple of hours of eating healthy to gain 10 wellness, and just one death to remove the hours you just spent raising it. This is very significant because wellness governs your max health and stamina. The lowest wellness you can get is 60, and the highest is 200. The highest I've ever gotten is about 92 (from 60) and that didn't last. I think the system is a neat idea, it's just near impossible to maintain unless you're a god at this game. The bugs aren't the only thing that ruin this game. The developers are doing it almost just as well. Recently with alpha 13, the game took a huge nose dive. There are some good things about it, I like the skill tree, I like how the new forge system works, and I like some aspects of the new UI. Along with alpha 13, though, a ton more bugs were introduced. They also tried to simplify the game, by removing a lot of what made their crafting system unique and enjoyable. They removed the grid which was very useful for crafting quick easy items (now you have to search through multiple menues for the same thing). The menues are now really unintuitive and frustrating to use. You can only set a small amount of waypoints, you can't craft amounts of items higher than 3 didgets, actions require excessive amounts of clicks, and is all around irritating to use. They got rid of the very handy right click menu and have told us they have no plan to return it, as well. The HUD that shows your health, toolbar, etc, was also downgraded. They removed important information like hunger and thirst with no option to put it back, exp counter, and you now have to check your character menu every time to see whether or not you're about to starve. They also for some reason limited the toolbar to only 8 items, instead of 9. The developers also tend to ignore a lot of community feedback and have been known to be hostile to community critics by cussing them out on the forums. Unfortunately, they have a small army of hardcore fanboys that will deny/dismiss/justify all of the negatives. They don't seem like bad guys, though. They work hard, push frequent updates with a good amount of content, and are rightfully proud of their success. It just feels like they've lost track of their original idea and are trying to make the game appeal to a larger audience, and focus on the future rather than the present (more updates/content but lack of fixes for current/past issues).Tl;Dr/ConclusionI know this game is in alpha, and a lot of these may very likely be fixed in the future. In it's current state, though, I cannot recommend it. I try again and again to play this with friends and enjoy the game, but the copious amount of bugs and horrible design decisions and flaws that never get fixed prevent us from enjoying the game. I really wish I wasn't writing this review as I've had so much fun with the game but I can only handle so much. I hope the game will improve with future updates but at the rate that it's been going I don't expect it anytime soon.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								TLDR: 7d2d is, thankfully, one of those early access games that, while somewhat buggy, is extremely playable. This is the game I always wanted Minecraft to be, and is the best of the zombie survival games to date. For why I feel this way, continue reading ;)This is how I see the game _Right Now_. I am not taking into account what the devs are planning to do, the game's potential, or any other such garbage. This is what you can expect right when you download the game, today.I almost passed on this game. I'm burnt out on minecraft, early access games, and unfinished poorly excecuted zombie apocalypse survival games in general. Thankfully, I didn't pass on it, and picked up the 2 pack to play with my wife. 7d2d has given us a lot of fun, and has overall been a pleasant experience. While occasional bugs and unexplained deaths did occur, they were never so frequent as to interfere with our ability to enjoy the game. Usually, when my wife and I play a game like this, we end up getting to a point where the pve is no longer a threat, so we turn to building bigger and better things. With this game, however, there's so many options for customizing the gameplay, that once it's no longer a threat on default settings, we can crank the difficulty way, way up, and extract more fun from the game that way, instead of building giant houses and stuff until I discover how effective pipe bombs are at making her latest monument to boredom go away. (Holy run-on Batman! Quick, get the grammar nazi reppellant!) On that note, I'll spare you from further rambling with a nice little list.The Good:-Excellent Atmosphere and tension.-Extensive Crafting.-Loads of fun with friends.-Built in challenges, without smacking you over the head and saying, "Oh look, if you beat me instead of hiding in your little hole, I'll give you an achievement." (The supply drop is an excellent mechanic.)-Zombies will make you afraid of the dark.-Extensive customization options. Want a hardcore mode? check. Want turbo zombies? check. Want hundreds of zombies that are as dangerous as baby seals? check. Infinite day/night? check. Pvp on/off? check. Create the experience and challenge that you want, not what they want you to have.-Managing your stamina, food, and water is critical to success, and not a tacked on checkbox for a survival game.-Looting takes time. (can be changed in the options)-Things make sense. Meaning, water needs to be boiled before used, meat cooked, wood is weaker than rock, etc.-The smell/scent system is well done, and a very enjoyable mechanic.The Bad:-Zombie Dogs.-Zombie Dogs early game, when you have no weapon.-Most of the bugs I ran into were with the dedicated server client.-Pathfinding and AI still needs work. (Allegedly this will be improved in an upcoming patch.)-Occasionally difficult to find the crafting recipe you need.-Random death for no apparent cause. This happened to me several times, and while it's entirely possible/likely that I died from something that I overlooked, if that's the case, it should be made far more apparent in the UI than it is now.-Most of the time upon killing a crawling zombie, the model will stretch/distort in a bizzarre fashion, leaving it difficult or impossible to loot.-The sound effects could be better. (I swear the sound effect the zombie dog uses when hit is the same sound a gnoll makes when getting hit in everquest.)-Dirt blocks break into octahedra (2 pyramids put together,) which just feels a little ackward, and makes it so that judging block size and distance requires practice.-You have to set all your options (graphics, sound, etc) before you join a game, as once you have, your 2 options are either "quit" or "suicide."-Zombie dogs.In conclusion, if you're on the fence about this game, or if survival games are your thing, do yourself a favor and pick this one up, it's worth it.

Early Access Review
								So, today I was sent a request to do a game review for a game I recently bought called 7 Days to Die. Supposedly my game reviews are famous now or something. Dunno what's up with that...Anyway, as for 7 Days to Die, I would say this game has a lot of potential. That's the thing with early access games, especially ones that are still in the Alpha stage. As it is now, the game definitely has an unfinished feel to it I think. However, with what it has now as a base, and adding on top of it the features that the game creators are planning for it? This game is really going to go far, and I can't wait to see it. That's the second reason I bought this game, the potential it has, and the potential it has is enormous.One of the coolest things about this game though is that it's the closest thing to a proper sequel to Minecraft right now. It uses the Voxel engine though so the best way I could describe it for looks would be taking Half Life 2 and making it completely destructible. Pretty amazing ne?As for the gameplay itself, that's a touch lacking, especially knowing some of the things they plan to add to the game later. Don't get me wrong, for an Alpha, it's pretty far along and pretty darn expansive, but considering the sheer amount of features they've yet to add, it's understandable why they still have the game listed as Alpha. The crafting system is really good. Some parts are a little weird, like only being able to get sticks from breaking apart bushes, rather than being able to snap off branches for sticks, and the game relies on Scrap Metal as its base staple resource for building tools, and you can only get that if you break metal things or if you scavenge for it.The game has a bigger focus on survival than Minecraft does. Zombies are currently the main enemy of the game, and they're dangerous, in that they can spawn at any time in any light source, which means even if you make it impossible for Zombies to get into your base, if you go out far enough, they will spawn in it regardless. That's one of my biggest complaints for the game currently. Minecraft did a better job by making mobs only spawn in darkness since that means there's an actual designated safe zone that you can create. In this game, currently, no where is safe, and the ambiance reflects that with some fairly creepy music and the sound of a guy whispering in a cult-ish voice that echoes on the wind(yes that's a word now). The game is also going to have a story, but it hasn't really been implemented yet. I'm guessing the whispering is going to have something to do with it, thought it's any guess what it is, since scattered news papers on the ground talk about everything from epidemics to nuclear war for the cause of this post apocalyptic world.Let's see... as for anything I don't really like about this game... I already mentioned the Zombies spawning no matter what... they can break through anything you can, but that's a deliberate game mechanic... I'm not so fond of the food/water/stamina system... I realize it's also for survival, but currently water can only be carried in jars that are consumed when you drink them, which is really really annoying. Hopefully this game will have an equipable canteen and food satchel, cause right now, water takes up half my inventory and food is difficult to come by, unless you find a corn field, but raw food like corn hardly feeds you. I don't know about you, but I'd feel pretty full after eating three corn cobs let alone 15.Oh there is one other thing I really dislike, but this is more of a glitch than anything I hope and will get fixed soon. If you ever get this game, do yourself a favor and stay away from corn fields, or at least get in and get out if you want the corn and seeds. Entities such as yourself, zombies, and animals break resource plants when they walk on them. I can't tell you how annoyed I was when the game suddenly started lagging like crazy because a bunny and a couple of stags decided to spawn in the middle of a corn field and run around AT THE SAME TIME. I think the only reason my game didn't crash is because my computer is ridiculously high end. Nevermind the fact that I had enemy spawning turned off. If zombies had been in that mess shambling everywhere and chasing the animals through the corn field, wrecking things themselves... ugh...But yeah. Other than that, this game is looking really good. I really hope they implement a way to stop zombies from spawning in certain areas soon though, cause until that happens, I don't really like playing the game with enemy spawning on, which kind of takes away from the challenge of the game itself.Huh. Just thought of something interesting. In all honestly, the best zombie survival game I've ever played is a flash game called Rebuild and Rebuild 2 (The sequel is actually better than the first. Surprising ne?) In that series, Zombies don't just spawn anywhere. They have a designated spawning zone, since some dumb cultists opened a portal to a Nether world and Zombies pour out of it. Sometimes there'd be more than one portal, and since the game setting is that of a town you have to utilize your survivors to be able to take back and defend, the town is surrounded on all sides by a forest, and there are other towns with portals open so Zombies come from those towns as well, and thus coming from the edges of the map. If they implemented THAT particular system for 7 Days to Die, that would be awesome. Like, when the world is first created, each area has a set number of Zombies, and as time goes on more come in from Death Portals as well as the borders of the map! That way instead of just survival, the game will have a somewhat clear set of objectives and goals. After all, humans as a rule don't want to just survive, we want to thrive!

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing! It focuses on realism in many different ways, which i find challanging and a welcome relief from today's cut and dried "shoot and be shot" games. You need to forage the zombie infested wilderness, be stealthy, quick and resourceful. Gathering food and water is a constant concern. The water you gather must be boiled or you will get diarrhea and suffer a slow death unless you can make yourself some herbal tea to cure yourself. Food, which can be obtained by looting houses, dead zombies, old cars and trash, can also be hunted. If you hunt and get yourself some nice fresh rabbit or boar meat, zombies can smell you for miles around. This creates an interesting challange and a necessary risk, that you need to quickly cook and contain the meat before you are set upon by zombies. Finding shelter is, in its self, an interesting challange too. Zombies can destroy walls and doors just as well as you can, so fortifying your home or making traps is recommended. Even just staying in your house, using a fireplace or smelting guns or armor can attract zombies. At night zombies run, and there are more than one type. The zombie dogs are particularly lethal. You can plant crops or minecraft it up by digging deep and finding coal and iron and potassium nitrate. With these you can make ammo and guns and armor which are a must if you plan to do more than just survive. You can choose from a premade world, or much like minecraft, a world that is generated. This game is co-op, meaning you can invite your buddies to play with you or just play solo and tough it out yourself. The game is early access, so it is being updated. Updates can be read about on their website. I reccomend this to anyone who likes killing zombies, exploration, survival and crafting.

Posted: April 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								One of the best games I've ever played.   It might not seem like much at first but then as you uncover this gem over time you realize that there is a ton of strategy invloved as well as those oh $hit moments of rapid clicking and heart pounding fun!  Not to mention that you can easily setup the game as you want to play it.  In addition to that, the devs have set it up so that you can easily change the xml files they provided to customize it even further.  Oh, and lets not forget the large community of modders, who share ideas, files, and how to's.This game is still in Alpha, and it's already better and more feature complete than most Triple AAA backed titles out there.  The devs have definitely shown, time and again that this is more than a game to them, it's their wonder child that they've created.   There are game updates that include new features with each release and even recently an entire game engine update overhaul to improve graphics!   The devs for this game care so much that they actually listen to their community and share stuff with them all the time.  I've played so many games that are just rushed to final release just to cash-in and walk away from leaving you feel that there is something missing or unbalanced or just broken.  THIS IS NOT one of those games!Also because of the interaction with the devs, this game community in itself is one of the most thoughtful, helpful, and funny that I've been associated with.  The forum moderators will help you troubleshoot, give advice, and point you in the direction of the answers that you need to get things going, or even just to help you with answers to the what and how to's.I would completely recommend this game to anyone that is thinking of buying it without hesitation.  All the while knowing that it will get even better with each update!Quick review, it's a 11/10 game that has come a long way and is already better than 99% finished games out there and  improving all the time!   Do yourself a favor and purchase it for yourself, a friend or several friends and have a blast!!!

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								I got this game just after I came out, and I have to say, as far as Alphas go, this one should win an award.  I have recommended this game to many of my gaming freinds, and they have all bought it and we play it together often through my easily configured dedicated server.There is something in here for everyone.  If you like killing zombies, mining, building, crafting, and exploring, this is definitely for you.  Nothing is more gratifying than walking up to a zombie and smashing them one in the face with your bare fist.  Or if you're in to guns, 7 days will not disappoint.  Sure, most of the weapons are generic, but whether you like donning  a pistol, or taking out a crowd of zombies with a rocket launcher, then it here.I am also fond of the forging and crafting system.  Once you learn recipes, you can strip down a weapon to its bare parts, create a mold of these parts and then manufacture all the weapons but the rocket launcher.  You can even craft your own bullets using the method described above.I love the two power tools, the chainsaw and the auger.  Not only are these great for gathering wood and stone, but they make quick work of any zombies.This game is filled with pure enjoyment, despite the occasional bug here and there.The Fun Pimps are great at what they do.  Although they have not implemented all the features detailed in the video, they have been consistant at following the road map of development.I would give this game 5 stars, and it, even in alpha I would give it a metacritic rating of 95.Bottom line:  Pure enjoyment! Worth more than just a cursory glance.

Surprising ne?) In that series, Zombies don't just spawn anywhere. They have a designated spawning zone, since some dumb cultists opened a portal to a Nether world and Zombies pour out of it. Sometimes there'd be more than one portal, and since the game setting is that of a town you have to utilize your survivors to be able to take back and defend, the town is surrounded on all sides by a forest, and there are other towns with portals open so Zombies come from those towns as well, and thus coming from the edges of the map. If they implemented THAT particular system for 7 Days to Die, that would be awesome. Like, when the world is first created, each area has a set number of Zombies, and as time goes on more come in from Death Portals as well as the borders of the map! That way instead of just survival, the game will have a somewhat clear set of objectives and goals. After all, humans as a rule don't want to just survive, we want to thrive!

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing! It focuses on realism in many different ways, which i find challanging and a welcome relief from today's cut and dried "shoot and be shot" games. You need to forage the zombie infested wilderness, be stealthy, quick and resourceful. Gathering food and water is a constant concern. The water you gather must be boiled or you will get diarrhea and suffer a slow death unless you can make yourself some herbal tea to cure yourself. Food, which can be obtained by looting houses, dead zombies, old cars and trash, can also be hunted. If you hunt and get yourself some nice fresh rabbit or boar meat, zombies can smell you for miles around. This creates an interesting challange and a necessary risk, that you need to quickly cook and contain the meat before you are set upon by zombies. Finding shelter is, in its self, an interesting challange too. Zombies can destroy walls and doors just as well as you can, so fortifying your home or making traps is recommended. Even just staying in your house, using a fireplace or smelting guns or armor can attract zombies. At night zombies run, and there are more than one type. The zombie dogs are particularly lethal. You can plant crops or minecraft it up by digging deep and finding coal and iron and potassium nitrate. With these you can make ammo and guns and armor which are a must if you plan to do more than just survive. You can choose from a premade world, or much like minecraft, a world that is generated. This game is co-op, meaning you can invite your buddies to play with you or just play solo and tough it out yourself. The game is early access, so it is being updated. Updates can be read about on their website. I reccomend this to anyone who likes killing zombies, exploration, survival and crafting.

Early Access Review
								I got this game just after I came out, and I have to say, as far as Alphas go, this one should win an award.  I have recommended this game to many of my gaming freinds, and they have all bought it and we play it together often through my easily configured dedicated server.There is something in here for everyone.  If you like killing zombies, mining, building, crafting, and exploring, this is definitely for you.  Nothing is more gratifying than walking up to a zombie and smashing them one in the face with your bare fist.  Or if you're in to guns, 7 days will not disappoint.  Sure, most of the weapons are generic, but whether you like donning  a pistol, or taking out a crowd of zombies with a rocket launcher, then it here.I am also fond of the forging and crafting system.  Once you learn recipes, you can strip down a weapon to its bare parts, create a mold of these parts and then manufacture all the weapons but the rocket launcher.  You can even craft your own bullets using the method described above.I love the two power tools, the chainsaw and the auger.  Not only are these great for gathering wood and stone, but they make quick work of any zombies.This game is filled with pure enjoyment, despite the occasional bug here and there.The Fun Pimps are great at what they do.  Although they have not implemented all the features detailed in the video, they have been consistant at following the road map of development.I would give this game 5 stars, and it, even in alpha I would give it a metacritic rating of 95.Bottom line:  Pure enjoyment! Worth more than just a cursory glance.
